lead_paragraph: The primary season is about to shift into overdrive with Super Tuesday, when Republican voters in 15 states will cast their votes.

headline: Who Is Winnie Greco, the Adams Aide Whose Houses the F.B.I. Searched?
abstract: Federal agents descended on two properties owned by Ms. Greco, the mayor’s director of Asian affairs who traveled with him to China.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, F.B.I. agents searched two houses in the Bronx owned by Winnie Greco, a close aide to Mayor Eric Adams of New York City.

headline: 2 Charged After Pouring Red Powder Over Case Holding U.S. Constitution
abstract: Two activists poured the powder over the protective case at the National Archives Museum last month to call attention to climate change, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two climate activists who dumped red powder over the display case that contains the U.S. Constitution at the National Archives Museum last month were charged on Thursday with destruction of government property, prosecutors said.

headline: What Are the Largest Wildfires in U.S. History?
abstract: The Smokehouse Creek fire in the Texas Panhandle is now one of the largest fires the country has faced. Here are five of the others.
lead_paragraph: Fueled by dry grass, harsh winds and unseasonably warm temperatures, the Smokehouse Creek fire in the Texas Panhandle has now burned more than 1.1 million acres, making it the largest fire in the state’s recorded history.

headline: Inside the E.P.A. Decision to Narrow Two Big Climate Rules
abstract: Michael Regan, the E.P.A. administrator, said the Biden administration would meet its climate goals despite tweaking regulations on automobiles and power plants
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s climate ambitions are colliding with political and legal realities, forcing his administration to recalibrate two of its main tools to cut the emissions that are heating the planet.

headline: Biden Unites With an Unlikely Ally to Champion Ukraine
abstract: In a visit to the White House by Italy’s far-right prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, the president declared that “we have each other’s backs” and “we also have Ukraine’s back.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden turned to an unlikely ally on Friday in his drive to build support for Ukraine’s war effort as U.S. aid falters, declaring during a White House visit by the far-right prime minister of Italy that the two leaders “have each other’s backs” and “have Ukraine’s back.”

headline: News Leaders Around the World Pledge Support for Journalists in Gaza
abstract: Leaders from The Associated Press, Reuters and others called for the safety of the Palestinian media workers doing the on-the-ground reporting.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 60 leaders from international and regional news outlets signed a letter on Thursday and Friday committing their support for journalists covering the war in Gaza and calling for their safety and the freedom to do their work amid intense personal risk.

headline: Many Iranians Boycott Vote, Despite Officials’ Pleas and Roses at Polls
abstract: Ordinary Iranians, fed up with a faltering economy and the government’s oppressive rules and violent crackdowns on peaceful protests, heeded calls to stay home.
lead_paragraph: Iran held parliamentary elections on Friday, but despite officials’ last-minute attempts to increase voter turnout with pleas on social media and roses at polling stations, many people stayed away from the ballot in an act of protest against the government, according to witnesses, interviews and news reports.

headline: Iris Apfel, Eye-Catcher With a Kaleidoscopic Wardrobe, Dies at 102
abstract: She came to fame in the fashion world in her 80s and 90s, and her wildly eclectic closet of clothes formed a hit exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Iris Apfel, a New York society matron and interior designer who late in life knocked the socks off the fashion world with a brash bohemian style that mixed hippie vintage and haute couture, found treasures in flea markets and reveled in contradictions, died on Friday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 102.

headline: Oregon Is Recriminalizing Drugs, Dealing Setback to Reform Movement
abstract: Oregon removed criminal penalties for possessing street drugs in 2020. But amid soaring overdose deaths, state lawmakers have voted to bring back some restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when Oregon voters approved a pioneering plan to decriminalize hard drugs, advocates looking to halt the jailing of drug users believed they were on the edge of a revolution that would soon sweep across the country.

headline: More Than a Thousand Mourners Pack Church to Honor Student Killed in Georgia
abstract: Laken Riley, whose death became enmeshed in the nation’s bitter debate over immigration, was remembered as a warm and caring woman who “shined so bright.”
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 mourners braved the rain and blustery chill outside to pack the Woodstock City Church on Friday for the funeral of Laken Riley, the 22-year-old nursing student killed last week on the University of Georgia campus, 70 miles away.

headline: Federal Regulators to Review Nonbinary Student’s Death in Oklahoma
abstract: The U.S. Department of Education said it had opened an investigation into whether a high school “failed to appropriately respond” to reports of harassment of Nex Benedict, who died a day after a fight in a school bathroom.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Education said on Friday that it had opened an investigation into the Oklahoma school district where a 16-year-old student, Nex Benedict, died a day after an altercation inside a high school bathroom.

headline: Newsom Faces Questions Over ‘Sausage Making’ in Wage Law
abstract: The California governor last year said a fast-food minimum wage law didn’t apply to Panera Bread because of the “nature of negotiation.” He changed course after a scathing report suggested otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California has increasingly been a national presence, flying to Washington to meet with President Biden, appearing on Sunday news shows and targeting conservative states with ads for reproductive rights.

headline: They’re in Circulation
abstract: Natan Last rolls up with a heart-thumping themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Natan Last is one of those constructors whose grids are recognizably zingy, and often visually striking. When I see his byline, I expect a solve with humor and more pop culture than ancient history in the trivia references. This crossword delivered on those fronts, and it also dealt me a surprise: After winging through its upper portion and its fantastic center swath, I simply could not catch a break in the bottom right corner. All my hunches were horrible, and I stared at it for an eon before going for a walk, after which a few ideas arose, proved correct and got me to the finish.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How Digital Tools Nabbed a 30-Year Fugitive
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t stress enough that some of these tools can and will further be abused by bad actors.”

headline: South Korea Needs Foreign Workers, but Often Fails to Protect Them
abstract: Though a shrinking population makes imported labor vital, migrant workers routinely face predatory employers, inhumane conditions and other abuse.
lead_paragraph: Samsung phones. Hyundai cars. LG TVs. South Korean exports are available in virtually every corner of the world. But the nation is more dependent than ever before on an import to keep its factories and farms humming: foreign labor.

headline: How a Small-Time Soccer Team Draws a Crowd: With Its Activism
abstract: The Dublin club Bohemians has made support for social causes a crucial part of its identity. Critics say the hipsters have taken over, but the approach has attracted fans around the world.
lead_paragraph: In the back room of the threadbare offices of the Irish soccer team Bohemians, the printer clunks and chugs and whirs incessantly, spitting out a cascade of shipping labels. Some of the addresses bear the names of nearby Dublin streets. Others are from farther afield: across Ireland, across the Irish Sea, across the Atlantic.

headline: Surprisingly Weak Ukrainian Defenses Help Russian Advance
abstract: Ukraine only built a sparse, rudimentary defensive line outside Avdiivka. Russia is taking advantage.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine only built a sparse, rudimentary defensive line outside Avdiivka. Russia is taking advantage.

headline: Corrections: March 2, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a possible link between vaccines for respiratory syncytial virus and a rare neurological condition referred incorrectly to illnesses prevented by R.S.V. vaccines. They prevent an estimated 25,000 outpatient visits, not hospitalizations.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How a Foodie and Business Promoter in Queens Spends His Sundays
abstract: Dirk McCall de Palomá starts his day with Diet Coke and ends with RuPaul. In between, he is bound to be trying a new restaurant in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Dirk McCall de Palomá is a serious epicurean seeker of spicy and ethnic food, and a passionate connector of people. For the past two years, he has also been the executive director at the Sunnyside Shines business improvement district, a nonprofit funded by the city that promotes Sunnyside, Queens, as a destination.

headline: Big Labor Gamble: Push to Unionize Every U.S. Auto Plant
abstract: A looming election at a Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga could be pivotal in the United Automobile Workers’ effort to organize the entire industry.
lead_paragraph: When Shawn Fain, the United Automobile Workers president, unveiled the deal that ended six weeks of strikes at Ford Motor in the fall, he framed it as part of a longer campaign. Next, he declared, would be the task of organizing nonunion plants across the country.

headline: As Trump’s Criminal Trial Approaches, He May Be His Own Worst Enemy
abstract: In civil cases, Donald J. Trump has ordered attorneys around from the defense table and insisted on testifying. The stakes will get higher March 25, when his first criminal case begins.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was minutes away from being grilled under oath by the New York attorney general and he was itching to talk. To fend off the state’s fraud investigation, the former president insisted on answering every question, believing he alone knew what to say.

headline: Blasphemy Is a Crime in Pakistan. Mobs Are Delivering the Verdicts.
abstract: Being convicted of the charge can bring a death sentence in the country. But simply being accused of disrespect toward Islam can also be enough to get a person killed.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, hundreds of people protested in major Pakistani cities over a blasphemy ruling by a top judge, who also faced an online backlash and threats. Two days later, a police officer in Punjab Province rescued a woman from attack by people who had mistaken Arabic script on her dress for Quranic verses.

headline: It’s Me, Hi, I’m the Problem. I’m 33.
abstract: Meet the 1990 and 1991 babies, a massive microgeneration in lifelong competition for America’s economic resources, reshaping the world around them.
lead_paragraph: I have covered economics for 11 years now, and in that time, I have come to the realization that I am a statistic. Every time I make a major life choice, I promptly watch it become the thing that everyone is doing that year.

headline: A New-Look Circus Sends in the Clowns, but Loses the Face Paint.
abstract: As the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus hits the road for the first time in seven years, gone are the tigers, elephants and Pennywise-esque clowns.
lead_paragraph: There are no tigers and elephants; in fact, the only “animal” is an electric dog named Bailey. The clowns are still there, but hardly wear any makeup.

headline: On the Trail of the Denisovans
abstract: DNA has shown that the extinct humans thrived around the world, from chilly Siberia to high-altitude Tibet — perhaps even in the Pacific islands.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals may have vanished 40,000 years ago, but they are no strangers to us today. Their stocky skeletons dazzle in museums around the world. Their imagined personas star in television ads. When Kevin Bacon noted on Instagram that his morning habits are like those of a Neanderthal, he did not stop to explain that our ancient cousins interbred with modern humans expanding out of Africa.

headline: Sarayu Blue Is Pristine on ‘Expats’ but ‘Such a Little Weirdo’ IRL
abstract: Blue performs alongside Nicole Kidman in the Prime Video series, but when she’s not working, she said, “I genuinely love just sitting somewhere and getting lost in a daydream.”
lead_paragraph: Sarayu Blue describes Hilary Starr, the affluent professional she plays in the Prime Video series “Expats,” as sharp. Very sharp.

headline: University of Idaho Needs More Students. Should It Buy an Online School?
abstract: Ahead of an expected drop in enrollment, the institution is looking to buy the University of Phoenix, a for-profit school with a checkered past. Is it worth $550 million?
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, the University of Idaho’s plan to take over the University of Phoenix, a for-profit online school, is either a sweet deal or a potential disaster.

headline: In Powerful D.C. Ward, Democrats Move to Oust Councilman Over Crime Surge
abstract: The effort to recall Charles Allen, spearheaded by Democratic operatives who once backed him, reflects how a response to a rise in crime has cut across ideological lines.
lead_paragraph: Before a standing-room-only crowd in an office building in Southeast Washington on a recent night, Tonya Fulkerson, a veteran Democratic fund-raiser, described the shootout that broke out last year in broad daylight on her street blocks from the U.S. Capitol.

headline: At Flamenco Festival, Molting Into a New Idea of Spanish Dance
abstract: Olga Pericet’s “La Leona” and a dance panorama by Ballet Nacional de España look to the past, with an eye to recovery and invention.
lead_paragraph: For Olga Pericet, flamenco is an invitation: to play and to explore the limits of her imagination onstage. “I like to keep things spontaneous and alive,” she said in an interview from Madrid. Pericet, who comes from a family of flamenco dancers and teachers, has a deep respect for the traditions of the form. But she also finds inspiration in unexpected places, like Quentin Tarantino’s films or the dances of Martha Graham. “I’m bipolar that way,” she said. “I like to mix it all.”

headline: Composer, Uninterrupted: Christian Wolff at 90
abstract: Wolff, the last representative of the New York School that included John Cage and Morton Feldman, will celebrate his birthday with a concert at Judson Memorial Church.
lead_paragraph: If artistic stature worked by osmosis, Christian Wolff could claim greatness based on that alone. “My father met Brahms,” he said, easing into conversation at a sturdy wooden table in the dining room of his Hanover, N.H., home. That meeting was in 1896, when Brahms was in Bonn, Germany, for Clara Schumann’s funeral. Wolff’s father was 6 or 7.

headline: The Core of the Tax Code Will Change, but We Don’t Know How
abstract: Important regulations expire at the end of next year, thwarting tax planning and creating a monumental fiscal challenge for Congress.
lead_paragraph: Navigating the byzantine U.S. tax rules and completing your return may be enough of a headache.

headline: The Absurd Problem of New York City Trash
abstract: Is this how one of the world's greatest cities still deals with garbage? Here’s what will be required to take New York’s trash bags off the street.
lead_paragraph: Is this how one of the world's greatest cities still deals with garbage? Here’s what will be required to take New York’s trash bags off the street.

headline: Why Some Colombians Call Their Mothers ‘Your Mercy’
abstract: Two centuries after independence from Spain, many Colombians still use “sumercé,” meaning “your mercy” as an everyday address.
lead_paragraph: After Altair Jaspe moved from Venezuela to the Colombian capital, Bogotá, she was taken aback by the way she was addressed when she walked into any shop, cafe or doctor’s office.

headline: When an Artist Dies, Who Owns Her Story?
abstract: The Cuban artist Ana Mendieta fell from a window of her 34th-floor apartment in 1985. Her family members have been fighting for control of her legacy ever since.
lead_paragraph: It was an evening in late January, and Raquel Cecilia Mendieta was dining at the Parador, the 12th-century monastery-turned-hotel where she was staying while she installed artwork for a new survey of Ana Mendieta, the famous Cuban-born performance artist — and Ms. Mendieta’s maternal aunt — at a nearby museum.

headline: What Is a Mortgage Servicer, and How Do You Avoid a Shady One?
abstract: Your mortgage lender can sell the servicing of your loan to a different company. You can’t stop that, but you can protect yourself.
lead_paragraph: Q: Here at Ask Real Estate, we recently received a reader’s question about poor treatment by mortgage servicers. Many first-time home buyers don’t realize that the lender that approves their mortgage could turn around and sell the servicing rights to a company they’ve never heard of. Now the homeowner might have to deal with a mortgage servicer that has bad customer service, charges late fees when it shouldn’t, or makes needless demands on borrowers. How can you protect yourself from having to do business with a bad mortgage servicer?

headline: ‘I’m Matt.’ For Some Politicians, Addiction Battles Drive Policymaking.
abstract: Elected leaders in recovery are sharing their histories of drug abuse, fueled by worry over the epidemic that’s killing so many Americans.
lead_paragraph: Around a long wooden table at San Francisco City Hall, nine people battling drug addiction swapped news on a recent Friday.

headline: Tana French’s Moody, Mesmerizing New Thriller
abstract: “The Hunter,” set in western Ireland, is a sequel to 2020’s “The Searcher.”
lead_paragraph: Four years ago in these pages, the critic Janet Maslin published a guide to “the essential Tana French.” For some of French’s fans, all the novels are essential. Others prefer her standalones or her Dublin Murder Squad series — six loosely connected mysteries that explore different viewpoints and settings within the reassuring confines of one department. Unpredictability and a refusal to be boring are part of French’s talent, and they make the books (almost) as much fun to debate as they are to read.

headline: Racial Turnout Gap Has Widened With a Weakened Voting Rights Act, Study Finds
abstract: The Black share of the electorate had been on the rise for decades, but in some counties, a Supreme Court decision in 2013 changed that, according to a new analysis.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court knocked down a core part of the Voting Rights Act in 2013, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. argued that some of the law’s protections against racial discrimination were no longer necessary.

headline: It Was a Historically Wet February in L.A., and Winter’s Not Over Yet
abstract: Last month was the fourth-wettest February in the city’s recorded history.
lead_paragraph: February was the wettest month in downtown Los Angeles since 1998. With over 12 inches of rain drenching the city, it was the fourth-wettest February — and the seventh-wettest month overall — in the city’s nearly 150-year recorded history.

headline: Disgraced but Embraced: Pop Culture Pariahs Are Making Big Comebacks
abstract: Shane Gillis hosted “S.N.L.,” the show that rebuffed him. Ye topped the Billboard chart after making antisemitic remarks. Has the mainstream given up on banishing bad actors?
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, the comedian Shane Gillis hosted “Saturday Night Live,” five years after he was fired from the show before ever appearing on it, when old podcast appearances in which he’d used slurs were brought to light. During his opening monologue, Gillis showed how he had evolved since then, which is to say, only slightly. In a tame bit about his parents, he fondly recalled spending time with his mother when he was younger, noting sweetly, “Every little boy is just their mom’s gay best friend.”

headline: Don’t Drown in That Dead-End Job
abstract: To get out of a losing work situation, you have to be relentless — and just get started.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Why Mainers Are Falling Hard for Heat Pumps
abstract: The percentage of households burning home heating oil is the highest in the country. Yet no other state is adopting climate-friendly heat pumps as fast.
lead_paragraph: It may have been a warmer than usual winter in Maine, but that doesn’t mean it hasn’t gotten mighty cold. In mid-January in Farmingdale, a town outside Augusta where Kaylie McLaughlin lives, the temperature dipped to 6 degrees Fahrenheit. “The kind of cold that hurts,” she said.

headline: Scenes From the Smokehouse Creek Fire in Texas
abstract: The fire, which has burned over a million acres in the state’s Panhandle, is still largely uncontrolled. Here’s a look at the damage it has done so far.
lead_paragraph: The Smokehouse Creek fire is the largest on record in Texas. Since it started on Monday, the blaze has burned over a million acres of land in the state’s Panhandle, much of which is cattle country.

headline: Barbie and Bella: Two Different Shades of Female Liberation
abstract: The Oscar best picture hopefuls “Barbie” and “Poor Things” look nothing alike, but their central characters go on similar journeys.
lead_paragraph: One takes place in a bright, plastic world where everything is coated in pink. The other takes place in an isolated black-and-white world that transforms, “Wizard of Oz” style, into a flashy, steampunk domain.

headline: Voters Doubt Biden’s Leadership and Favor Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
abstract: The share of voters who strongly disapprove of President Biden’s handling of his job has reached 47 percent, higher than in Times/Siena polls at any point in his presidency.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is struggling to overcome doubts about his leadership inside his own party and broad dissatisfaction over the nation’s direction, leaving him trailing behind Donald J. Trump just as their general-election contest is about to begin, a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College has found.

headline: In Los Angeles, Even an Art Fair Is Really About the Parties

lead_paragraph: “I think Frieze is fantastic,” James Corden said. “I went to the one in London before anyone in L.A. even knew what it was.”

lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk sued OpenAI and its chief executive, Sam Altman, for breach of contract on Thursday, he turned claims by the start-up’s closest partner, Microsoft, into a weapon.

headline: The Big Change Between the 2020 and 2024 Races: Biden Is Unpopular
abstract: Donald Trump has the largest national lead in an NYT poll since first running for president in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Let’s just say it: Joe Biden should be expected to win this election. He’s an incumbent president running for re-election with a reasonably healthy economy against an unpopular opponent accused of multiple federal crimes.

headline: Brian Mulroney Divided and Reshaped Canada Through Free Trade With the U.S.
abstract: The former prime minister, who died this week, brought dramatic changes, good and bad, to the country’s economy with the pact.
lead_paragraph: Brian Mulroney first led the Progressive Conservatives to power while I was early in my career as a journalist. But his political life was never something that I covered in any great detail. His decision to negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States transformed Canada’s economic history and did, however, consume much of my work life for several years.

headline: Why We Can’t Stop Rushing
abstract: We know that happiness is to be found in taking our time and being present. How can we slow down?
lead_paragraph: Racing to catch a subway train recently, I tripped on the stairs leading to the platform, steadying myself only barely by grabbing the arm of an unsuspecting and rightfully alarmed fellow passenger. I sustained no major damage — a scraped knee, a bruise on my thigh I’d discover a week later. These injuries were, I told myself in the aftermath, well deserved. I’d disregarded one of my precepts for personal happiness, the one that stipulates, “Most misery is caused by rushing.”

headline: What You Need to Know for the 2024 Tax Season
abstract: There are tax breaks for electric car purchases, SALT workarounds, benefits for retirees and a new system for eligible taxpayers to file their returns.
lead_paragraph: Filing your tax return serves as an annual reminder of just how tediously complex the American tax code is — and this year is no exception.

abstract: Sure, the West applies more scrutiny to Israel than to other countries, but that shouldn’t deflect from the catastrophe in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Does the West have a double standard when it comes to Israel, pouncing on everything it does with undue harshness?

headline: The Justice of Israel’s War in Gaza Will Depend on How It Ends
abstract: How to think about the moral complexities in the Israel-Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: When the United States and its Middle Eastern allies went to war against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, there was nothing clean or surgical about the campaign.

headline: The Unexpected Celebrity of Adam Schiff
abstract: Adam Schiff’s resistance to Trump has made him a Democratic hero in California, to the frustration of candidates farther to the left.
lead_paragraph: “I have to go get a photo of Adam!”

abstract: Only in D.C. do you dream about the State of the Union.

headline: The Fires Sweeping Across Texas Offer a Terrifying Warning
abstract: We’re entering clima incognita.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, as flames from the Smokehouse Creek fire raced eastward across the Texas Panhandle for the fourth straight day at speeds faster than a person can run, a cold front, driving a snow squall, swept southward over the Great Plains. In an elemental collision, the fire and snow met east of Amarillo, the swirling flakes joining and then melting into the smoke and ash of the colossal prairie fire.

headline: Yousef
abstract: Can he find his family a safe place to stay in Gaza?
lead_paragraph: Yousef Hammash has been moving his family from one place to another in Gaza for five months. He always finds options. Now his youngest sister is about to have a baby, and everyone may need to move again. They’re all looking to Yousef to find one more option.

headline: Two Books About Lovable Unlikable People
abstract: Molly recommends a novel about a scornful teenager and a collection of interviews about a difficult filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Big Questions Raised by Elon Musk’s Lawsuit Against OpenAI
abstract: Experts say the case against the start-up and its chief executive, Sam Altman, raises unusual legal points that do not have a clear precedent.
lead_paragraph: From Silicon Valley to Wall Street to Washington, the blockbuster case that Elon Musk filed against OpenAI and its C.E.O., Sam Altman, has become Topic A. It is the business world’s hottest soap opera.

headline: A.I. Is Making the Sexual Exploitation of Girls Even Worse
abstract: Parents, schools and our laws need to catch up to technology, fast.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Kat Tenbarge and Liz Kreutz of NBC News reported that several middle schoolers in Beverly Hills, Calif., were caught making and distributing fake naked photos of their peers: “School officials at Beverly Vista Middle School were made aware of the ‘A.I.-generated nude photos’ of students last week, the district superintendent said in a letter to parents. The superintendent told NBC News the photos included students’ faces superimposed onto nude bodies.”

headline: An Analog Library of All the Lives I’ve Lived
abstract: What is lost when journaling moves into the cloud?
lead_paragraph: After a routine iPhone update, a new Journal app recently appeared. Intrigued, I tapped it, which led to the instruction “Enable journaling suggestions.” If I agreed, my phone promised to give prompts like “Take a moment to write about something special in your life you’ve been taking for granted” and “Take a look around you and take a picture of something you’ve overlooked. What do you notice about it?”

headline: Two Lives Intertwined, on Both Sides of the Camera
abstract: In “Double Click,” the writer Carol Kino explores the pioneering glamour of a famous fashion-photography pair.
lead_paragraph: I’m going to toss out some names: Diane Arbus, Richard Avedon, Erwin Blumenfeld, Louise Dahl-Wolfe, Lee Miller, Irving Penn, Man Ray, Edward Steichen, Franny McLaughlin, Fuffy McLaughlin. If you recognize everyone but Franny and Fuffy, you know something about photography. And if, by chance, you recognize them all, then you’re probably Carol Kino, the author of “Double Click,” a book ostensibly about Franny and Fuffy.

headline: A Fresh Look at a Sensational 1843 Murder Case and Its Fallout
abstract: In “The Witch of New York,” Alex Hortis revisits a Staten Island case that helped usher in a lurid new era of journalism.
lead_paragraph: The story began with a fire: On Christmas night in 1843, a Staten Island teenager spotted smoke coming from the white house owned by Capt. George Houseman. After he raised the alarm, men drinking at the local tavern came running to help put out the blaze. The captain was away at sea, but the men made a grim discovery in the burned-out kitchen: the bodies of Emeline Houseman, 24, and her toddler daughter, Ann Eliza.

lead_paragraph: The United States made its first airdrops of humanitarian aid into Gaza on Saturday, as the Biden administration tried to prevent a greater humanitarian disaster in the Palestinian territory.

headline: Freight Cars Derail on Lehigh River in Pennsylvania After 3-Train Crash
abstract: Photos on social media showed two locomotives and several container cars derailed. No one was injured and no hazardous materials leaked, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Several freight train cars derailed onto the banks of the Lehigh River, a tributary of the Delaware River, in Pennsylvania on Saturday in a crash involving three trains that spilled diesel fuel and plastic pellets into the water, the authorities said.

headline: King Harald V of Norway Receives Temporary Pacemaker in Malaysia
abstract: Implanted after the monarch, 87, contracted an infection, the device is intended to aid in transporting him back to Norway, his royal house said.
lead_paragraph: King Harald V of Norway received a temporary pacemaker in Malaysia on Saturday to help him return home, according to the Norwegian Royal House, after contracting an infection while on the trip.

headline: Lives Ended in Gaza
abstract: Since the war started, more than 30,000 people have been killed during Israel’s bombardment and invasion. Here are some of their stories.
lead_paragraph: Since the war started, more than 30,000 people have been killed during Israel’s bombardment and invasion. Here are some of their stories.

headline: A Citrusy Salmon Recipe With the Salad Built Right In
abstract: Just add rice or potatoes (and maybe a chilled white wine).
lead_paragraph: Citrus and salmon is a winning combination, previously proven in New York Times Cooking’s recipes for broiled salmon with mustard and lemon, roasted salmon with ginger-lime butter and citrusy roasted salmon and potatoes. Our newest addition to this esteemed company is Farideh Sadeghin’s recipe for orange-glazed baked salmon. It’s a no-fuss fish dinner with a clever, timesaving twist: Farideh builds a side salad into the recipe by tossing salad greens with some of the reserved honeyed orange juice that is used to flavor the salmon. If you’re looking at the above image and thinking, “I bet blood oranges would be especially beautiful and excellent in this recipe,” know that Coco, a reader, already tried that and can confirm that the results were “absolutely delicious.”

headline: Iris Apfel, a Full Life in Full Looks
abstract: The New York society figure, former interior designer and self-proclaimed “geriatric starlet” made dressing a delight.
lead_paragraph: Iris Apfel, the O.G. geriatric fashion inspiration and influencer who died on Friday at age 102, was not an advocate of minimalism. She did not have much truck with stealth wealth or quiet luxury or the old axiom that elegance is refusal. She was not terribly interested in the tyranny of good taste. Where’s the fun in that?

headline: The Face of The Times, and the Man Who Commissioned It
abstract: Tom Bodkin ordered up NYTCheltenham to replace a mélange of typefaces and sharpen the design of the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: The answer was right there on Tom Bodkin’s bookshelf.

headline: Trump’s Support Among Latinos Grows, New Poll Shows
abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll found President Biden losing support among Latino voters, who now account for nearly 15 percent of eligible voters, a record high.
lead_paragraph: President Biden continues to lose crucial support among Latino voters, with an increasing number of those voters saying they are more likely to vote for former President Donald J. Trump, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: ‘Pretty Sickening’: Texas Ranchers Face Crippling Losses
abstract: Fires burning across the plains of Texas, Kansas and Nebraska have hit ranchers hard. Dry, windy weather threatens to make the fires worse.
lead_paragraph: Justin Homen kept driving across his vast Texas ranch, but he only found the same bleak scenes: blackened grassland, charred cow carcasses and smoldering debris turned almost entirely to ash.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of residents were left without power, and life came to a standstill for many in the Sierra Nevada region on Saturday after a winter storm dumped as much as two feet of snow overnight and created treacherous conditions.

headline: For Democrats Pining for an Alternative, Biden Team Has a Message: Get Over It
abstract: A new poll shows that nearly two in five Democrats say that the president should not be their nominee. But no one who matters to the president seems willing to suggest he step aside.
lead_paragraph: When it comes down to it, a lot of Democrats wish President Biden were not running this fall. Only 28 percent of Democrats in a new survey by The New York Times and Siena College expressed enthusiasm about his candidacy and 38 percent said flatly that Mr. Biden should not be their nominee.

headline: Migration From South America Through the Perilous Darién Gap Resumes
abstract: On Friday, boat companies began operating in Colombia after a five-day pause, allowing migrants to once again make their way through the notorious jungle terrain and continue toward the U.S. border.
lead_paragraph: Migration toward the United States through the perilous jungle known as the Darién Gap returned to normal on Friday, with hundreds of people from Venezuela, Ecuador and beyond entering the jungle following a roughly five-day pause in which migrants could not begin the trek.

headline: University of Florida Eliminates All D.E.I.-Related Positions
abstract: The move complies with a state law that barred public universities from using government funds for initiatives that promote diversity, equity and inclusion.
lead_paragraph: The University of Florida has terminated all positions associated with diversity, equity and inclusion at the school in compliance with new state regulations, according to a university memo released on Friday.

headline: Trump Dominates Michigan G.O.P. Convention Amid Party Turmoil
abstract: The former president won all 39 delegates against Nikki Haley during the caucus-style event in Grand Rapids.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump capped off a clean sweep of Republican delegates in Michigan on Saturday during a raucous convention, which further exposed a deep fissure in the state party that threatens to fester in one of the most important battleground states.

lead_paragraph: For nearly an hour, the driver of a tractor-trailer was trapped in its cab as it dangled high above the Ohio River off the side of a Kentucky bridge after a multivehicle crash on Friday.

abstract: After a national incident was declared in January, officials have been scrambling to address problematically low levels of immunization.
lead_paragraph: The 5-year-old looked nervously at her older brothers, scanning their faces for any sign of distress as needles were swiftly stuck into their upper arms, the syringe plungers pushed in and the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine administered. Whether it was for her benefit or not, they barely flinched.

headline: Lack of Plan for Governing Gaza Formed Backdrop to Deadly Convoy Chaos
abstract: Israel has no clear plan for governing Gaza. That is a particular problem in the north, where the fighting has ebbed, and where a deadly stampede occurred on Thursday around an aid convoy.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s reluctance to fill the current leadership vacuum in northern Gaza formed the backdrop to the chaos that led to the deaths on Thursday of dozens of Palestinians on the Gazan coast, analysts and aid workers have said.

lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the artist James Turrell, using information provided by a representative for the project, mis­stated the city where Turrell is based. It is Flagstaff, Ariz., not Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Is Already Looking Toward the Election
abstract: In its opening sketch, “S.N.L.” offered a parody of a CNN political show.
lead_paragraph: A new poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College indicated that voters have a wide range of concerns about President Biden in the months before the 2024 presidential election. But “Saturday Night Live” gave some of Biden’s advocates — or, at least, the cast members impersonating them — the opportunity to dispel these anxieties and argue that he isn’t too old to continue in the job.

abstract: Skyscrapers in the heart of Los Angeles were a financial failure that many people had ignored — until graffiti artists tagged their windows.
lead_paragraph: It was a billion-dollar aspiration meant to transform a neighborhood.

headline: Aging Bridge Is a Flashpoint in Competitive Washington State House Race
abstract: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez is running on fixing one of the busiest bridges in the region. Her far-right opponent calls it an “Antifa superhighway.”
lead_paragraph: The first thing Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez told donors gathered at a recent wine-and-cheese campaign fund-raiser was of the role she played in securing $600 million in federal funding to rebuild one of the region’s main arteries, the aging Route I-5 bridge.

headline: Sunken Ship Carried Fertilizer That Threatens Red Sea, U.S. Says
abstract: The U.S. Central Command said the 21,000 metric tons of ammonium phosphate sulfate fertilizer presented “an environmental risk,” while the vessel posed an “impact risk.”
lead_paragraph: A British-owned cargo ship sank in the Red Sea about two weeks after being damaged in a missile attack by the Iran-backed Houthi militia, and the fertilizer it was carrying now posed an environmental risk, the United States military said late Saturday.

headline: An Amnesiac Pieces Together a Life From Strangers’ Stories
abstract: “Your Absence Is Darkness,” a novel by the Icelandic writer Jon Kalman Stefansson, is a complex history prompted by one man’s quest.
lead_paragraph: Jon Kalman Stefansson’s 2007 novel “Heaven and Hell,” the first of an extraordinary trilogy, begins with a sea voyage worthy of Melville. A crew of cod fishermen is caught in a storm off a remote coast of Iceland. The land vanishes, snow swirls over the water. As the waves bear down on the soaked rowers, they must stop continually to punch off the ice that forms on their clothes. It’s a fitting image of both the sea’s terrifying indifference and a desperate, seemingly futile violence from within.

headline: France’s Biggest Literary Sensation Tells His Story — Again
abstract: “Change,” Édouard Louis’s latest work of autofiction, retraces his trajectory from abject poverty to life as a cultured Parisian.
lead_paragraph: Édouard Louis (né Eddy Bellegueule) burst onto the French literary scene in 2014 at the age of 21 with “The End of Eddy,” an autobiographical novel that announced, with aplomb, his own abnegation. The immolation is even more direct in the original French — “En Finir Avec Eddy Bellegueule,” something like “finishing off Eddy,” as others rendered it.

headline: It Just Got Easier to Visit a Vanishing Glacier. Is That a Good Thing?
abstract: “Last-chance tourists” are visiting the melting Mer de Glace in Chamonix, France, in droves. A just-opened lift should make that easier. But some worry tourism is only making the problem worse.
lead_paragraph: Claude Folmer was about 40 years old the first time he visited the Mer de Glace, the largest glacier in the French Alps. He remembers enjoying the panoramic view from the observation platform, then taking a short hike down to the ice, where he toured the ice cave that’s carved into the glacier’s surface.

headline: A New Keith Haring Biography Draws the Most Complete Picture Yet
abstract: In his thoroughly researched “Radiant,” Brad Gooch considers the short, blazing life of the ’80s artist, activist and man about downtown.
lead_paragraph: Modern art can baffle and intimidate. Keith Haring strove to democratize it.

headline: How a ‘Body Farm’ Might Help Tackle Fentanyl Abuse
abstract: The U.S. government brought Mexican coroners to America to learn how to detect fatal overdoses, hoping to show that fentanyl kills in Mexico, too.
lead_paragraph: The two women lifted a stiff corpse from the ground, revealing a squirming bug in the dirt.

headline: Time to Pluck Around
abstract: Almost 30 years ago, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy inspired my barely there eyebrows. I didn’t think I would be tweezing them back into existence.
lead_paragraph: In late January, when a friend emailed to alert me that her favorite brow person was doing a residency uptown not far from where I lived. I laughed. “I have no brows,” I responded. “I belong to the great Carolyn Bessette disappearing eyebrow generation!”

headline: Why Are Pants So Big (Again)?
abstract: And what the latest swing from skinny to wide tells us about ourselves.
lead_paragraph: At some point in the past few years, as if we didn’t have enough to worry about, everyone’s pants started to look wrong. For an improbably long time, the “right” pants — meaning those that conveyed some socially agreed-upon, base-line level of stylishness — had been, in a word, small. Snug through the thighs, throttled at the knees, close-cut at the calves, on intimate terms with the ankles. Running a minuscule gamut from skinny to the slightly-more-accommodating slim. There were exceptions, particularly when it came to women’s pants. But on balance, fitted was the way good pants were supposed to fit.

headline: In ‘Oppenheimer’ and ‘The Zone of Interest,’ We Hear What We Are
abstract: Does morality have a sound? Both films use sonics and silence in contrast with images. The complex results raise questions about what makes us human.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.

headline: ‘Spaceman’ Has an Identity Crisis. So Do Plenty of Sci-Fi Space Movies.
abstract: With the release of Adam Sandler’s odd, middling and expensive new Netflix film, a look at space movie misfires of the past and how history repeats itself.
lead_paragraph: Not long into “Spaceman,” Adam Sandler’s new somber sci-fi space movie on Netflix, it becomes quite clear that it’s struggling to channel something greater, something better, something already respected.

headline: Trump’s Allies Ramp Up Campaign Targeting Voter Rolls
abstract: Calling themselves investigators, activists are using new data tools and disputed legal theories to urge officials to drop voters from the rolls.
lead_paragraph: A network of right-wing activists and allies of Donald J. Trump is quietly challenging thousands of voter registrations in critical presidential battleground states, an all-but-unnoticed effort that could have an impact in a close or contentious election.

headline: The ‘Dune’ Popcorn Bucket and the Golden Age of Movie Merch
abstract: The hilariously suggestive misfire is a reminder of the days when too-weird-to-be-true film mementos could be found in every kitchen cupboard.
lead_paragraph: When I first encountered an image of the popcorn bucket that AMC Theaters is selling to promote Denis Villeneuve’s “Dune: Part Two,” I stared at it for a beat trying to process what I was looking at. The item is supposed to represent a giant sandworm, the beasts that slither under the desert planet Arrakis. On top of the normal container sits a lid that depicts the cylindrical body of the creature emerging from the ground. The opening where you are ostensibly supposed to reach in to snatch some kernels is fashioned like the worm’s maw with its many tendril-like teeth, here rendered in plastic. The bucket is intricately designed, but appears, well, especially anatomical — to put it politely — and somewhat difficult to use to actually get treats into your mouth.

headline: In Texas, a ‘Once-in-a-Generation’ Brawl for Control of the G.O.P.
abstract: Attorney General Ken Paxton is out for revenge. Gov. Greg Abbott wants private school vouchers. Both want to bring down incumbent Republicans in Tuesday’s primary and shift the state further to the right.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Trump and Haley after Super Tuesday.

headline: The Clippers Are Short on Championships, but Long on Logos
abstract: A rebranding effort is underway, yet again, for an N.B.A. franchise that has always struggled to find an identity.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Clippers have struggled for years to shed their reputation as one of the N.B.A.’s most woebegone franchises. Operating in a perennial shadow cast by the Lakers, the Clippers actually have a decent team this season, with hopes of winning their first championship.

headline: Who Will Win Control of the House in 2024? California May Hold the Key.
abstract: While the state is solidly in the Democrats’ column for the presidential election, the winners in key districts could determine who runs Congress.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats look to wrest control of the U.S. House of Representatives in November, their fight will fully begin with Tuesday’s primaries in California.

headline: Why ‘Fetal Personhood’ Is Roiling the Right
abstract: An Alabama decision on I.V.F. has put an uncompromising principle on a collision course with political reality.
lead_paragraph: In vitro fertilization creates life, in the most literal sense. The procedure offers a chance to make a baby, with eggs that are fertilized and develop into embryos in a lab. I.V.F. has helped countless people have children, including couples struggling with infertility and an increasing number of L.G.B.T.Q. parents. In a sense, it’s the opposite of an abortion, which ends a pregnancy.

headline: The I.R.S.’s Taxpayer Experience Officer Says Open Your Mail Already
abstract: Ken Corbin is fixing the phone lines — but those foreboding letters are staying the same.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is on a charm offensive, as long as you don’t earn too much money.

headline: Majority of Biden’s 2020 Voters Now Say He’s Too Old to Be Effective
abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll revealed how much even his supporters worry about his age, intensifying what has become a grave threat to his re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Trump and Haley after Super Tuesday.

headline: Kremlin Seeks to Suppress Navalny’s Influence, in Death as in Life
abstract: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
lead_paragraph: When Aleksei A. Navalny was alive, the Kremlin sought to portray him as an inconsequential figure unworthy of attention, even as the Russian authorities vilified and attacked him with a viciousness that suggested the opposite.

headline: The Verdict on the New Alexander McQueen
abstract: A confusing debut, but Rick Owens and Yohji Yamamoto prove that originality is the best revenge.
lead_paragraph: That the death of Iris Apfel, the geriatric influencer whose idiosyncratic sense of personal style made her a fashion star when she was well into her 80s, happened smack in the middle of Paris Fashion Week was both startling and oddly fitting. All the appreciations of her life and outfits have been adding up to pointed reminders of how this whole circus relates to the art of dressing, and the way clothing can be an interface with the world in the most expressive, original way.

headline: How to Grow Old Like Isabella Rossellini
abstract: “How do I fulfill the rest of my life? That question came to me very clearly at 45, and I didn’t have an answer.”
lead_paragraph: If you go to Isabella Rossellini’s Instagram page — and I recommend you do — you will see the 71-year-old actress/director/model/farmer wearing a giant woolly hat and vest, beaming with joy in the sunshine at her farm on Long Island. Another photo shows her staring off into the distance, her face proudly unretouched. Scrolling through, I often wonder how Rossellini is so comfortable in her own skin at an age when many women struggle in theirs.

headline: As Pakistan Installs a Prime Minister, the Road Ahead Looks Rocky
abstract: Parliament’s election of Shehbaz Sharif for a second term follows a month of political turmoil. The new government faces economic troubles and questions of legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s newly elected Parliament approved Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister on Sunday, ushering in his second term in that role and capping weeks of upheaval — as well as setting into motion a government facing economic and political challenges that are likely to leave the country in turmoil for years to come.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘How Tom Sandoval Became the Most Hated Man in America’
abstract: He turned last year’s season of “Vanderpump Rules” into the best in reality TV’s history — and ruined his life in the process.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a quiet, leafy street in the Valley in Los Angeles, the reality TV star Tom Sandoval has outfitted his home with landscaping lights that rotate in a spectrum of colors, mimicking the dance floor of a nightclub. The property is both his private residence and an occasional TV set for the Bravo reality show “Vanderpump Rules.” After a series of events that came to be known as “Scandoval,” paparazzi had been camped outside, but by the new year it was just one or two guys, and now they have mostly gone, too.

headline: German Police Conduct Raid in Hunt for Red Army Fugitives
abstract: Ten people were arrested and later released. The action in Berlin came after one of three wanted members of the militant group was arrested last week.
lead_paragraph: The German police conducted a raid in Berlin on Sunday in their longtime search for three fugitives connected to the Red Army Faction, originally known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, Germany’s most infamous postwar terrorist group.

headline: Climate Change and ‘Last-Chance Tourism’
abstract: Travelers are racing to see parts of the world that may soon vanish.
lead_paragraph: A lot of climate discussion revolves around time. Lines rise across charts predicting the next century. Scientists set deadlines for the coming decades. Each month seems to bring news of a new heat record. The sense that time is running out can be heady.

headline: Russian Strike’s Toll Rises to 12 as Zelensky Blames Air Defense Delay
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not refer to the United States, but his words appeared to reflect frustration over a stalled American aid package.
lead_paragraph: Rescue workers in the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa pulled the bodies of a mother and baby from the rubble of an apartment building on Sunday, as the death toll in a Russian attack two days earlier rose to 12. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said delays by allies in supplying air defenses had contributed to the deaths.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 4, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Israel Opts Out of Cease-Fire Talks as Hamas Delegation Arrives in Cairo
abstract: Israeli officials did not attend after Hamas was said to have refused a request from Israel to provide a list of the hostages who were still alive.
lead_paragraph: A Hamas delegation arrived in Cairo on Sunday for talks aimed at achieving a cease-fire in the war in Gaza and an exchange of hostages held by militants there for Palestinian prisoners, according to an official in the group, Basem Naim. But a breakthrough in the negotiations did not appear to be imminent, as Israel decided not to attend.

headline: Easing the Daily Reality of My Strangeness
abstract: D.E.I. efforts have their flaws, but for Black faculty members and students on campus, they can ease a sense of not belonging.
lead_paragraph: Like many African American professors, I teach at a predominantly white institution (Wheaton College) and live in the largely white small city where it’s located, outside Chicago. I have not experienced serious acts of discrimination, but that doesn’t make life simple.

headline: How Democrats Can Win Anywhere and Everywhere
abstract: Enterprising Democratic governors have had success where it’s by no means guaranteed. This is how they did it.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania got an emergency call about I-95 last June, his first thought turned to semantics. “When you say ‘collapse,’ do you really mean collapse?” he recalled wondering. Highways don’t typically do that, but then tractor-trailers don’t typically flip over and catch fire, which had happened on an elevated section of the road in Philadelphia.

headline: Living Slow Deaths Behind Bars
abstract: Parole reform has been languishing in the New York State Legislature.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have found that most cells in our bodies regenerate every seven to 10 years, on average. This includes certain cells in the heart and brain. Can we assume, then, that our moral and emotional compasses are also capable of transforming over time?

headline: Why Elon Musk Is the Second Most Important Person in MAGA
abstract: With readership collapsing for right-wing outlets, X is all the movement has left.
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable developments of the new century has been the concentration of right-wing power and adulation in two men. Donald Trump is the obvious one, the unquestioned king of the American right. But easier to miss if you’re outside the MAGA world is the central importance of Elon Musk.

headline: U.N. Experts Say Gaza Is Close to Famine. What Does That Mean?
abstract: Several criteria, including acute malnutrition in at least 30 percent of children, go into determining that a famine exists. It is not clear who has the authority to officially declare a famine in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The aid delivery that ended in bloodshed this week showed the extent of Gazans’ desperation, with dozens killed after many thousands converged on a rare convoy of aid trucks. As the number of aid deliveries into Gaza has rapidly dropped and Palestinians struggle to find food, humanitarians and United Nations officials are warning that famine is imminent in the enclave.

headline: What’s Hidden in Woodlawn’s Mausoleums? Extraordinary Stained Glass.
abstract: Many artworks commissioned by the rich and powerful for their final resting places have rarely been seen by the living for the last century.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Bronx morning late last year, an all-star team of stained-glass experts prepared to enter a dank 1894 tomb at Woodlawn Cemetery that had been opened just once in the past century.

headline: Nikki Haley Ducks and Weaves on Trump Endorsement, I.V.F. and Jan. 6
abstract: In a Sunday interview, Ms. Haley suggested she might no longer feel bound to support the eventual Republican nominee and also said that she supported I.V.F. but that states should be able to ban it.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley suggested Sunday that she no longer felt bound by a pledge to support the eventual Republican nominee, but did not rule out endorsing former President Donald J. Trump, even as she said she didn’t know whether he would follow the Constitution as president.

headline: Go Big With Bibimbap
abstract: It’s a showstopping kaleidoscope of bulgogi, shiitakes, bean sprouts, spinach, carrots and cucumbers, all drizzled with a spicy gochujang sauce.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. On Sunday, I like a project in the kitchen more than on any other day. It’s a chance to work at the stove without the need to get something on the table in 45 minutes, a time to stretch my skill set. Mostly, it’s an opportunity to explore recipes rather than simply following them. On Sundays I don’t want to fly by wire. I want to fly.

headline: Imagining a Brokered Democratic Convention if Biden Drops Out
abstract: Readers react to political commentary by Jamelle Bouie and Ezra Klein. Also: Human skills in an A.I. world; not all fun and games in Florida.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Aid Agency Researchers Allege Abuse of Gazans in Israeli Detention
abstract: UNRWA, the aid agency for Palestinians, is preparing to publish an investigation based on testimony from more than 100 detainees that accuses Israeli troops of abuse.
lead_paragraph: An unpublished investigation by the main United Nations agency for Palestinian affairs accuses Israel of abusing hundreds of Gazans captured during the war with Hamas, according to a copy of the report reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Inmates Escape After Attacks on Two Prisons in Haiti’s Capital
abstract: The assault on prisons is the latest in a wave of violent episodes in the past few days staged by gangs who have vowed to oust the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Gangs attacked two prisons in Haiti, including the country’s largest penitentiary, and allowed prisoners to escape on Saturday night, according to Haitian officials, the latest instance of escalating violence and disorder in the country’s capital, which has been ravaged by gang violence for more than two years.

headline: Washington D.C. Republican Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live election results from the 2024 Washington, D.C. Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results from the 2024 Washington, D.C. Republican primary.

headline: Jazz Concerts Celebrate Met Opera Composers on an Intimate Scale
abstract: Terence Blanchard and Anthony Davis, recent pioneers at the Metropolitan Opera, returned to earlier works in a pair of performances over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: In the musical “Jelly’s Last Jam,” which just had an acclaimed revival in the New York City Center Encores! series, Jelly Roll Morton, a pianist and composer who claims he invented jazz, pays for his hubris. But while the show occasionally excoriates him, its fictionalized tale revels in his real-world achievements.

headline: Supreme Court Poised to Rule on Monday on Trump’s Eligibility to Hold Office
abstract: An unusual announcement from the court provided a strong hint that the justices will act the day before the primaries on Super Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced on Sunday that it would issue at least one decision on Monday, a strong signal that it would rule then on former President Donald J. Trump’s eligibility for Colorado’s primary ballot.

headline: Republicans Nod to Trump’s Influence in Race to Succeed McConnell
abstract: Donald Trump is looming over the upcoming leadership battle to replace Mitch McConnell as senators weigh each contender’s independence with their alignment to the former president and the party’s base.
lead_paragraph: With nine months before Senate Republicans select their new leader to succeed Senator Mitch McConnell, some are acknowledging the shadow of one figure outside Congress who looms over the race: former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Ohio Fines CVS $1.5 Million Over Safety and Staffing Issues
abstract: The penalty is part of a settlement of 27 cases involving safety concerns revealed during inspections of nearly two dozen stores, officials said.
lead_paragraph: CVS Health, the nation’s largest pharmacy chain with more than 9,000 locations, has been fined more than $1.5 million by Ohio regulators over problems connected to understaffing and patient safety, officials said.

headline: OPEC to Extend Oil Production Cuts Through June
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s announcement appears to be aimed at bolstering oil prices as growth in demand remains modest.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said Sunday that it would extend cuts in oil production through June, noting that it was acting “in coordination with some” other states. Saudi allies including Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates said Sunday that they would also continue their reductions.

headline: ‘Dune: Part Two’ Draws Large Audiences
abstract: The science-fiction sequel sold an estimated $81.5 million in tickets in the United States and Canada, the biggest opening for a Hollywood film since “Barbie.”
lead_paragraph: “Dune: Part Two” and its A-list cast jump-started moviegoing in North America after a dismal start to the year.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Sets Back Law Meant to Fight Money Laundering
abstract: An Alabama judge barred the government from collecting certain company ownership data to help the Treasury Department identify money launderers, and called the effort a case of congressional overreach.
lead_paragraph: In a blow to government efforts to combat money laundering, a federal court has ruled that the Treasury Department cannot require some small businesses to report personal details about their owners.

headline: Monday Briefing: Fears of Anarchy Grow in Gaza
abstract: Also, Pakistan’s newly elected prime minister and a bard of China’s rust belt
lead_paragraph: Last week, more than 100 people were killed in northern Gaza, health officials there said, after thousands of Gazans rushed at aid trucks. The crush on Thursday led to a stampede and prompted Israeli soldiers to fire at the crowd.

headline: Texas Judge Temporarily Blocks Paxton’s Demand for Transgender Minors’ Records
abstract: An L.G.B.T.Q. organization had sued after the state’s attorney general asked for documents on children receiving gender-affirming care.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Friday temporarily blocked the Texas attorney general from forcing an L.G.B.T.Q. organization to turn over documents on transgender minors and the gender-affirming care they may be receiving.

headline: Kate Winslet Pushes Her Characters, and Herself, to the Edge
abstract: As a young star, she endured Hollywood’s brutal treatment of women. Now she’s putting her resilience and grit on full display.
lead_paragraph: Kate Winslet was standing in front of a microphone, breathing hard. Sometimes she did it fast; sometimes she slowed it down. Sometimes the breathing sounded anxious; other times, it was clearly the gasping of someone who was winded. Before beginning a new take, Winslet stood stock still, hands opening and closing at her sides; she looked like a gymnast about to bound into a floor routine. Every breath seemed high-stakes, even though she was well into a long day of recording in a dim, windowless studio in London.

headline: Tiny Drink
abstract: Samantha Podos Nowak makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Harris Calls for an ‘Immediate Cease-Fire’ in Gaza
abstract: The vice president urged Hamas to agree to a six-week cease-fire proposal and called on Israel to increase the flow of aid into the enclave.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday called for an “immediate cease-fire” in Gaza, saying that Hamas should agree to the six-week pause currently on the table and that Israel should increase the flow of aid into the besieged enclave amid a humanitarian crisis.

headline: Deaths of Gazan Children Likely to ‘Rapidly’ Rise Amid Aid Snarls, U.N. Warns
abstract: Delivering supplies into Gaza, especially the north, has taken on increased urgency as the United Nations has warned that many Gazans are on the edge of famine.
lead_paragraph: Days after an aid delivery in Gaza turned into a deadly disaster, Israel pushed ahead with another convoy bound for northern Gaza on Sunday, a Palestinian businessman involved in the initiative said, as the United Nations warned that deaths of children and infants are likely to “rapidly increase” if food and medical supplies are not delivered immediately.

headline: Activist Investor’s Group Raises Bid for Macy’s
abstract: The new offer values the department store chain at $6.6 billion. Macy’s, which just announced a strategy to turn around its business, said it would “carefully review” the proposal.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor group that is seeking to buy Macy’s increased the pressure on the department store chain on Sunday, raising its offer and disclosing additional details about its financing plans.

headline: Will Shortz, New York Times Crossword Editor, Says He Is Recovering From a Stroke
abstract: Mr. Shortz, who has been with The Times for three decades and also hosts NPR’s “Sunday Puzzle,” said on Sunday that he had a stroke in February but was recovering.
lead_paragraph: Will Shortz, crossword editor of The New York Times and the host of NPR’s “Sunday Puzzle,” is recovering from a stroke, he said on Sunday.

headline: Mark Dodson, Voice of ‘Star Wars’ and ‘Gremlins’ Characters, Dies at 64
abstract: He voiced Salacious B. Crumb, the monkey-lizard pet of Jabba the Hutt in “Return of the Jedi,” as well as Mogwai in both “Gremlins” films.
lead_paragraph: Mark Dodson, who voiced strange puppet creatures in “Star Wars,” including Salacious B. Crumb, the cackling monkey-lizard pet of Jabba the Hutt, and “Gremlins” films, died on Saturday. He was 64.

headline: Tracking an Invisible Climate Menace From 360 Miles Above
abstract: A new satellite will detect emissions of methane, an invisible yet potent gas that is dangerously heating the planet.
lead_paragraph: A new satellite will detect emissions of methane, an invisible yet potent gas that is dangerously heating the planet.

headline: Kamala Harris Calls for ‘Immediate Cease-Fire’ in Gaza
abstract: During a speech in Selma, Ala., the vice president called on Hamas to agree to a six-week pause that is on the table and for immediate aid to those living in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: During a speech in Selma, Ala., the vice president called on Hamas to agree to a six-week pause that is on the table and for immediate aid to those living in Gaza.

headline: How Regulations Fractured Apple’s App Store
abstract: As the App Store approaches its 16th anniversary, patchwork rules have turned what was a single store into different shops across many countries.
lead_paragraph: Since introducing the App Store in 2008, Apple has run it largely the same way across 175 countries, right down to the 30 percent commission it has collected on every app sold.

headline: Forced to Change: Tech Giants Bow to Global Onslaught of Rules
abstract: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and others operated unfettered. But new laws and regulations have finally compelled them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
lead_paragraph: By Thursday, Google will have changed how it displays certain search results. Microsoft will no longer have Windows customers use its Bing internet search tool by default. And Apple will give iPhone and iPad users access to rival app stores and payment systems for the first time.

headline: Gaza War Is Shifting Ties Between Secular and Ultra-Orthodox Israelis
abstract: Israel’s Haredi minority has long lived apart from the nation’s mainstream, but fighting has both widened that divide and in some ways helped to bridge it.
lead_paragraph: In a neighborhood of Jerusalem, ultra-Orthodox Jewish residents cheered a soldier returning from military service. At a religious seminary, similarly devout students gathered to hear an officer talk about his military duties. And at a synagogue attended by some of the most observant Jews in the country, members devoted a Torah scroll in memory of a soldier slain in Gaza.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The U.N. warns that more children will die in Gaza without aid.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. warned that deaths of children and infants in Gaza were likely to “rapidly increase” if food and medical supplies were not sent immediately, days after an aid delivery into the enclave turned into a disaster.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: the Oscars and the State of the Union
abstract: ABC airs the awards show for all things film. President Biden addresses the nation across the major networks.
lead_paragraph: For TV viewers like me who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network shows, movies and specials broadcasting Monday through Sunday, March 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Italy’s Oscar Nominee Is a Great Film, but It Doesn’t Tell the Whole Story
abstract: “Io Capitano” ends where many would have wanted it to continue.
lead_paragraph: Of all the offerings this Oscar season, one stands out: “Io Capitano.” A nominee for best international feature film, it is a visually stunning and often harrowing account of the journey from West Africa to Europe. Based on many real-life stories, it shows the horrors of the perilous route across the Sahara and the Mediterranean Sea that more than one million people have taken over the past decade, along which thousands have died.

headline: No Corrections: March 4, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Inside Britain’s Struggle to Scale Up Nuclear Power
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The U.K. and the U.S. have, in a sense, forgotten how to build nuclear power stations.”

lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
