headline: Barbara Lee Is a Progressive Hero. Why Is She Trailing in the Polls in California?
abstract: Her vote against authorizing the war in Afghanistan was an act of true courage.
lead_paragraph: “The perspective, the lens, the representation, the experience of a Black woman from California is badly needed.”

headline: Iditarod Racer Kills Moose to Protect Himself and Dogs, Officials Say
abstract: Dallas Seavey, a five-time Iditarod winner, had to gut the moose during the sled dog race to comply with the competition’s rules.
lead_paragraph: The Iditarod sled dog race in Alaska has had a messy start, with a five-time champion shooting and killing a moose to protect himself and his dogs, race officials said on Monday.

headline: Victoria Nuland, Veteran Russia Hawk, to Leave the State Department
abstract: A hard-charging diplomat and determined advocate of supporting Ukraine will step down from the department’s No. 4 post.
lead_paragraph: Victoria J. Nuland, the fourth-ranking official at the State Department and a determined advocate of tough policies toward Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia, will retire this month after more than 30 years of government service.

headline: In Trump Cases, Supreme Court Cannot Avoid Politics
abstract: The justices’ efforts to remain unified in cases affecting the election are fraying as the former president wins one case and is granted a delay in another.
lead_paragraph: In major cases concerning former President Donald J. Trump, the Supreme Court has tried to put some distance between itself and politics. That fragile project does not seem to be succeeding.

headline: Humanitarian Aid Boxes Dropped Over Northern Gaza
abstract: Palestinians in Gaza City scrambled for boxes of supplies airdropped by the United States, Jordan, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians in Gaza City scrambled for boxes of supplies airdropped by the United States, Jordan, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Antoine Predock, Architect Who Channeled the Southwest, Dies at 87
abstract: His striking, acclaimed structures evoked the desert. But for major projects elsewhere in the world, he adopted the same principle: connecting buildings to their settings.
lead_paragraph: Antoine Predock, an Albuquerque-based architect who became known for buildings that resonated with the landscape of the American Southwest, earning him international acclaim and prestigious commissions as far away as Canada, Costa Rica and Qatar, died on Saturday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 87.

headline: Why It Takes Longer for California to Count Ballots
abstract: A heavy reliance on mail-in ballots, and an extensive review process, can lead to a waiting game for results.
lead_paragraph: By Tuesday night in California, the ballots will be cast, but the results for many races may remain uncertain for days, even weeks.

headline: 10 Great Oscar Winners for Best Original Song
abstract: Hear tracks by Billie Eilish, Keith Carradine, Isaac Hayes and more.
lead_paragraph: Happy Oscar week! The 96th Academy Awards are this Sunday, and you know which competition we’re most excited about here at The Amplifier: best original song. Today’s playlist is a brief but star-studded tour through the category’s history.

headline: Whatever We Call This Age, Humans Are Changing the Planet. Here’s How.
abstract: Many of our imprints on nature will be preserved in the rocks, scientists say, even if this time isn’t yet recognized as a new geologic epoch.
lead_paragraph: Coming after nearly 15 years of deliberation, a ruling by geologists on Tuesday feels almost anticlimactic: Our species has not so radically altered our world as to have started a new chapter in its history, at least not yet, a scholarly panel decided.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Richard Haass
abstract: The March 1, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Richard Haass. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Why Is This $2.99 Tote Bag Causing Chaos?
abstract: It’s tiny. It’s cheap. Trader Joe’s stores can’t seem to keep them on shelves.
lead_paragraph: Thaddeus Yan went to Trader Joe’s more than a dozen times last week, but he wasn’t there for groceries. Mr. Yan, a 23-year-old lifestyle content creator in Los Angeles, was searching for a tote bag.

headline: Rabbi Ellen Bernstein, Who Saw Ecology as God’s Work, Dies at 70
abstract: She linked her passion for the natural environment to the precepts of the Hebrew Bible, beginning with the Garden of Eden.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Bernstein, a river guide turned rabbi who blazed a spiritual trail in the environmental movement by undergirding it with the Hebrew Bible’s veneration of nature, died on Feb. 27 in Philadelphia. She was 70.

headline: Kyrsten Sinema Bows Out of Arizona Senate Race
abstract: The independent incumbent’s decision cleared the field for a two-person race, most likely between Representative Ruben Gallego, a Democrat, and Kari Lake, a Republican.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, the Democrat turned independent who cut bipartisan deals that cemented parts of President Biden’s agenda but also stymied some of her former party’s highest priorities, said on Tuesday that she would not seek re-election.

headline: Is Crypto Back? What to Know About Bitcoin’s Surge.
abstract: Bitcoin just hit a record high, but there are big differences between now and the last crypto boom, when digital currencies became a cultural phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Cryptocurrency enthusiasts celebrated on Tuesday, as the price of Bitcoin reached a record high of more than $69,000. For believers, it was a moment of vindication after a 2022 industry downturn that sent several major companies into bankruptcy and tainted crypto’s reputation.

headline: 1 Killed as Explosion at Michigan Vape Distributor Sends Canisters Flying
abstract: A 19-year-old man was looking at the glowing orange sky when he was struck by a butane canister from a quarter-mile away, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A teenager in Michigan was struck and killed by a flying butane canister from an explosive fire at a vaping distributor’s warehouse about a quarter mile away on Monday night, the authorities said.

headline: A Music Festival Headlined by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
abstract: The New York Democrat had top billing at a recent concert event in Florida that took a partisan approach to politics as entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Two acts received top billing at MadSoul, a music and arts festival in Florida, on Saturday. The first was Muna, an indie-pop group that opened for Taylor Swift at some Eras Tour stops. The second: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York.

headline: Janice Burgess, 72, Dies; Nickelodeon Executive and ‘Backyardigans’ Creator
abstract: She oversaw production of “Blue’s Clues” and drew on her childhood for the popular show in which five cartoon animals imagine their yard as a place of otherworldly adventure.
lead_paragraph: Janice Burgess, a longtime executive of the Nickelodeon channel who sought to promote children’s curiosity and sense of play for decades, overseeing popular television shows like “Blue’s Clues” and “Little Bill” and creating her own musical children’s show, “The Backyardigans,” died on Saturday in hospice care in Manhattan. She was 72.

headline: New Federal Rule Caps Most Credit Card Late Fees at $8
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said its new restriction would save households $10 billion a year in “junk fees.”
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans could soon see lower credit card bills after a federal rule that caps late fees at $8 a month was finalized on Tuesday by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which estimates that the change will save households $10 billion a year.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Why Did I Choose Her?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In 1997 I wanted a new tax guy. I was referred to Mike. He had a great smile, and I immediately crushed hard. Each year I’d offer up a new persona to get his attention: The damsel in financial distress. The rising PR exec who catered on the side and could cook. Nothing worked; Mike was all business. Fast forward to 2005. At his suggestion, we meet for a drink. Four drinks in, I say, “Can I tell you a secret? I’ve had a crush on you since Day 1.” We just celebrated our 15-year wedding anniversary. — Debra Jack

headline: ‘A Revolution on Canvas’ Review: The Personal, the Political and the Painting
abstract: A documentary about lost artwork intimately involves one of its directors.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “A Revolution on Canvas,” one of the documentary’s directors, Sara Nodjoumi, receives a warning from a friend. She and her father, the painter Nikzad Nodjoumi (commonly known as Nicky) have been trying to discover if his paintings — left behind at the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art when he fled Iran in 1980 — are still in the basement archives of the museum. By video chat, a friend counsels caution. “It’s just a film,” he says. “You don’t want to risk your life.”

headline: Damage to Cables Under Red Sea Highlights Mideast Conflict’s Broader Threat
abstract: What disabled three major cables linking East to West is still not clear. Suspicion has centered on Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who have attacked numerous ships in the area, but they have denied responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Mysterious damage to vital communications cables under the Red Sea has raised concerns about whether the conflict in the Middle East is now beginning to threaten the global internet.

headline: The Rich Spend Differently From You and Me
abstract: Your inflation rate may not be mine. Does it matter?
lead_paragraph: In my most recent column I had a bit of fun with Donald Trump making an assertion that shows that he hasn’t flown commercial in a very long time — saying that America’s terrible airports make us look like a third world nation:

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Americans Vote on Super Tuesday
abstract: Also, China’s ambitious growth goal and this year’s winner of the Pritzker Prize.
lead_paragraph: Millions of voters across 15 states are casting ballots on Super Tuesday, one of the most important dates on the U.S. political calendar.

headline: A Grainy Photo and a Dilemma: How U.K. Papers Are Covering Princess Catherine
abstract: In a country where the health struggles of even public figures are generally viewed as out of bounds, journalists are trying to balance the right to privacy with a thirst for royal stories.
lead_paragraph: After a week of often hysterical speculation about her well-being, there were suddenly two plausible pieces of evidence that Catherine, Princess of Wales, was on the mend: a photo of her in a car driven by her mother and a confirmation by the British Army that she would attend a military ceremony in June.

headline: Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Is ‘In the Hands of Hamas,’ Biden Says
abstract: President Biden said the Israelis had been cooperating in negotiations over a possible six-week cease-fire in Gaza, being mediated by Qatar and Egypt, and that “a rational offer” was made.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said the Israelis had been cooperating in negotiations over a possible six-week cease-fire in Gaza, being mediated by Qatar and Egypt, and that “a rational offer” was made.

headline: ‘We need a cease-fire,’ Biden says.
abstract: President Biden said Tuesday that talks on a possible six-week cease-fire in Gaza are “in the hands of Hamas right now.” He spoke just before a Hamas leader in Lebanon appeared to reject a proposed deal the United States is backing, insisting that Israeli hostages would be released only after a cease-fire was in place and Israeli forces have withdrawn.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said Tuesday that talks on a possible six-week cease-fire in Gaza are “in the hands of Hamas right now.” He spoke just before a Hamas leader in Lebanon appeared to reject a proposed deal the United States is backing, insisting that Israeli hostages would be released only after a cease-fire was in place and Israeli forces have withdrawn.

headline: Robert Menendez and Wife Are Charged With Obstruction of Justice
abstract: The New Jersey senator and his wife, Nadine Menendez, who already faced bribery charges, were charged in an 18-count superseding indictment.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez and his wife, Nadine Menendez, were charged with obstruction of justice in a new federal indictment on Tuesday, adding to the wide-ranging bribery and corruption charges they already face.

headline: How a Climate Rule Got Watered Down
abstract: The S.E.C. was the target of intense corporate lobbying and a backlash from Republicans.
lead_paragraph: What should companies have to tell their investors about climate change risks?

headline: Shafiqah Hudson, Who Fought Trolls on Social Media, Dies at 46
abstract: When the hashtag #EndFathersDay began trending on Twitter, she realized it was more than a joke: It was a coordinated disinformation effort.
lead_paragraph: Shafiqah Hudson was looking for a job in early June of 2014, toggling between Twitter and email, when she noticed an odd hashtag that was surging on the social media platform: #EndFathersDay.

headline: Amid Age Concerns, the White House Tries a New Strategy: Let Joe Be Joe
abstract: President Biden tries to take on worries about a tough race by turning to TikTok influencers, a late-night talk show and more give-and-take with reporters.
lead_paragraph: He is wearing aviators and baseball caps. He is making visits to ice cream parlors and barbecue joints, and asking to meet with influencers who can disseminate images of him on TikTok and Instagram. He is talking more often to reporters and fielding questions on the Middle East, Republicans and, of course, his age.

headline: Learning to Love Fitness, Despite Dreading Gym Class
abstract: Memories of the Presidential Physical Fitness Test, the grade-school assessment, inspired one reporter to reflect on her movement journey.
lead_paragraph: When I think about running a timed mile in elementary school gym class, I can still feel the stinging in my lungs and the full-body sensation of strain.

headline: Brown University Will Reinstate Standardized Tests for Admission
abstract: The school joins Yale, Dartmouth and M.I.T. in backtracking on “test optional” policies adopted during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Brown University will reinstate standardized testing requirements for admission, joining Yale, Dartmouth and M.I.T. in backtracking on “test optional” policies adopted during the Covid pandemic.

headline: Cyberattack Paralyzes the Largest U.S. Health Care Payment System
abstract: The hacking shut down the nation’s biggest health care payment system, causing financial chaos that affected a broad spectrum ranging from large hospitals to single-doctor practices.
lead_paragraph: An urgent care chain in Ohio may be forced to stop paying rent and other bills to cover salaries. In Florida, a cancer center is racing to find money for chemotherapy drugs to avoid delaying critical treatments for its patients. And in Pennsylvania, a primary care doctor is slashing expenses and pooling all of her cash — including her personal bank stash — in the hopes of staying afloat for the next two months.

headline: Starbucks Franchise Lays Off Workers in Mideast Amid Gaza-Tied Boycotts
abstract: Store traffic has dropped off in the Middle East and Southeast Asia as customers protest perceptions of Starbucks’ stance on the Israel-Hamas conflict.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks franchise operators across the Middle East and Southeast Asia are losing significant business amid boycotts linked to the Israel-Hamas war, and at least one has started laying off employees.

headline: U.S. Warns Spring Breakers Headed to Mexico, Jamaica or the Bahamas
abstract: In recent weeks, American travelers to some of the busiest international destinations during spring vacation have been urged by the State Department to exercise extra caution.
lead_paragraph: Don’t wander off the resort after dark. Keep the flashy clothing and jewelry to a minimum. Stay aware of your surroundings. Those are some of the travel rules that Ginger Moore, a retired logistics analyst from Panama City, Fla., adheres to on her solo trips throughout the Caribbean.

headline: Why Trump and Biden Can’t Clinch Nominations on Super Tuesday
abstract: Mathematically, Super Tuesday won’t secure either candidate a majority of his party’s delegates.
lead_paragraph: Super Tuesday will not make President Biden or former President Donald J. Trump a presumptive party nominee, as defined by locking up a majority of the delegates available nationwide.

headline: ‘Scary and Daunting’: Dartmouth Players Detail How Union Plan Came Together
abstract: On Tuesday, the historic 13-2 vote by the men’s basketball team to unionize took a significant step toward classifying student-athletes as employees.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Dartmouth College men’s basketball team congregated at the stately Hanover Inn near campus on a dreary, drizzly Tuesday and walked over to a small office building where they smiled for a group photo. Then they went up to a second-floor conference room and took a vote that had been six months — or rather, many years — in the making.

headline: House Races to Watch in California
abstract: Several races in the state could prove crucial to House control next year, including one that might be decided on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: California’s battleground races for the House of Representatives are pivotal again this election year, and Tuesday’s primaries could provide more clues about which party will win control of Congress in November.

headline: It’s the Biggest Day of This Year’s Primary Elections
abstract: Also, China set an ambitious goal for economic growth. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans in 15 states and one territory went to the polls today for primary contests that will set the stage for November’s elections. We call it Super Tuesday because it’s the busiest voting day before November, and typically it plays a central role in the presidential nomination process.

headline: Estella Bergere Leopold Dies at 97; Found Climate Clues in Ancient Pollen
abstract: The last child of the pioneering ecologist Aldo Leopold, she also helped preserve her father’s legacy as a founder of the modern environmental movement.
lead_paragraph: Estella Bergere Leopold, a botanist who examined ancient pollen to illuminate the effects of climate change — and who, as the last child of the pioneering environmentalist Aldo Leopold, helped preserve her father’s legacy as a founder of the modern conservation movement — died on Feb. 25 at a retirement home in Seattle. She was 97.

headline: When Will We Get Results on Super Tuesday?
abstract: A lot of polls will close around 8 p.m. Eastern time, but delegate-rich California, which is famously slow to count ballots, will be one of the last states to wrap up.
lead_paragraph: The states voting today span the nation, and millions of Americans will visit polls from when the sun rises off the Maine coast to when it sets in Alaska. Because of different time zones, some results might start coming in early, while others won’t come until late — maybe very late.

headline: Panama Bars Ex-Leader Martinelli From Presidential Election
abstract: The electoral tribunal disqualified Ricardo Martinelli, saying he was ineligible to run because of his conviction for money laundering and sentencing to more than five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Panama’s electoral tribunal disqualified former President Ricardo Martinelli from running in the May presidential election in light of a 10-year sentence he received for money laundering.

headline: Does Eating Yogurt Reduce Your Diabetes Risk?
abstract: The F.D.A. will now allow yogurt makers to claim it can — but the evidence is mixed.
lead_paragraph: Nonfat or full-fat, flavored or plain, probiotic or natural — yogurt is already peppered with labels. But you may soon see a new claim on your container: This month, the Food and Drug Administration announced it will allow yogurt makers to say their products may prevent Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Biden Dominates on Super Tuesday as He Turns Toward Trump
abstract: The president, facing only token opposition, won easily in state after state as he begins to focus fully to the general election.
lead_paragraph: President Biden won Democratic nominating contests in 15 states on Tuesday, all but closing the book on this year’s primary campaign as he shifts fully toward the general election.

headline: How the ‘Uncommitted’ Effort to Protest Biden Has Spread in Super Tuesday States
abstract: The campaigns have been fragmented, organized with far less time and resources than Michigan’s operation.
lead_paragraph: Organizers in several Super Tuesday states are calling on voters to oppose President Biden at the ballot box over his stance on the war in Israel and Gaza, building on momentum that began last month in Michigan.

headline: Frank Popoff, Who Sought to Lead a Friendlier Dow Chemical, Dies at 88
abstract: As chief executive, he pushed a company known for Agent Orange, napalm and chlorine to undo its confrontational reputation and promote environmental sustainability.
lead_paragraph: Frank Popoff, who as chief executive and chairman tried to make Dow Chemical more conciliatory toward regulators and environmentalists in the late 1980s and ’90s, and who prodded the chemical industry to adopt safer practices, died on Feb. 25 at his home in Midland, Mich., where Dow is based. He was 88.

headline: 6 Charged With Smuggling Goose and Duck Intestines From China
abstract: Six New York City residents were arrested on Tuesday and charged with importing the sought-after delicacies in violation of federal rules.
lead_paragraph: Some were in crates marked as “pet nail clippers.” Others were hidden under packaged rattlesnakes, a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn said.

headline: Patti Smith Sings for a ‘New York Gem’
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum drew devotees out for a party celebrating its centennial, including Peter Marino, Vito Schnabel and Walton Ford.
lead_paragraph: Over a century ago, J.P. Morgan built a majestic library for his opulent mansion in Midtown Manhattan. After his death, his son, the financier Jack Morgan, opened it to the public in 1924, and it eventually became the Morgan Library & Museum. Last night, crowds of art patrons and well-heeled bibliophiles gathered in that grand library to attend the Morgan’s centennial celebration.

headline: Read the Latest Menendez Indictment
abstract: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his wife, Nadine Menendez, with obstruction of justice, adding to the bribery and corruption charges they already face.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his wife, Nadine Menendez, with obstruction of justice, adding to the bribery and corruption charges they already face.

headline: Tumbleweeds Roll Through Parts of Utah and Nevada
abstract: Neighborhoods and roads were overrun by tumbleweeds after strong winds blew across the western United States.
lead_paragraph: Neighborhoods and roads were overrun by tumbleweeds after strong winds blew across the western United States.

headline: It’s Been All Tumbleweeds, All the Time, in Utah and Beyond
abstract: Over the weekend the spiny orbs buried cars and piled up against the sides of houses as an unusual storm swept the region with dust and snow. And tumbleweeds. They’re still digging out.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning, residents of South Jordan, Utah, about 20 miles south of Salt Lake City, woke up to an astonishing sight. Thousands of tumbleweeds had blown into town and piled up against people’s homes overnight.

headline: Liberty University Fined $14 Million for Mishandling Sex Assaults and Other Crimes
abstract: The penalty is the largest ever imposed by the Education Department, which found that the school had punished sexual assault victims but not their assailants and created a “culture of silence.”
lead_paragraph: Liberty University, the evangelical Christian university in Lynchburg, Va., agreed to pay a record $14 million fine for breaking federal campus safety laws, the Education Department announced on Tuesday, accusing the school of creating a “culture of silence” that discouraged the reporting of crimes and repeatedly mishandling sexual assaults.

headline: In California, Senate Battle Has the Most Intrigue
abstract: An intraparty fight for the late Senator Dianne Feinstein’s seat has been complicated by the entrance of the former baseball star Steve Garvey.
lead_paragraph: California is a big part of Super Tuesday, but don’t expect a big turnout in the state.

headline: Minnesota Democratic Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Minnesota Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Minnesota Democratic primary.

headline: Inside America’s Shadow War With Iran
abstract: There’s another Middle East conflict going on, and U.S. soldiers are on the front lines of it.
lead_paragraph: It’s often been said that the most dangerous hot spot in the world is the waterway between Taiwan and mainland China, where the Chinese Navy and Air Force flex their muscles every day to try to intimidate Taiwan — while the U.S. Navy patrols nearby. I wonder. There is actually a stable balance of deterrence there right now. You could hold a friendly regatta in the Taiwan Straits compared to where I just visited.

headline: Israel Sees Vindication in U.N.’s Report, but Tensions Between Them Rise
abstract: A U.N. inquiry found support for Israel’s allegations of sexual violence in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, but they remain bitterly at odds over the war in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Israelis largely welcomed a U.N. report that supported allegations of sexual violence during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, even as a top Israeli official accused the United Nations of not doing enough to address the findings — a sign of the rising tensions between them.

headline: The New Rape Denialism
abstract: How quickly the far left pivots from “believe women” to “believe Hamas” when the identity of the victim changes.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, Hamas invaded Israel and filmed itself committing scores of human-rights atrocities. Some of the footage was later captured by the Israeli military and screened to hundreds of journalists, including me. The “pure, predatory sadism,” as Atlantic writer Graeme Wood described it, is bottomless.

headline: Maker of Raw Milk Cheese Pleads Guilty in Listeria Outbreak That Killed 2
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration linked cheese from the Vulto Creamery in Walton, N.Y., to an outbreak of listeria that also sickened six from 2016 to 2017.
lead_paragraph: A former raw milk cheese manufacturer and his company pleaded guilty on Tuesday in connection to an outbreak of listeria from 2016 to 2017 that killed two people and left six others hospitalized, prosecutors said.

headline: Venezuela Announces Election Date, With Opposition Candidate Still Banned
abstract: The decision to hold a vote on July 28 is a partial fulfillment of a commitment to the United States, but with the top opposition figure barred, many wondered how free and fair the balloting would be.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan officials announced on Tuesday that national elections that many had hoped would forge a path toward democracy will be held on July 28.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Faces House Subpoena Over Covid Deaths in Nursing Homes
abstract: Mr. Cuomo was accused of stonewalling a House subcommittee trying to interview him about his administration’s handling of nursing homes during the Covid pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has been subpoenaed to appear before a House subcommittee to answer for his administration’s handling of nursing homes during the coronavirus pandemic, reigniting a flashpoint that could further damage his chances at a political comeback.

headline: Ex-President of Honduras Denies at Trial That He Trafficked Drugs
abstract: Juan Orlando Hernández, who is accused of conspiring to import cocaine into the United States, also denied receiving a bribe from the Mexican drug lord El Chapo.
lead_paragraph: The former two-term president of Honduras denied in court on Tuesday that he had trafficked narcotics, offered police protection to drug cartels or taken bribes — assertions that have been at the heart of a conspiracy trial taking place in Manhattan.

headline: Donald Trump, Seeking Cash Infusion, Meets With Elon Musk
abstract: It’s not clear whether Mr. Musk will spend any of his billions on the former president’s behalf. If he does, he could erase Mr. Trump’s financial disadvantage in the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, who is urgently seeking a cash infusion to aid his presidential campaign, met on Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla., with Elon Musk, one of the world’s richest men, and a few wealthy Republican donors, according to three people briefed on the meeting who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe a private discussion.

headline: Harvard’s Response to Subpoenas Is Called ‘Useless’ by House Committee
abstract: Harvard said it has been acting in good faith and submitted thousands of pages of new material.
lead_paragraph: Representative Virginia Foxx, who is leading a House investigation of campus antisemitism, blasted Harvard University on Tuesday for handing over “useless” documents in response to subpoenas.

headline: Review: For ‘Jack Tucker,’ Failure Is the Only Option
abstract: Zach Zucker delivers a raucously funny portrait of a catastrophically dim stand-up comic at SoHo Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: In one of his most quotable lyrics, Bob Dylan sang about a woman who knows “there’s no success like failure/ And that failure’s no success at all.” She clearly never saw the comedy of Jack Tucker.

headline: Mark Robinson Wins Republican Primary for North Carolina Governor
abstract: Mr. Robinson, the state’s lieutenant governor, had never run for office until 2020. He is a political firebrand whose harsh rhetoric could work for or against him.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina defeated his two challengers in the Republican primary for the governor’s race on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. His win proved that his blustering, Trump-aligned style is favored by conservatives who are gearing up for what will probably be the most expensive and closely contested statewide race in the country.

headline: Josh Stein Wins Democratic Primary for North Carolina Governor
abstract: Mr. Stein, the state attorney general, easily defeated four primary opponents and will likely face Mark Robinson, the Republican lieutenant governor, in November.
lead_paragraph: Josh Stein, the North Carolina attorney general, handily won the state’s Democratic primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, setting the stage for a matchup with a fiery Republican rival in a race that will be tightly contested and closely watched.

headline: Philadelphia Man Is Freed After 34 Years in Prison
abstract: Police had hidden evidence showing that Ronald Johnson did not participate in the crime he was convicted of, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Johnson, who had spent more than three decades behind bars, was freed on Monday after a Philadelphia judge vacated his sentence and reversed his conviction, officials said.

headline: International Court Accuses 2 Russian Officers of War Crimes in Ukraine
abstract: Arrest warrants were issued by the International Criminal Court for two military officials, a general and an admiral, both accused of targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court on Tuesday issued arrest warrants for two top Russian military officers, accusing them of war crimes in Ukraine for targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.

headline: Something to Bat Around
abstract: Brad Wiegmann figures he can trick us. And he does.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Marilynne Robinson
abstract: The March 5, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Marilynne Robinson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Houston’s District Attorney Concedes in Democratic Primary
abstract: The incumbent, Kim Ogg, had made herself a lightning rod within her party by tacking to the center and clashing with fellow Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Sean Teare, a former prosecutor and first-time candidate who promised new approaches to handling low-level criminal cases, defeated Kim Ogg, the two-term district attorney in Harris County, Texas, in the Democratic primary on Tuesday.

headline: OpenAI Says Elon Musk Tried to Merge It With Tesla
abstract: In its first public comment since Mr. Musk sued the artificial intelligence lab, OpenAI claims he tried to commercialize its operations years ago.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI, in its first public comments about Elon Musk’s lawsuit against the influential artificial intelligence research lab, said Mr. Musk had tried to transform the lab from a nonprofit into a for-profit operation before he left the organization in early 2018.

headline: Nikki Haley Wins Vermont, Her Second Victory Against Trump
abstract: The win signals her limited strength in places with large numbers of younger people, college-educated voters and independents.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley won the Republican primary in Vermont, according to The Associated Press, notching her second victory of the 2024 campaign and her first — and perhaps only — win in a Super Tuesday state.

headline: The Super Tuesday Shocker That Wasn’t: Biden Pulls Out a Tie in American Samoa
abstract: Jason Palmer, an entrepreneur from Maryland, was denied a win over President Biden due to a rounding error. He did secure three of the territory’s six delegates.
lead_paragraph: It looked at first like an embarrassing loss for a president struggling to rally his party behind him: For three hours on Tuesday night, President Biden appeared to have lost the Democratic caucus on a faraway Pacific island, American Samoa, to a little-known opponent.

headline: Quotation of the Day: She Boxes. She Conducts. She Defies Stereotypes.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted to have a magic wand, and I wanted to do something crazy.”

headline: Corrections: March 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a U.N. investigation of sexual violence during the Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel misattributed the source of several quotes about the U.N. investigation. The quotes were taken from a U.N. statement summarizing the report, not from the report itself. The full report is linked from the article online.

headline: Schiff and Garvey Advance in the California Senate Race for Feinstein’s Seat
abstract: Representative Adam Schiff, a prominent antagonist of former President Donald J. Trump, will face Steve Garvey, a Republican former baseball star, in a November runoff.
lead_paragraph: Representative Adam Schiff, the lead prosecutor in Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment trial, and Steve Garvey, a former Major League Baseball star, advanced on Tuesday night to the California general election for a Senate seat, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Colin Allred Wins Democratic Contest to Take On Senator Ted Cruz in Texas
abstract: The Dallas-area congressman presented himself as an across-the-aisle politician who could appeal to a wide range of voters.
lead_paragraph: Representative Colin Allred, a Dallas-area Democrat who defeated an incumbent Republican in 2018 to gain his congressional seat, won the Democratic primary race for the U.S. Senate on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, emerging on top of a crowded field seeking to challenge Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: ‘Uncommitted’ Draws Strong Support Against Biden in Minnesota
abstract: The effort to pressure the president over his support for Israel garnered a sizable share of the vote, despite being more hastily organized. Voters in other states also voiced unease.
lead_paragraph: The movement objecting to President Biden’s position on Israel by voting “uncommitted” drew a significant share of the vote on Tuesday in Minnesota despite having a hastily organized and low-budget campaign.

headline: On a Bright Night for His Campaign, Trump Again Conjures a Dark Vision
abstract: As he dominated the Super Tuesday battlefield, former President Donald Trump warned of dark days ahead if President Biden were to win a second term. “We’re a third-world country,” he said repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: Despite dominating the Super Tuesday nominating contests, former President Donald J. Trump gave a victory speech short on celebration or exultation and long on sinister evocations of what he portrayed as a grim fate for the country if President Biden is re-elected.

headline: A Window Into Chinese Government Has Now Slammed Shut
abstract: Once a year, the premier held a news conference, explaining the economy and giving Chinese a taste of political participation. That has come to an end.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, the Chinese premier’s annual news conference was the only time that a top leader took questions from journalists about the state of the country. It was the only occasion for members of the public to size up for themselves China’s No. 2 official. It was the only moment when some Chinese might feel a faint sense of political participation in a country without elections.

headline: Gabriel García Márquez Wanted to Destroy His Last Novel. It’s About to Be Published.
abstract: The publication of “Until August” adds a surprising twist to his legacy, and may stir questions about posthumous releases that contradict a writer’s directives.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of his life, when his memory was in pieces, Gabriel García Márquez struggled to finish a novel about the secret sex life of a married middle-age woman. He attempted at least five versions and tinkered with the text for years, slashing sentences, scribbling in the margins, changing adjectives, dictating notes to his assistant. Eventually, he gave up, and issued a final, devastating judgment.

headline: In Showdown Over G.O.P. Control in Texas, the Race for House Speaker’s Seat Heads to a Runoff
abstract: Dade Phelan’s failure to secure his seat on Tuesday indicated that fights over the future direction of the Republican Party in Texas would continue roiling the state.
lead_paragraph: The Texas House speaker, Dade Phelan, and a local Republican activist backed by former President Donald J. Trump will compete in a runoff in May after neither received enough votes to win on Election Day, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Two Democrats emerge from a crowded field in a newly competitive House district in Alabama.
abstract: Shomari Figures, a former Justice Department official, and State Representative Anthony Daniels will head to a runoff election in the Democratic primary in the Second Congressional District.
lead_paragraph: Shomari Figures, a former Justice Department official, and State Representative Anthony Daniels will head to a runoff election in the Democratic primary for Alabama’s Second Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A big day in American politics.
lead_paragraph: Super Tuesday, during which millions of U.S. voters went to the polls for primaries in 15 states, indicated that Americans will likely face a presidential rematch between two deeply unpopular candidates in 2024: Donald Trump vs. President Biden.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Super Tuesday: Trump Wins and Haley Exits
abstract: Donald Trump racked up delegates, but also revealed weaknesses. Nikki Haley conceded to cold, hard math. And restive Democrats sent a message to President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley has dropped out of the presidential race. Follow for live updates.

headline: Who Won, Who Lost and What’s Still Undecided From Super Tuesday
abstract: The presidential candidates weren’t the only ones on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and President Biden emerged victorious from Super Tuesday, the biggest day in the primary season, with only Nikki Haley’s narrow victory in Vermont helping her avoid a shutout in the 15 Republican contests. She was expected to end her campaign on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
