abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: From China to New York, by Way of the Southern Border
abstract: Thousands of Chinese migrants have made their way to Queens, Brooklyn and Chinatown after first passing through Central and South America.
lead_paragraph: When busloads of migrants from Venezuela and Latin America started turning up on New York City streets in 2022, it spurred a crisis that has overwhelmed city shelters and incited protests over immigration policies.

headline: Checking Your Watch
abstract: Are you always in a rush?
lead_paragraph: Are you always rushing and racing to and fro?

headline: Late Night Finds Super Tuesday Super Predictable
abstract: “Spoiler: It’s Biden/Trump,” Stephen Colbert said. “It’s always been Biden/Trump. It will always be Biden/Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Israel Must Let More Aid Into Gaza, U.K. Tells Israeli Official
abstract: After meeting with Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, the British foreign secretary, David Cameron, had strong words about conditions in Gaza that “must change.”
lead_paragraph: Meeting with a member of Israel’s war cabinet on Wednesday, Britain’s foreign secretary said Israel must help get far more food and other supplies into the Gaza Strip to address the humanitarian crisis there, the secretary said after they spoke.

headline: No One Has Ever Read Genesis Like This
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Marilynne Robinson delivers a riveting interpretation of the Bible’s first book.
lead_paragraph: Marilynne Robinson’s “Reading Genesis” is a writer’s book, not a scholar’s; it has no footnotes. Its power lies in the particular reading it gives us of one of the world’s foundational texts, which is also one of the foundations of the Pulitzer Prize-winning author’s mind and faith. We want to know what Robinson thinks of Genesis for the same reason we’d want to know what Tolstoy thought of it.

headline: You Don’t Need a Greenhouse to Grow Citrus Indoors
abstract: ‘Lemons and limes are really great houseplants,’ said the owner of a rare-plants nursery in Connecticut — if you choose the right ones.
lead_paragraph: Shattering the glass ceiling isn’t always a goal — not if you’re a certain beloved lemon tree growing in a Victorian-era greenhouse.

headline: $1,780 to Spend the Night in a ‘Cocoon’? Hotels Are Betting on Sleep Tourism.
abstract: A.I.-assisted beds, on-call hypnotherapists and sequestered guest rooms, including one inside a stainless steel sculpture, are taking sleep tourism to the next level.
lead_paragraph: To sleep, perchance to dream. Or if not dream, at least to feel vaguely rested the next day, especially on vacation. Is that too much to ask?

headline: This Los Angeles House Really Raises the Bar
abstract: A hillside home of Spanish architects has a skin made of colorful tubes.
lead_paragraph: Lucía Cano and José Selgas are architects who have no fear of color. Founders of the studio SelgasCano in Madrid, they designed a conference center in Cartagena, Spain, that looks like a translucent organ glowing orange from within as if it were coursing with alien blood. Their Serpentine Pavilion — one of the famed temporary experimental structures displayed in London each summer — was a sprawling, tentacled cocoon with misty rainbow bands.

headline: 5 Exercises We Hate, and Why You Should Do Them Anyway
abstract: Loathe burpees? Fear planks? Trainers share tips to make dreaded moves work for you.
lead_paragraph: Some exercise moves are easy, others are tough but manageable. But there are always a few that we truly abhor. Some are so reviled that they have their own merch with phrases like “Burpees Hate You Too.” If you’re not the “no pain, no gain” type, is it OK to just skip the burpee, or any of your other least favorite moves?

headline: Trump’s Conquest of the Republican Party Matters to Every American
abstract: Donald Trump has used the presidential primaries to purge his party of dissent. Republicans have lost the capacity to serve as a check on his power.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: For Casting Directors, the Hunt for a Killer Never Stops
abstract: Procedural dramas are often relaxing to watch, but the hectic sprint to find and cast new patients, clients and crooks each week is anything but.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday afternoon in February, Findley Davidson and Jonathan Tolins met for a video call. Tolins, the showrunner for the new CBS procedural “Elsbeth,” and Davidson, the show’s casting director, were finalizing casting for the sixth episode, which visits the offices of an exclusive plastic surgeon, and discussing the seventh, which attends a country club wedding.

headline: Not Your Grandpa’s Military Surplus
abstract: The young men of Americana Pipedream use social media to hype their wares, finding customers who may have never set foot in an Army Navy store.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly afternoon in February, Logan McGrath and Mack Fritz were preparing to shoot a video advertising the green Austrian army fatigue shirts they were selling on Americana Pipedream Apparel, the online military surplus store Mr. McGrath started out of his parents’ basement in Appleton, Wis., three years ago.

headline: Why Don’t More American Maestros Lead American Orchestras?
abstract: Leonard Bernstein blazed a trail for conductors from the United States nearly 70 years ago. But at top American orchestras these days, they’re scarce.
lead_paragraph: When Leonard Bernstein was named music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1958, his appointment was hailed as a breakthrough for orchestra conductors from the United States.

headline: The Best Dessert Mom Made for Us, but Better
abstract: Our house had the best treats in the neighborhood. This one we never shared.
lead_paragraph: In my mother’s kitchen, in the cabinet above the stove, lives a rectangle baking pan. It is chestnut brown, true to the 1970s, the decade she bought it as a young wife and new mother. It has knife scrapes along the bottom, spatula scratches along the sides, a few dents here and there from being packed and shipped and unpacked in countless kitchens, from the southern tip of Georgia to the middle of Bavaria. It is a talisman of my youth, a rare constant from the life of a wayward military brat.

headline: The Very Busy Writer Telling Everyone to Slow Down
abstract: In his eighth book, the best-selling author Cal Newport offers life hacks for producing high-quality work while working less.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through his new book, “Slow Productivity: The Lost Art of Accomplishment Without Burnout,” Cal Newport presents the example of Galileo, whose summertime visits to a villa near Padua gave him a chance to rest and reflect between scientific pursuits. “Once there,” Newport writes, “he would take long walks in the hills and enjoy sleeping in a room ingeniously air-conditioned by a series of ducts that carried in cool air from a nearby cave system.”

headline: A Growth Spurt in Green Architecture
abstract: Buildings made shaggy with vegetation or fragrant with wood are no longer novelties.
lead_paragraph: In the lineup of climate villains, architecture towers above many. The building and construction industries account for some 37 percent of worldwide carbon dioxide emissions, according to the United Nations Environment Program. Three of the most commonly used building materials — concrete, steel and aluminum — generate nearly a quarter of all carbon output.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Don Cherry
abstract: Listen to favorite songs by an adventurous musician who pushed the boundaries of jazz, selected by writers and musicians including Nailah Hunter, Kieran Hebden and the artist’s son Eagle-Eye Cherry.
lead_paragraph: Of all the musicians we’ve featured in this series, Don Cherry might be the most adventurous. From his early days in the late 1950s playing with the saxophonist Ornette Coleman to his tinkering with electronic funk and R&B in the ’80s, Cherry proved himself a worthy anarchist, broadening the depth of his art through the wind of his pocket cornet, an instrument he popularized. Though with Cherry, there was a sense that he didn’t want to shift the genre as a whole. Instead, his music felt innocent and voyeuristic, like he colored outside the lines just because.

headline: 31 Things to Do for the Big Eclipse This April
abstract: On April 8, the moon will blot out the sun along a roughly 4,200-mile-long, 115-mile-wide path across North America. Where will you watch it? Here are some ideas.
lead_paragraph: Wherever you go to catch the total solar eclipse on April 8, those three or four minutes of daytime darkness — no matter how spectacular — might not be enough.

headline: We’re Not Asking the Most Important Questions About Age
abstract: A presidential contest between two older candidates is an opportunity for us to start recognizing the crucial needs of our aging population.
lead_paragraph: After President Biden delivers his third State of the Union address on Thursday, much of the analysis will focus on the apparent signs of the president’s age. How alert does he seem? How spry? Does he look up to the task of running for office, or of governing? Questions like these certainly matter, but they are not the only ones we should be asking about age and aging right now. They are not even the most important.

headline: When Caitlin Clark Comes to Town
abstract: Measures of her star power include huge jumps in attendance at road games, and the logistical planning required.
lead_paragraph: What happens when Caitlin Clark comes to town?

headline: ‘This Could Well Be Game Over’
abstract: The Supreme Court may well decide another presidential election.
lead_paragraph: While the Supreme Court ruling on Monday that states cannot bar Donald Trump from appearing on their presidential ballots garnered a lot of attention, the more politically consequential decision came on Feb. 28, when the court set a hearing on Trump’s claim of presidential immunity for the week of April 22.

headline: $950,000 Homes in Maine, Florida and Washington
abstract: A cottage in Southwest Harbor, a two-bedroom condominium in Miami Beach and a four-bedroom bungalow in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Southwest Harbor, a small town on Mount Desert Island. It is less than a five-minute drive from the popular campgrounds, hiking trails and beaches in Acadia National Park, and about the same distance from the late 19th-century Claremont Hotel and from a drugstore, a coffee shop and several seafood restaurants on Main Street.

headline: Biden Preps for the State of the Union Speech and Rowdy Republicans
abstract: The speech, which will be edited up until the president delivers it, will be watched by one of his biggest audiences before the November election.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

headline: Novelist Celeste Ng on the Big Power of Little Things
abstract: The acclaimed author delves into a Modern Love essay about parenting, poetry and persistence.
lead_paragraph: Before Celeste Ng became a best-selling author, she had a side hustle selling miniatures on eBay — dollhouse-size recreations of food were her specialty. Even after the publication of “Little Fires Everywhere,” “Everything I Never Told You,” and, most recently, “Our Missing Hearts,” Celeste still makes tiny things — now, as a hobby. She’s come to realize the parallels between making small things and writing: Both give her a chance to look closely at the world.

headline: What Is Teenage Bullying Like Today?
abstract: An Opinion columnist writes that meanness among teenagers hasn’t gone away, it’s just gotten more stealthy. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever watched an old high school movie — say, “Mean Girls,” “The Breakfast Club” or “Clueless” — and been shocked by the insults the teenagers in the film hurled at one another? Did they use names and terms that you and your friends wouldn’t dare use today?

headline: A Best-Actor Nominee Who Could Make Oscar History
abstract: Our critic on Colman Domingo in “Rustin.”
lead_paragraph: Even if you don’t know Colman Domingo’s name, you probably know his face. The actor has established himself as one of Hollywood’s most compelling character actors with standout performances in TV shows like “Euphoria” and films like “If Beale Street Could Talk” and “The Color Purple.” But now, Domingo is making the leap to leading man. He was nominated for an Oscar this year for his portrayal of the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin in “Rustin.” His best-actor nomination isn’t just a significant career milestone, it could also be a milestone for Hollywood: If he wins, Domingo will be the first openly gay man to win an Oscar for playing an openly gay character. Our movie critic Alissa Wilkinson discusses Domingo’s star turn and where it fits in Hollywood history.

headline: The Answer to America’s Addiction Crisis Could Come Out of Tulsa
abstract: Nicholas Kristof on the most effective recovery program he’s ever seen.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof has spent a lot of time reporting on addiction. “My own community in Oregon has suffered a great deal from it. I’ve lost a lot of friends to it,” he says. In a recent trip to Tulsa, Okla., Kristof visited Women in Recovery, an addiction treatment program showing what’s possible. In this audio essay, he introduces us to a program graduate, Katelyn Fullbright, who struggled with cocaine and meth addiction but now holds a full-time job she enjoys.

headline: After Super Tuesday, Trump Is Stronger Than He’s Ever Been
abstract: A rule of the Trump era: The lower his profile, the higher his polls.
lead_paragraph: About 18 months ago, Donald Trump suffered one of his worst political defeats, when many of his loyalists and handpicked candidates were defeated in a midterm landscape that clearly favored the Republicans. A lot of people — I was one of them — thought that this might be the beginning of the end for him, a stark indicator of political weakness that would encourage G.O.P. voters to abandon him or set him up for a decisive general election defeat.

headline: Who Is Mark Robinson, the Republican Nominee for North Carolina Governor?
abstract: Mr. Robinson formally entered politics in 2019, when he began his run for lieutenant governor. He has appeared eager to drive divisions, disparaging L.G.B.T.Q. people and quoting Hitler on social media.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina secured the Republican nomination for governor on Tuesday, continuing his rapid political rise in a key battleground state.

headline: Texas Fires Bring Loss to a Small Town That Already Knows It Well
abstract: Fritch has endured tornadoes and wildfires over the years, and a fire now burning through the Panhandle struck dozens of homes. On Tuesday, the fire chief died fighting a house fire.
lead_paragraph: Mickey German has lived just about his entire life in Fritch, Texas, but Fritch has not always made it easy.

headline: Where Electric Vehicles Are (and Aren’t) Taking Off Across the U.S.
abstract: New data show where E.V.s are booming and reveal some surprising places where they’re getting a foothold.
lead_paragraph: New data show where E.V.s are booming and reveal some surprising places where they’re getting a foothold.

headline: The 2020 Election Is Back
abstract: Donald J. Trump begins the 2024 general election campaign in the lead.
lead_paragraph: It’s Biden vs. Trump.

headline: The Youths Have Spoken: Wallets Are Uncool. Go Digital.
abstract: A wallet-free lifestyle relying on your phone is attainable, but it requires preparation and some compromise.
lead_paragraph: To a growing number of youths, a wallet stuffed with cash and cards is as unfashionable as the millennial tuck, no-show socks and skinny jeans. Carrying only a smartphone is the way. Iykyk — that’s “if you know, you know,” for those who don’t know.

headline: Why Power Eludes the French Left
abstract: France has often been the vanguard of leftist politics — but support in the streets doesn’t always translate to votes at the ballot box.
lead_paragraph: The signs that a protest is happening in Paris are nearly always the same: the quiet of blocked-off streets; the neat rows of police vans containing the gendarmerie stretching down the boulevard; the sound of drumbeats and whistles and the neon red flares that spit smoke into the sky. For six months last year, those signs were constant and ubiquitous, as furious, sometimes violent marches and general strikes protesting President Emmanuel Macron’s pension reforms brought Paris to a standstill. Students and activists, public-transit operators, custodial staff, medics, mechanics, teachers, oil-rig workers, writers and celebrities all gathered to rail against Macron’s plan to raise the national retirement age by two years, to 64.

headline: The Privileges and Pitfalls of Making Movies About Real People
abstract: The Oscars slate this year is packed with films rooted in historical events and biographies. How much influence should the subjects have?
lead_paragraph: When Walter Naegle was first approached over a decade ago by producers who wanted to make a feature about his late partner, the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin, Naegle needed to be talked into it.

headline: The Babe Paley in ‘Feud’ Is Not the Woman I Knew
abstract: In a popular TV show, my grandmother is fictionalized as one of Truman Capote’s swans. I wish she’d had the chance to tell her story in her way.
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw Naomi Watts playing my grandmother Babe Paley in “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” she was in tears. She had just discovered her husband’s affair with Happy Rockefeller, the governor’s wife, finding him on the bedroom floor, scrubbing a stain of menstrual blood from their plush carpet. Babe summons Truman Capote to her Fifth Avenue apartment, her face set in distress, her mascara running. He tries to comfort her, handing her a Valium, reminding her that her marital arrangement is still worth it; she can buy a Matisse to soothe her broken heart.

headline: Seeing Stars, Sperm and Millions of Spawn After a Valentine’s Day Rendezvous
abstract: Sunflower sea stars, a species of giant starfish, are critically endangered. Researchers tinkered with sperm in an aquarium lab to help them reproduce.
lead_paragraph: On Valentine’s Day, Melissa Torres strung up red tinsel hearts around a shallow pool at her workplace, the Birch Aquarium at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif. She and her colleagues were arranging a romantic encounter of sorts, and the stakes were high. The happy couple, a pair of sunflower sea stars, belonged to a species that has nearly vanished because of climate change.

headline: With Sweeping New Laws, Louisiana Embraces Tough-on-Crime Approach
abstract: Gov. Jeff Landry is enacting stringent new measures that he says are crucial to address crime; critics say the laws resemble failed policies of the past.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Louisiana overhauled its criminal justice system with broad bipartisan support, all in an effort to lose the distinction of having the nation’s highest incarceration rate. Sentences were reduced. Opportunities for parole were expanded. Alternatives to prison were introduced.

headline: There Were Lynchings in the North, Too
abstract: An N.Y.U. project examines the history of lynchings after the Civil War, including one in New York State.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out about a new effort at New York University to document a troubling part of America’s past. We’ll also look at the city’s uneven rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The One Thing You Need Next Season
abstract: Louis Vuitton, Chanel and Miu Miu bring the ready-to-wear shows to an end. What’s the takeaway?
lead_paragraph: One month, four cities, hundreds of shows. After all that, Nicolas Ghesquière of Louis Vuitton brought the curtain down on the fall season with a no-holds-barred 10th anniversary show — in front of 4,000 celebrities, guests and brand employees — that not only celebrated his decade at the house but the whole absurd, delightful enterprise known as fashion.

headline: Too Little Ammunition, Too Many Russians: The Harrowing Retreat From Avdiivka
abstract: The fall of the city, when it came in mid-February, was brutal and fast. Soldiers fought for their lives. Many did not make it.
lead_paragraph: The fighting had become increasingly ferocious last month at the Zenith air-defense base a mile south of Avdiivka, where for years a company of Ukrainian soldiers had defended the southern approaches to the city.

headline: For Gazans, Truce Talks Bring Tangle of Emotions
abstract: “It’s a form of psychological torture,” said one man in Rafah. “It’s unbearable. We’re told one day that the war is ending and then the opposite the next day.”
lead_paragraph: When President Biden suggested last week that a cease-fire was imminent, Khalil el-Halabi was elated.

headline: What Happened on Super Tuesday
abstract: President Biden and former President Donald Trump scored big victories across the country, but there were some signs of weakness.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and former President Donald Trump scored big victories across the country, but there were some signs of weakness.

headline: The Unhappy Voters Who Could Swing the Election
abstract: In 2020 as in 2016, a potentially decisive slice of the electorate dislikes both main candidates. That could make for a volatile race.
lead_paragraph: Millions of voters in states across the country cast their ballots in the presidential primary on Super Tuesday, leaving little doubt that the November election will be a rematch between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Haley Expected to Drop Out, and Bitcoin Completes Comeback
abstract: Plus, bad blood in Southeast Asia over Taylor Swift’s tour.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Election is Set
abstract: The primaries are effectively over —  and the general election begins.
lead_paragraph: It’s Biden vs. Trump. It’ll be a few weeks before they have enough delegates to clinch their nominations, but after yesterday’s Super Tuesday results — in which those candidates won at least 14 states each — the primaries are effectively over. The general election is about to begin.

headline: Israel Rejects Far-Right Plan for New Limits on Access to Important Mosque
abstract: As the Muslim holy month of Ramadan approaches, the move may reduce tensions at the Aqsa Mosque compound, which has long been a flashpoint for unrest.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli government has decided against putting new restrictions on access to an important mosque in Jerusalem during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, a move that may reduce tensions at a site that has long been a flashpoint for unrest.

headline: Rain Douses New York and Southern New England
abstract: As a storm drenched the coastal Northeast, officials warned of heavy rain on Wednesday night and Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 million people were under a flood watch from Wednesday evening as a large coastal storm threatened New York City, Boston and other parts of the coastal Northeast, forecasters said, and commuters were cautioned to expect travel disruptions.

headline: How to Fix the Crisis of Trust in Higher Education
abstract: Start listening to students about what makes college relevant.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginning of the year, I’ve been keeping track of every report I see about major budget shortfalls at universities. The general trend seems to be that the schools facing these shortfalls have declining enrollments, and state and federal funding is not meeting the financial gaps left by fewer students. Every week it seems there’s fresh bad news. Here’s a sampling:

headline: Inflation Fears Stalk Presidential Politics and the Markets
abstract: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are set to grill Jay Powell, the Fed chair, about interest rates and the economy, topics that are top of mind for voters and investors alike.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Donald Trump dominated Super Tuesday, setting the stage for a rematch of the 2020 election. One topic that’s high on the agenda for voters: Inflation.

headline: With Haley Out of the Race, What Will Her Voters Do in November?
abstract: Nikki Haley’s supporters tend to be moderate and college educated, the type of voters who have helped decide recent presidential races. The New York Times spoke with nearly 40 in February to see where they were leaning.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans are dreading a Trump-Biden rematch, but no one feels the anguish quite like a Nikki Haley voter.

headline: Fed Chair Powell Still Expects to Cut Rates This Year, but Not Yet
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, told lawmakers that rate cuts in 2024 were still likely and that hot-button bank rules could be reissued.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said on Wednesday that he thought the central bank would begin to lower borrowing costs in 2024 but that policymakers still needed to gain “greater confidence” that inflation was conquered before making a move.

headline: Why Won’t Our Daughter Introduce Us to Her New Boyfriend?
abstract: Parents who enjoy an otherwise close relationship with their 33-year-old daughter feel hurt not to have been introduced to a man she met three months ago and with whom she now lives.
lead_paragraph: Our only child is 33 and unmarried. We have a good relationship with her. She lives 30 minutes away from us, and we see her frequently. She met a man three months ago, and he has now moved in with her. The problem: We would love to meet him and become part of their lives together, but she says she is not ready to introduce us yet. We have tried to set up various opportunities to meet him, but she refuses. She says it’s not him, it’s her. She wants the encounter to be “perfect” and is anxious that it won’t be. I feel hurt! We try to avoid talking about him, but he soon becomes the elephant in the room. She says she’s an adult, and it’s her decision. Should we respect her privacy? She seems happy.

headline: California’s Primary Results: What We Know So Far
abstract: Representative Adam Schiff and the former M.L.B. player Steve Garvey will face off in November for a U.S. Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: A number of races from Tuesday’s primary election in California remain too close to call, but the most-watched contest is a done deal.

headline: Atom Bombs in Space Are Back to Scare Us Again
abstract: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin may find that a nuclear weapon in orbit is less useful for war than intimidation.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, President Ronald Reagan was considering what became known as “Star Wars,” a plan to shield America from Soviet missiles by deploying up to thousands of weapons in space. At the same time, as a young science writer, I was reporting on how the rays from a single nuclear detonation in orbit could wipe out whole fleets of battle stations and laser death rays. “Star Wars: Pentagon Lunacy,” read one of the headlines.

headline: U.K. to Cut Taxes Again as Election Nears
abstract: The Conservative government, trailing badly in the polls, proposed the second tax cut in four months.
lead_paragraph: Amid lackluster prospects for economic growth, the British government announced it would cut taxes for workers ahead of a general election this year.

headline: S.E.C. Approves New Climate Rules Far Weaker Than Originally Proposed
abstract: The rules, designed to inform investors of business risks from climate change, were rolled back amid opposition from the G.O.P., fossil fuel producers, farmers and others.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules on Wednesday detailing if and how public companies should disclose climate risks and how much greenhouse gas emissions they produce, but there are fewer demands on businesses than the original proposal made about two years ago.

headline: Denzel Washington and Jake Gyllenhaal to Lead Broadway ‘Othello’
abstract: Kenny Leon will direct a starry revival of Shakespeare’s tragedy in the spring of 2025.
lead_paragraph: Denzel Washington and Jake Gyllenhaal will star in a Broadway production of “Othello” next year, setting up what is sure to be one of the hottest tickets of the 2024-2025 theater season.

headline: Scientists Create Elephant Stem Cells in the Lab
abstract: The results could shed light on why the animals rarely get cancer. But the researchers’ ultimate goal of bringing back woolly mammoths is still aspirational.
lead_paragraph: When the biotechnology firm Colossal started in 2021, it set an eyebrow-raising goal: to genetically engineer elephants with hair and other traits found on extinct woolly mammoths.

headline: With Haley’s Departure, the Rematch Between Biden and Trump Is Now Set
abstract: The contest that many Americans had long hoped to avoid — the 2024 sequel of Biden vs. Trump — is an inescapable reality.
lead_paragraph: The exit by Nikki Haley from the Republican primary after a string of resounding losses on Super Tuesday assured former President Donald J. Trump of his party’s nomination, kicking off a general election contest with President Biden that both sides expect will be bitter, brutal and long.

headline: Ukraine’s First Lady Declines Invitation to State of the Union Address
abstract: Olena Zelenska’s office cited a scheduling conflict. The Russian opposition figure Yulia Navalnaya also declined an invitation.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

headline: ‘Bérénice’ Review: Crushed by Isabelle Huppert’s Star Power
abstract: Romeo Castellucci’s production of the classic play by Jean Racine is all about the lead performer — and that’s it.
lead_paragraph: The Isabelle Huppert vehicle is a curious subgenre of French theater. At this point, its ingredients have grown predictable: They include a high-profile male director, like Robert Wilson or Ivo van Hove; a prestigious playhouse; and a central role that casts Huppert as a woman teetering on the edge of reason.

headline: National Guard and State Police Will Patrol the Subways and Check Bags
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul, amid a series of violent crimes on the subway, said she would deploy 1,000 members of the State Police and National Guard to the transit system.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of National Guard soldiers and State Police officers will patrol the New York City subway platforms and check riders’ bags beginning this week, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Wednesday.

headline: There Was Always Crying in Sports. The Kelces Made It Cool.
abstract: A tear-filled retirement announcement was just the latest instance of Jason and Travis Kelce, two of the toughest guys around, putting their emotions on full display.
lead_paragraph: As Jason Kelce strode to a dais on Monday to announce his retirement from the N.F.L. after 13 seasons with the Philadelphia Eagles, he appeared to be playing the role of traditional masculinity to perfection.

headline: MH370 Disappeared a Decade Ago. Here’s What We Know Today.
abstract: The disappearance of the Malaysia Airlines flight has remained one of the greatest aviation mysteries of all time. A new search may begin soon.
lead_paragraph: On March 8, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was heading from Kuala Lumpur, the Malaysian capital, to Beijing, when it deviated from its scheduled path, turning west across the Malay Peninsula.

headline: Charges Dismissed in ‘Hotel California’ Theft Conspiracy Case
abstract: Don Henley, a co-founder of the Eagles, has been trying to get back draft lyrics from some of his group’s biggest hits.
lead_paragraph: The criminal trial of a prominent rare books dealer accused of conspiring to possess dozens of pages of handwritten lyrics stolen from the Eagles co-founder Don Henley collapsed abruptly on Wednesday as a judge in Manhattan dismissed the charges in the case.

headline: ‘This Is the Best Dinner I’ve Ever Made’
abstract: “This meal was simple, healthy, and so incredibly tasty. I’d eat this every night of my life,” a reader says of my sheet-pan chicken with garlic yogurt.
lead_paragraph: We’ve had a few glorious days of faux spring here in New York City, a balmy omen of sunshine to come. Only a few short weeks of winter to go!

headline: New Data Details the Risk of Sea-Level Rise for U.S. Coastal Cities
abstract: A new study of sinking and rising land along American coasts offers a more specific understanding of potential flooding in 32 coastal cities.
lead_paragraph: A new study of sea-level rise using detailed data on changes to land elevation found that current scientific models may not accurately capture vulnerabilities in 32 coastal cities in the United States.

headline: ‘As Living as Opera Can Get’: John Cage’s Anarchic Anti-Canon
abstract: In his “Europeras,” Cage dismantled centuries of tradition and expectations, for musicians and audiences alike. A rare revival is coming to Detroit.
lead_paragraph: The start was typical: Oper Frankfurt in Germany asked John Cage to write an opera.

headline: Michael Chabon Wants to Help You Win Connections
abstract: The author of “Moonglow” and “The Yiddish Policeman’s Union” has a method for solving, and he’s sharing it with other puzzle lovers on Threads.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I learned from Michael Chabon that did not have to do with writing was this: Never begin solving the daily Connections by immediately clicking on the words in the 4x4 grid, even if I think I can group some of them. That alone was a revelation, because my go-to strategy has been to stare woefully at the seemingly disparate 16 words, and then nervously start tapping away. It works, mostly, but I am always open to other, less anxiety-producing methods.

headline: Russia Strikes Odesa With Missile During Visit by Zelensky and Greek Leader
abstract: Neither man was hurt, and it was unclear whether the Russian Army was targeting them.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a missile strike on the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa on Wednesday while President Volodymyr Zelensky and Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece were visiting.

headline: My Spouse Is the Breadwinner. How Should We Divvy Assets in the Divorce?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to equitably divide marital assets after a split.
lead_paragraph: I have been married for eight years, and I’m starting the process of divorce. In the beginning of the marriage, we contributed equally to the household expenses. Over the last few years, I have cut back my hours and have taken lower-paying, more meaningful work. In the meantime, my spouse has had increased responsibility and pay at work. She has taken on most of the household expenses. We have discussed changing our lifestyle in order to allow her to get a less-stressful, lower-paying job, but she decided not to pursue that. Additionally, she has been financially generous with my grown children from a previous marriage, helping to pay for weddings and down payments on homes.

headline: Full Transcript of Nikki Haley’s Remarks as She Dropped Out of G.O.P. Primary
abstract: Nikki Haley wished Donald J. Trump well, but she did not endorse him.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley suspended her presidential run on Wednesday morning, delivering remarks at her headquarters on Daniel Island in South Carolina. The following is a transcript of her remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: ‘Ricky Stanicky’ Review: Best Fiends Forever
abstract: In this slapdash, off-color comedy directed by Peter Farrelly, three buddies use the same imaginary friend as an excuse to get them out of binds.
lead_paragraph: “Ricky Stanicky,” a sloppy shock comedy by the director Peter Farrelly (of the Oscar-winning “Green Book”), is named for an imaginary friend conjured up by three childhood pals (Zac Efron, Jermaine Fowler and Andrew Santino). As kids, the lads made their fictional buddy take the fall for a Halloween prank gone wrong.

headline: Bracing for a Trump Rematch, Biden Confronts Four Thorny Challenges
abstract: Before his State of the Union address, the president faces several political problems that are largely out of his control and present dangers to his re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: As he prepares to deliver the State of the Union address on Thursday, President Biden faces four intractable political problems that loom as hazards to his re-election campaign.

headline: A Comforting Rice Dish That Won’t Break the Bank
abstract: Adas polo, a Persian recipe perfumed with cinnamon and layered with caramelized onions and dates, only feels expensive.
lead_paragraph: A bowl of lentils and rice is essential comfort food across so many cultures, be it South Asian khichdi, Middle Eastern mujadara or Greek fakorizo. No matter how traditional recipes differ, combining lentils and rice always results in a dish that’s thrifty, hearty and infinitely adaptable, inspiring as many appealing variations as there are inventive cooks.

headline: Russians Flock to Navalny’s Grave as They Grapple With His Legacy
abstract: The loss of the optimism in the face of oppression espoused by Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, has hit many Russians hard. Now, as one mourner said, “I don’t have any vision of the future.”
lead_paragraph: Marina, a Moscow lawyer, decided to stay home when the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was buried last Friday. She had expected a big crowd and widespread arrests at the Borisovsky Cemetery, given Russia’s current climate of repression, and thought it would be better to pay her respects another day.

headline: What It Takes to Be an Award Show Writer
abstract: Jason Zinoman, a New York Times critic who writes the On Comedy column, explains the struggles of the underappreciated award show writing staff and how its job often goes beyond writing.
lead_paragraph: Jason Zinoman, a New York Times critic who writes the On Comedy column, explains the struggles of the underappreciated award show writing staff and how its job often goes beyond writing.

headline: Off the Board Game, Onto the Digital Canvas
abstract: Are role-playing games enriching culture, or destroying it? In two shows, the artist Simon Denny spoofs the grandiose fantasy worlds of tech entrepreneurs designing virtual reality.
lead_paragraph: The capricious churn of internet-charged culture is producing more main characters, apocrypha and relics than we can handle. Remember when the Canadian musician known as Grimes — former partner of one of the world’s most powerful men, the tech entrepreneur Elon Musk — brought a sword to the 2021 Met Gala? The image of a futurist pop star lugging a medieval blade (made from a smelted AR-15, no less) down the red carpet summed up the mystifying way contemporary culture seems to run in all directions, chasing myths both new and old.

headline: N.T.S.B. Says Boeing Has Not Provided Key Information in 737 Max Inquiry
abstract: At a Senate hearing, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board complained that the plane maker had not been fully cooperative with the agency’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: Boeing has not provided crucial information sought by the National Transportation Safety Board as it investigates what caused a door panel to come off a 737 Max 9 plane during an Alaska Airlines flight in January, the safety board’s chairwoman told a Senate committee on Wednesday.

headline: Haley’s Failed Campaign Highlights G.O.P. Rifts and Trump’s Dominance
abstract: Falling well short in a spirited campaign to dethrone Mr. Trump, Ms. Haley brought to a close the latest struggle over the soul and direction of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: After absorbing bruising losses in the Super Tuesday primaries, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, announced on Wednesday that she was ending her presidential campaign.

headline: Mitch McConnell Endorses Trump, Whom He Once Denounced
abstract: The Kentucky Republican, who plans to step down as Senate minority leader at the end of the year, had blamed the former president’s lies about the 2020 election for the Jan. 6 riot.
lead_paragraph: Three years after delivering a scorching denouncement of Donald J. Trump after the Jan. 6 riot, Senator Mitch McConnell endorsed him for president on Wednesday, illustrating Mr. Trump’s power to bend the Republican Party to his will as he marches to the G.O.P. nomination.

headline: girl in red: The Popcast (Deluxe) Interview
abstract: An interview with the Norwegian singer girl in red (Marie Ulven) about her second album, “I’m Doing It Again Baby!,” opening for Taylor Swift and more.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, features an interview with the Norwegian indie-pop star girl in red (Marie Ulven) — whose second album, “I’m Doing It Again Baby!,” is out April 12 — in conversation about:

headline: Apple Blocks Epic Games From Using iPhone Tools in Escalation of Feud
abstract: The move tests the European Union’s new tech competition law, which was designed to allow competing app stores.
lead_paragraph: When the European Union passed a 2022 law to loosen Apple’s grip on the app economy, Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, began planning to launch a competing app store for developers.

headline: Steve Garvey’s Improbable Rise, Decades After His Baseball Heyday
abstract: The former Major League Baseball star running for the Senate faces long odds in Democratic-run California. He hopes to appeal to voters who are frustrated — and love a good sports analogy.
lead_paragraph: For months after Steve Garvey joined the race for the Senate seat formerly held by Dianne Feinstein, voters in California were only dimly aware he was a candidate. A Republican long shot in a deeply Democratic state, the former Major League Baseball star seemed to be courting tens of millions of Californians in stealth mode: Scant press. Vague stances. No ads to speak of.

headline: Protesters Interrupt Adam Schiff’s Victory Speech, Chanting ‘Cease-Fire Now’
abstract: The California Democrat was thrilled by Tuesday’s election results, but his celebration was tempered by protests of his support of Israel.
lead_paragraph: Representative Adam Schiff got everything he wanted on Super Tuesday: not only a first-place finish in the primary for a California Senate seat, but also his preferred general-election opponent in second place.

headline: Paper Bag Players Celebrate 65 Years of Making Magic Out of the Ordinary
abstract: The children’s theater company will bring its latest production, “It’s a Marvelous Paper Bag World!,” to stages in New York this spring.
lead_paragraph: What fun can you have with plain brown grocery sacks and empty cardboard cartons?

headline: John Kerry: ‘I Feel Deeply Frustrated’
abstract: The departing climate envoy on what the world has and hasn’t achieved.
lead_paragraph: When former Secretary of State John Kerry stepped into a newly created post as America’s top climate diplomat in 2021, the reputation of the United States abroad was, in his words, “in the crapper,” and the pathway to meeting the world’s climate goals looked, to most, very narrow.

headline: And the Oscars Carpet Color Goes … Back to Red
abstract: Following the surprise of last year’s champagne-hued rug, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences unveiled a bright red one on Wednesday at the Dolby Theater.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.

headline: Dean Phillips Halts Long-Shot Presidential Bid
abstract: Mr. Phillips, President Biden’s most significant Democratic rival, had argued that voters wanted a younger alternative to the president. But his candidacy stalled soon after he entered the race.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota suspended his long-shot campaign for the Democratic nomination on Wednesday and endorsed President Biden.

headline: Onstage in Chicago, Zach Bryan Howled, and the Crowd Found Its Voice
abstract: The singer and songwriter has become one of pop’s least expected new stars. On opening night of his arena tour, he showcased the bond with his fans that brought him there.
lead_paragraph: The first two songs Zach Bryan played at the United Center on Tuesday night were from the more muscular end of his catalog. They landed hard and quick — Bryan was singing with a rugged howl, guitars were churning, the fiddle poked through the top like a squeal. This was opening night of The Quittin Time Tour, and the first of three sold-out shows here, and he was wasting no time pumping the audience into a frenzy.

headline: Alabama’s I.V.F. Protection Law Will Reopen Clinics but Curb Patient Rights
abstract: Here’s what to know about the legislation, which the Legislature approved overwhelmingly on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Alabama legislature on Wednesday approved legislation intended to make it possible for fertility clinics in the state to reopen without the specter of crippling lawsuits.

headline: Haiti Engulfed by Crisis as Gangs Press Prime Minister to Step Down
abstract: The power struggle in Haiti is raising pressure on the United States to ease tensions while casting doubt on plans for a Kenyan-led security mission.
lead_paragraph: Haiti’s security crisis is reaching a breaking point. An alliance of armed gangs is pressing the country’s prime minister to resign, placing the United States in the middle of a power struggle gripping the country. Aiming to ease the standoff, the Biden administration is increasing pressure on Prime Minister Ariel Henry to enable a transfer of power.

headline: Reflections on a Trump-Biden Rematch
abstract: Readers react to articles about the two candidates’ dominance on Super Tuesday. Also: Older bike riders; French abortion amendment; shrinkflation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Christopher Walken’s Hidden ‘Dune’ Connection
abstract: The actor who plays the malevolent emperor in the new film actually brought an element of the saga to life once before. Remember “Weapon of Choice”?
lead_paragraph: If you turned on MTV for any length of time in 2001, you almost certainly saw Christopher Walken flying around the lobby of a Marriott in Los Angeles. Even in an era when music videos were far more hotly discussed than they are now, it was a weird sight. Walken’s trim shock of gray hair matched his gray suit, punctuated by a red tie; he looked less like the movie star he was than some guy on a long layover.

headline: Federal Judge Rules Minority Business Agency Must Serve White People as Well
abstract: The ruling, by a judge in Texas, was the latest in a string of court decisions that have eroded or struck down federal affirmative-action mandates in a variety of arenas.
lead_paragraph: The Minority Business Development Agency, a Commerce Department program created during the Nixon administration to help minority-owned businesses, discriminates against white people and must offer its services to people of all races and ethnic groups, a federal judge in Texas ruled on Wednesday.

headline: A Swimming Dinosaur? Maybe Not, Study Says
abstract: A new paper challenges the idea that the large, carnivorous Spinosaurus dived after prey rather than wading and plucking it out of the water.
lead_paragraph: Spinosaurus was one of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs, and it ate fish. That much paleontologists agree on.

headline: Review: Lucid Dreaming, Person to Person
abstract: In Ursula Eagly’s “Dream Body Body Building” at the Chocolate Factory, the dancers seem to be transmitting a dream state to the audience.
lead_paragraph: For the first stretch of “Dream Body Body Building” at the Chocolate Factory Theater, five performers in a row of folding chairs sit facing the audience, almost entirely still.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Alex Neptune’ and More
abstract: I’m the Asia business correspondent for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m the Asia business correspondent for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Please, President Biden: Don’t Blame Corporate Greed for Inflation
abstract: Instead of casting blame, Biden should tout what he’s done to ease Americans’ financial pressures.
lead_paragraph: I hope President Biden doesn’t show up for his State of the Union address on Thursday with a Snickers bar. Politico reported last month that Biden abruptly asked people at a dinner whether they had “seen that article about the Snickers bars,” an apparent reference to this guest essay in The Times about why voters are so upset about inflation.

headline: With Haley Out, Will States Still Hold Primaries?
abstract: It’s likely too late for them to do anything else.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has driven all of his major primary rivals out of the race. And yet, the voting will go on. Why?

headline: John Walker, Tech Executive Who Popularized AutoCAD, Dies at 74
abstract: He avoided the spotlight, but he helped bring to market an explosively popular computer program that revolutionized the architecture and design industries.
lead_paragraph: John Walker, a groundbreaking, if reclusive, technology entrepreneur and polymath who was a founder and chief executive of Autodesk, the company that brought the ubiquitous AutoCAD software program to the design and architecture masses, died on Feb. 2 in Neuchâtel, Switzerland. He was 74.

headline: The Trump-Biden Rematch Is Here. Americans Are Processing.
abstract: They’ve worked through denial, bargaining and grief over the 2024 matchup. Are discontented voters inching toward acceptance?
lead_paragraph: After weeks of campaign ads, political speeches and voting in more than two dozen primary contests, Americans are coming to terms with a reality that many have tried to avoid: a rematch.

headline: After 217 Covid Vaccines, Man Had No Side Effects and Robust Immunity
abstract: Media accounts of a German man’s extreme vaccination history spurred researchers to analyze his immune responses.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, German doctors stumbled across news reports of a man being investigated for receiving scores of coronavirus vaccines with no medical explanation.

headline: Hawaii Democratic Caucus Results
abstract: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii Democratic caucus.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii Democratic caucus.

headline: Biden Promised Calm After Trump Chaos, but the World Has Not Cooperated
abstract: Inflation, an explosion of migration at the border and wars in Europe and the Middle East have created a sense of instability that polls show have eroded his support.
lead_paragraph: During the 2020 campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced Donald J. Trump as “an incumbent president who sows chaos rather than providing order.” After defeating Mr. Trump, Mr. Biden told the nation in his Inaugural Address that he would reverse the “state of chaos” that he had inherited.

headline: ‘Uncommitted’ Effort to Protest Biden Will Shift Its Focus to Washington State
abstract: The campaign is urging Democrats to register their discontent with President Biden’s handling of the war in Gaza by voting “uncommitted.” Washington’s primary is on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After gaining some traction in Michigan and Minnesota, the next stop in the campaign to protest President Biden’s handling of Israel’s war in Gaza will be the Washington State primary next Tuesday.

headline: Drake Bell Will Detail Abuse He Suffered as a Child Star
abstract: The former Nickelodeon actor is set to describe sexual abuse he experienced at the hands of a former dialogue coach, according to a new docuseries. Court documents detail the back story.
lead_paragraph: Jared Drake Bell, a former star of the hit Nickelodeon series “Drake & Josh,” will speak publicly about abuse he suffered at the hands of a 41-year-old dialogue coach when he was 15, according to the network airing a new docuseries about the grimmer aspects of children’s television.

headline: Israel-Hamas Talks Over Hostage Releases and a Cease-Fire Stall
abstract: Officials say Hamas has continued to press Israel for a commitment to a permanent cease-fire after a multistage release of all hostages, but Israel has refused.
lead_paragraph: Talks between Israel and Hamas over the release of dozens of Israeli hostages held in Gaza have stalled, dimming hopes that a deal could be reached before Ramadan begins in a few days, according to several people briefed on the conversations.

headline: Republicans’ Dilemma on Mayorkas Impeachment: When to Take the Loss
abstract: House Republicans rushed to impeach the homeland security secretary but are taking their time delivering the charges to the Senate, where a trial is likely to be over before it begins — or yield a quick acquittal.
lead_paragraph: After approving impeachment articles against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, that are doomed in the Senate, House Republicans are facing a confounding question: How — and when — do you take a political loss in the least embarrassing way?

headline: Thursday Briefing: Haley Drops Out
abstract: Also, Israel-Hamas talks stall before Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley exited the race for president, effectively handing the Republican nomination to Donald Trump. She pointedly declined to endorse him — instead saying he must earn the support of her voters.

headline: Steven Mnuchin Backs New York Community Bank in $1 Billion Deal
abstract: Mr. Mnuchin, the former Treasury secretary, led investors who put together a package in an effort to rescue the struggling lender.
lead_paragraph: Former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin swooped in to rescue New York Community Bank on Wednesday, leading a group of investors who injected more than $1 billion into a lender flailing from its exposure to a softening real estate market and internal management mistakes.

headline: Do You Have Experience Working With Boeing? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: Boeing’s quality control practices have been criticized after a panel on one of the company’s 737 Max jets blew open during a flight in January.
lead_paragraph: Two fatal crashes. Quality concerns and production slowdowns. A loose panel that blew out during a flight. Boeing is an American institution that has contributed to the country’s place on the global stage. But it is also weathering a particularly difficult period.

headline: House Passes Bipartisan $460 Billion Spending Bill to Avert a Partial Shutdown
abstract: Staring down yet another spending deadline, Speaker Mike Johnson again relied on Democratic votes to push through a six-bill package to fund about half the government through the fall.
lead_paragraph: The House on Wednesday passed a $460 billion spending bill to fund about half the federal government through the fall, moving to avert a partial shutdown at the end of the week and offering the first glimmer of resolution to bitter spending fights that have consumed Congress for months.

headline: Josette Molland, Who Told of Life in Nazi Camps Through Art, Dies at 100
abstract: She endured horrors as a captured member of the French Resistance, and to ensure that her story, too, would survive, she depicted them years later in a series of stark paintings.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1943, Josette Molland, a 20-year-old art student, was certain of two things: that she was making a pretty good living creating designs for Lyon’s silk weavers, and that it was unbearable that Germans occupied her country.

headline: Josette Molland’s Testimony: Scenes of Life in Nazi Camps
abstract: In the 1980s, she created a series of paintings depicting the horrors she endured in forced-labor camps during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Josette Molland, who died at 100 in France on Feb. 17, was a young member of the French Resistance during World War II when she was captured by the Gestapo and imprisoned in Nazi forced-labor camps for women. She survived, after witnessing and enduring repeated episodes of brutality. Later, after her return to France, she spoke to students about her experiences for years.

headline: One Twin Was Hurt, the Other Was Not. Their Adult Mental Health Diverged.
abstract: A large study of “discordant twins,” in which only one suffered abuse or neglect, adds to evidence linking childhood trauma to adult illness.
lead_paragraph: Twins are a bonanza for research psychologists. In a field perpetually seeking to tease out the effects of genetics, environment and life experience, they provide a natural controlled experiment as their paths diverge, subtly or dramatically, through adulthood.

headline: How Trump’s Crushing Primary Triumph Masked Quiet Weaknesses
abstract: Even though he easily defeated Nikki Haley, the primary results suggested that he still has long-term problems with suburban voters, moderates and independents.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s daunting level of Republican support helped him vanquish a field of presidential primary rivals in under two months.

headline: Democratic Congressional Candidate in Michigan to Air First I.V.F. Ad of Election Cycle
abstract: The spot provides a glimpse of how Democrats plan to make the issue of access to fertility treatments central to campaigns across the country.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Michigan on Friday will see the first television advertisement of the campaign cycle featuring a Democratic candidate for Congress talking about her experience using I.V.F. to start a family.

headline: ‘Martin Luther King on Steroids’? Meet a Perfect MAGA Mirror.
abstract: Trump’s pick for North Carolina governor is, like Trump himself, all about ire.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the double edge of a Donald Trump endorsement. On the one hand, the MAGA chieftain has commanded his tribe to vote for you, and that can be enough to propel a candidate into the winner’s circle. On the other hand, you’re stuck with whatever loopy language and loopier logic he used.

headline: Expecting Protests at the Oscars, Police Plan to Beef Up Security
abstract: The Los Angeles police said it would increase its presence at the Academy Awards, given the potential for protests related to the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles police said it would increase its presence at the Academy Awards on Sunday night to make sure that potential protests related to the Israel-Hamas war do not disrupt the Oscars ceremony.

headline: Supper Clubs in New York Are a Vanishing Breed. Café Carlyle Is Keeping the Tradition Alive.
abstract: Any night at the Upper East Side’s nearly 70-year-old cabaret still feels like a big night out.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday evening last December, the singer-pianist Michael Feinstein was at Café Carlyle on Manhattan’s Upper East Side in a sparkly silver blazer, making his way through the audience to the little stage, where the members of his four-piece band were taking their places. The audience erupted into applause. A few people stood and reached out a hand to greet him. As he launched into George and Ira Gershwin’s “Our Love Is Here to Stay,” some sang along, others swayed a little. Written in 1937, the American songbook standard is full of nostalgia, wit and romance. The same might be said for Café Carlyle.

headline: Before N.Y.C. Snow Day Debacle, IBM Had Warned of Tech Limitations
abstract: Technical failures blocked thousands of students who tried to log on to school during a snowstorm. At a City Council hearing on Wednesday, an IBM official said it wasn’t the company’s fault.
lead_paragraph: When New York City held virtual classes during a winter storm last month, the system ran into major tech problems. But officials unfairly blamed IBM for the debacle, according to a company representative and several City Council members who spoke at a hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Nearly Half the States Sue E.P.A. Over New Limits on Deadly Pollution
abstract: Republican attorneys general from 24 states said the crackdown on fine industrial particles would raise costs. The E.P.A. said it would save lives.
lead_paragraph: Manufacturers and 24 states sued the Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday over the Biden administration’s decision to tighten limits on fine industrial particles, one of the most common and deadliest forms of air pollution.

headline: Haley Dropped Out, Making Way for a Biden-Trump Rematch
abstract: Also, National Guard troops will patrol New York’s subway. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina who represented the last, best hope for a faction of Republicans hoping to move the party beyond Donald Trump, announced today that she was ending her presidential campaign after a string of resounding primary losses.

headline: Gray Whale, Long Absent From the Atlantic, Is Spotted Off Massachusetts
abstract: Gray whales are regularly found in the North Pacific, but sightings in the Atlantic, from which they had vanished by the 18th century, are extremely rare.
lead_paragraph: Researchers with the New England Aquarium were conducting a regular survey of the waters south of Martha’s Vineyard and Nantucket in Massachusetts last week when something caught their eye.

headline: Cruise Ship Worker Accused of Hiding Cameras in Bathrooms to Spy on Guests
abstract: The former employee of Royal Caribbean told investigators that he had been secretly recording people since he started working there in December 2023. He faces federal and state charges.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of the cruise ship company Royal Caribbean was accused of placing cameras in guests’ bathrooms and of hiding in their bedrooms and recording them when they took off their clothes, with one of his reported targets being as young as 10.

headline: ‘Rust’ Armorer Convicted of Manslaughter in Alec Baldwin Shooting
abstract: The armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, had placed a live round in a gun the actor was rehearsing with when it fired, killing the film’s cinematographer, Halyna Hutchins.
lead_paragraph: The armorer who put a live round into the gun that Alec Baldwin was rehearsing with on the set of the film “Rust” when it went off, killing the cinematographer, was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter on Wednesday.

headline: Was Trump’s Nomination Always Inevitable?
abstract: As recently as a year ago, less than half of Republican voters named Trump as their preferred candidate.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s exit from the presidential race this morning all but assures former President Donald Trump of the Republican nomination, in a contest that has been notably lacking in suspense. But that wasn’t always the case.

headline: I.M.F. Agrees to Much Larger Rescue Package for Egypt
abstract: The International Monetary Fund will provide $8 billion to Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to more than double a bailout package for Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades, exacerbated by war in the neighboring Gaza Strip and in Ukraine.

headline: Katie Porter, a Rising Star in Congress, Finds Herself Without Another Seat
abstract: The California representative harnessed social media and her committee perch to build a following. But it wasn’t enough to survive a brutal Senate contest, and she has nowhere to go this election season.
lead_paragraph: There were cocktails, and there were sliders. There were pop hits played by a D.J. at The Bungalow, a midcentury-modern lounge in Long Beach, Calif., where Representative Katie Porter had gathered supporters after more than a year of campaigning for a coveted Senate seat.

headline: Lucien Pellat-Finet, Fashion’s ‘King of Cashmere,’ Dies at 78
abstract: The aesthetic of the sweaters he designed, which included provocative symbols like marijuana leaves and skulls, was casual. Their price tags were not.
lead_paragraph: Lucien Pellat-Finet, the French fashion designer whose brash, irreverent and unapologetically expensive sweaters earned him the nickname King of Cashmere, died on Feb. 26 in Trancoso, Brazil, where he had owned a home for more than two decades. He was 78.

headline: Senegal’s Leader Breaks Up Cabinet and Sets Date for Presidential Election
abstract: President Macky Sall previously postponed the election without setting a date. On Wednesday, he also fired the prime minister, his party’s candidate for president.
lead_paragraph: President Macky Sall of Senegal on Wednesday dissolved his cabinet, replaced the prime minister and rescheduled the country’s presidential election to March 24, according to a government statement. The move came weeks after Mr. Sall postponed the ballot indefinitely, throwing the country into one of its deepest political crises in recent history as many feared he might try to stay in power past his term limit.

headline: Takeaways From the Texas Primary: Ken Paxton Ousts Some of His Enemies
abstract: The Republican attorney general succeeded in defeating some politicians and judges who opposed him. But Democrats showed they also know how to punish incumbents.
lead_paragraph: The primary election in Texas on Tuesday was among the most expensive and hard-fought in state history, as factions of the Republican Party battled for control.

headline: The School Issues We’re Battling Over Aren’t the Ones That Matter
abstract: What’s worse than censoring a book? Kids not being able to read it anyway.
lead_paragraph: A Florida school district, facing pressure about “nudity” in schools, removed from shelves a picture book that showed an illustration of a goblin’s bare bottom. Some students were saved from debauchery when school officials colored in a pair of pants on the goblin.

headline: Dr. Anthony Epstein, Pathologist Who Discovered Epstein-Barr Virus, Dies at 102
abstract: His groundbreaking research, which he performed with Yvonne Barr, his doctoral student, uncovered the first virus capable of causing cancer in humans.
lead_paragraph: In March 1961, Dr. Anthony Epstein, a pathologist at Middlesex Hospital in London, almost skipped a visiting physician’s afternoon lecture about children with exceptionally large facial tumors in Uganda.

headline: Eight Teens Are Shot at Philadelphia Bus Stop, Police Say
abstract: The injured high school students, one of whom was in critical condition, range in age from 15 to 17, the police said. It was the latest in a series of shootings on or near public buses in the city.
lead_paragraph: Eight Philadelphia high school students were shot and wounded as they waited for a public bus after school on Wednesday, the latest in a spate of shootings that have touched off outrage in the city, the police said.

headline: How Bad Is Crime in the Subways?
abstract: Officials have spent millions to make New Yorkers transit riders feel safe. The investment is motivated more by passengers’ perception than by crime rates.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s new push to deploy hundreds of state troopers and National Guard members in New York City’s subway to beef up security in the system was evident at Grand Central Terminal Wednesday evening.

headline: Big American Tech Profits From Chinese Ad Spending Spree
abstract: Temu, Shein, and streaming and gaming apps looking to break into the U.S. market are spending huge sums to get their wares in front of American consumers.
lead_paragraph: The trade relationship between China and the United States has plenty of friction. But at least one area is booming: Chinese start-ups looking to establish a presence in the West are spending billions of dollars for advertisements on services owned by some of Silicon Valley’s biggest technology companies.

headline: Trump’s Super Tuesday Speech: Assessing 10 False and Misleading Claims
abstract: After racking up a series of wins that cleared the field, former President Donald J. Trump moved to a general election message. Here’s a fact check.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump moved another step closer to becoming the 2024 Republican nominee for president Tuesday, sweeping up delegates and prompting his last remaining rival, Nikki Haley, to suspend her campaign. The results all but guarantee a November rematch against President Biden.

headline: Ex-Google Engineer Charged With Stealing A.I. Secrets for Chinese Firm
abstract: Linwei Ding, a Chinese national, was arrested in California and accused of uploading hundreds of files to the cloud.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese citizen who recently quit his job as a software engineer for Google in California has been charged with trying to transfer artificial intelligence technology to a Beijing-based company that paid him secretly, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: Are You Embarking on a GLP-1 Journey? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: The New York Times is looking to speak with people who are about to start GLP-1 medications such as Ozempic and are open to allowing us to chronicle their experiences.
lead_paragraph: Have you tried numerous avenues to help your chronic illness, obesity or mental health and turned to Ozempic, Wegovy or another GLP-1 drug to address these issues? The New York Times wants to chronicle the journeys of people who are about to start taking one of these medications or who are losing access to them. We’re especially interested in hearing from groups of people, such as friends or families, that are taking these drugs as a group.

headline: Southern Baptists Say Justice Dept. Has Closed Abuse Inquiry Into Leadership Body
abstract: A Southern Baptist Convention leader said federal investigators had informed the executive committee that there would be no charges against it.
lead_paragraph: A Southern Baptist Convention leader said on Wednesday that the Justice Department had concluded a sexual abuse investigation into the organization’s executive committee without issuing any charges.

lead_paragraph: Waem Al-Farra is expecting her first child, but for her the joys of pregnancy have been replaced with fear and concern for her future and the life of her unborn child.

lead_paragraph: Both President Biden and former President Trump presided over robust economies in their first three years in office. Can you tell who did better in each metric?

headline: Alabama Passes Law to Protect I.V.F. Treatments
abstract: Two major fertility clinics said they were moving to resume treatments quickly, though legal experts cautioned that state constitutional challenges may still arise.
lead_paragraph: Alabama lawmakers passed legislation on Wednesday to shield in vitro fertilization providers from civil and criminal liability, capping off their scramble to allow the fertility treatment after a State Supreme Court ruling found that frozen embryos should be considered children.

lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Weirdly Warm Winter Has Climate Fingerprints All Over It, Study Says
abstract: Recent heat waves in cities worldwide have the hallmarks of global warming, researchers said. And last month was the hottest February on record.
lead_paragraph: Winter was weirdly warm for half the world’s population, driven in many places by the burning of fossil fuels, according to an analysis of temperature data from hundreds of locations worldwide.

headline: Profound Damage Found in Maine Gunman’s Brain, Possibly From Blasts
abstract: A laboratory found a pattern of cell damage that has been seen in veterans exposed to weapons blasts, and said it probably played a role in symptoms the gunman displayed before the shooting.
lead_paragraph: A specialized laboratory examining the brain of the gunman who committed Maine’s deadliest mass shooting found profound brain damage of the kind that has been seen in veterans exposed to repeated blasts from weapons use.

headline: How China Came to Dominate the World in Solar Energy
abstract: Beijing is set to further increase its manufacturing and installation of solar panels as it seeks to master global markets and wean itself from imports.
lead_paragraph: China unleashed the full might of its solar energy industry last year. It installed more solar panels than the United States has in its history. It cut the wholesale price of panels it sells by nearly half. And its exports of fully assembled solar panels climbed 38 percent while its exports of key components almost doubled.

headline: Crowdfunding, Auctions and Raffles: How Ukrainians Are Aiding the Army
abstract: Fund-raisers are borrowing heavily from business techniques to keep donations flowing to the military. The latest trend? Broad approaches that rely on networks of friends and acquaintances.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Daria Chervona, a photo retoucher from Kyiv, was busy trying to raise 78 million Ukrainian hryvnia, about $2 million, for Ukraine’s army, posting daily on social media to urge friends and acquaintances to chip in. That was a high bar, but after a few weeks she announced she had cleared it, reaching her target.

headline: Playing a British Rogue, With Added Firepower
abstract: Daniel Ings has built a career playing charming, posh men. His latest role is a chaotic aristocrat in Guy Ritchie’s series “The Gentlemen.”
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of Guy Ritchie’s new Netflix series “The Gentlemen,” a British aristocrat is forced to dress up in a chicken suit and dance on camera at the pleasure of a gangster to whom he owes money. He flaps his arms wildly, thrusts his head forward and crows at the top of his voice, as tears stream down his face.

headline: Britain Is Cutting Taxes Again. Why Now?
abstract: The government announced a budget as a national election looms. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: At least once a year, Britain’s top financial official stands up in Parliament to lay out his — it has always been a his to date — tax and spending plans that are normally intended to bolster economic growth and keep a check on the nation’s debt. This year, Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the Exchequer, had to consider another priority: the upcoming general election.

headline: A Popular Israeli Minister’s Meeting in London Sends a Message to Netanyahu
abstract: A meeting between the British foreign secretary, David Cameron, and an Israeli minister, Benny Gantz, carried more weight than usual, analysts said, and stressed the frustration of Israel’s allies.
lead_paragraph: When Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, met David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, in London on Wednesday, he got a sharp message that Israel must do more to allow humanitarian aid to flow into Gaza.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Nikki Haley ends her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley announced yesterday that she was ending her presidential campaign, clearing the way for another general election contest between President Biden and former President Donald Trump, an outcome many Americans had hoped to avoid. She had come to represent the last, best chance for Republicans hoping to turn the page on Trump’s divisive brand of politics.

headline: Dark Brandon in the House

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Are You Buying What Kylie Jenner Is Selling?
abstract: The youngest Kardashian-Jenner sister has a new look. And a slew of new products to go along with it.
lead_paragraph: Kylie Jenner is 26 years old. She is a mother of two small children. She no longer wears wigs or bold makeup every day. She no longer wakes up and immediately posts on social media. “Maturity” and “sophistication” are the words guiding her branding now.

headline: Home Care Aides Fight to End 24-Hour Shifts: ‘This Work Is Killing Them’
abstract: Home health care, among the fastest growing industries in New York and nationwide, is also one of the lowest paying, with often grueling hours.
lead_paragraph: For eight years, Lai Yee Chen worked 24-hour shifts, up to five days a week, as a home care aide for bed-bound seniors in New York City. She cooked, cleaned, changed diapers and turned her patients at least every two hours to prevent bedsores.

headline: A Journalist Who Moves Between Writing and Recording
abstract: In an interview, the reporter Annie Correal discussed why she was “thinking for audio” during a recent assignment in South America.
lead_paragraph: For many African migrants, El Dorado International Airport in Bogotá, Colombia, is now one stop on the long journey to the United States. Which is why Annie Correal, who spent January and February covering the Andes region for The New York Times, made the airport a recent reporting destination.

headline: Tree Stump
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: The Disappearance of Mayor Adams
abstract: Unlike most of his predecessors, he has had few accomplishments while leading New York City. But there’s still time to change that.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through Eric Adams’s term as mayor of New York, many of the headlines he generates aren’t about the city; they’re about his personal problems. The F.B.I. raided the home of his chief campaign fund-raiser. Agents seized his cellphones and iPad. Government officials are looking into whether he received illegal campaign donations from foreigners.

headline: A Move to England Led Armistead Maupin Back to ‘Tales of the City’
abstract: Some familiar San Franciscans turn up in the British countryside in “Mona of the Manor,” which the author vows is the 10th, and last, in the series: “That has a nice symmetry.”
lead_paragraph: What book should everybody read before the age of 21?

headline: Bond of Brothers: The Black Crowes Are Back, and Bygones Are Bygones
abstract: After ego clashes and substance abuse drove Chris and Rich Robinson apart, they’ve reunited for their first album of raw rock ’n’ roll together in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing the fractious Black Crowes co-founders agree on, it’s that they’ve never fit in.

headline: Not Just for Scooby-Doo Anymore — the Secret Door Is Having a Moment
abstract: Homeowners are adding hidden doors and rooms to foil burglars, eke out extra storage space and prepare for Armageddon.
