Trump, to block a bipartisan deal that would provide an infusion of money for border security and allow the president to close off the border to asylum seekers.

headline: Biden the President Wants to Curb TikTok. Biden the Candidate Embraces Its Stars.
abstract: At a party for social media influencers at the White House this week, President Biden’s political concerns collided with his national security concerns.
lead_paragraph: The White House is so concerned about the security risks of TikTok that federal workers are not allowed to use the app on their government phones. Top Biden administration officials have even helped craft legislation that could ban TikTok in the United States.

headline: Prosecutors Charge Man With Firing Shots Outside the Capitol on Jan. 6
abstract: The charges once again laid bare one of the most persistent myths about the attack promoted by pro-Trump politicians and media figures: that none of the rioters were armed.
lead_paragraph: A Trump supporter who prosecutors say fired a pistol into the air on the grounds of the Capitol as a mob stormed the building on Jan. 6, 2021, was charged on Friday with firearm offenses, trespassing and interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder.

headline: Biden Makes a Campaign Stop in Pennsylvania
abstract: President Biden held a campaign rally outside Philadelphia on Friday to amplify his message from his State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: President Biden held a campaign rally outside Philadelphia on Friday to amplify his message from his State of the Union address.

headline: Providing Both Bombs and Food, Biden Puts Himself in the Middle of Gaza’s War
abstract: The president’s decision to send aid by air and sea represents a shift prompted by the growing humanitarian crisis. But it raised uncomfortable questions about America’s role.
lead_paragraph: From the skies over Gaza these days fall American bombs and American food pallets, delivering death and life at the same time and illustrating President Biden’s elusive effort to find balance in an unbalanced Middle East war.

headline: Senate Clears $460 Billion Bill to Avert Partial Shutdown, Sending It to Biden
abstract: The White House said the executive branch was halting shutdown preparations and that President Biden would sign the bill on Saturday. But the spending fight isn’t over yet.
lead_paragraph: The Senate gave final approval on Friday to a $460 billion spending bill to fund about half the federal government through the fall, sending the legislation to President Biden’s desk with just hours to spare to avert a partial shutdown.

headline: National Guard in the Subway? A Transit Reporter Explains.
abstract: Ana Ley covers mass transit and commuters in New York City. In an interview, she discussed Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision to beef up security on the city’s subway.
lead_paragraph: The New York City subway is full of surprises, and Ana Ley, who covers mass transit for The Times, is used to waking up not knowing where her reporting will take her next. Still, Ms. Ley was shocked on Wednesday when Gov. Kathy Hochul announced she was deploying members of the National Guard to patrol subway stations and assist the police officers who inspect riders’ bags.

headline: About 600 Workers Unionize at Microsoft-Owned Activision
abstract: The group will become the largest union at a video game company in the United States, while Microsoft pledged to stay neutral on the vote.
lead_paragraph: About 600 workers at Activision Publishing, the video game maker owned by Microsoft, are unionizing, forming the largest video game workers’ union in the United States, the Communications Workers of America said on Friday. Microsoft recognized the union after the vote count was finalized.

headline: Read the Federal Judge’s Ruling
abstract: A U.S. district judge allowed the Biden administration to continue a program that it has used to give temporary legal status to hundreds of thousands of citizens of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. district judge allowed the Biden administration to continue a program that it has used to give temporary legal status to hundreds of thousands of citizens of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.

headline: Pet Shop That Sold Sick and Hurt Puppies Will Repay Nearly 200 Customers
abstract: Shake A Paw agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by New York’s attorney general after investigators found that the Long Island business was selling puppies from so-called puppy mills.
lead_paragraph: The owners of a Long Island pet store accused of knowingly selling hundreds of sick and injured puppies, including some that died days after being bought, will pay $300,000 to about 200 customers under a settlement announced by New York’s attorney general on Friday.

headline: MacGyvering
abstract: Let’s see if we can puzzle our way out of John Guzzetta’s tough themeless.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is all about its innovative verbiage, which could be contorted into a portmanteau; let’s not try to make “innoverbiage” happen, though. John Guzzetta has made New York Times crosswords for every day of the week, but he’s a particular whiz at a themeless: This is his 20th construction that has run on a Friday or Saturday. I love the way offbeat elements are peppered throughout this puzzle; big oddball surprises alternate with little deadpan touches.

headline: Biden Makes a Rare Mention of Marijuana in the State of the Union
abstract: The president pointed toward his efforts to ease restrictions on cannabis, a potential signal that he could talk more during the campaign about an issue he has been reluctant to embrace.
lead_paragraph: Buried in President Biden’s fiery re-election pitch in his State of the Union address on Thursday night was a brief mention of an issue he has often been reluctant to embrace: marijuana.

headline: Army Investigators Search for Answers After Helicopter Crash That Killed 3
abstract: Two National Guard soldiers and a Border Patrol agent died in the crash in Texas during what the military says was a routine mission on the border.
lead_paragraph: Army investigators on Saturday headed to the site where a military helicopter crashed in southern Texas the previous day, killing two National Guard soldiers and a Border Patrol agent.

headline: Police Shoot and Kill Man Suspected of Stabbing a Woman at a Party
abstract: The police said they had found the man, 46, holding a knife in the hallway of a Queens apartment building when they responded to reports of an assault.
lead_paragraph: A 46-year-old man died Friday night after police officers in Queens shot at him four times and used a Taser because they said he was wielding a knife after a dispute at a social gathering, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Baffled Londoners Start Spreading the Schmear
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t tell you how many times I say, ‘sesame, black sesame, poppy, garlic, onion and salt’ — it literally just comes off the tip of my tongue now.”

headline: Corrections: March 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday out racial profiling by police in Japan misstated the publication year for the training manual used by police in the Aichi prefecture. It was published in 2009, not 2021.

headline: ‘You Can Hear a Pin Drop’: The Rise of Super Strict Schools in England
abstract: Inspired by the academic success of schools like the Michaela secondary school in northwest London, some principals are introducing tight controls on students’ behavior.
lead_paragraph: As the teacher started to count down, the students uncrossed their arms and bowed their heads, completing the exercise in a flash.

headline: Macron and Scholz, Never Close, Spar Over Policy Toward Ukraine and Russia
abstract: A fraught relationship has recently turned bitter, with insults and barbs threatening European unity at a critical moment.
lead_paragraph: It was a private dinner in a Parisian garden on the Boulevard St. Germain, meant to cement the important personal relationship between the leaders of France and Germany.

headline: The 10-Year-Old Boy Who Has Become the Face of Starvation in Gaza
abstract: The harrowing image of a skeletal Yazan Kafarneh circulated widely on social media and has served as a graphic warning about the enclave’s dire food situation.
lead_paragraph: It is all too easy to trace the skull beneath the Gazan boy’s face, the pallid skin stretching tight over every curve of bone and sagging with every hollow. His chin juts with a disturbing sharpness. His flesh has shrunk and shriveled, life reduced to little more than a thin mask over an imminent death.

headline: Sweden and Canada to Restart Payments to U.N. Agency for Palestinians
abstract: The countries were among those that suspended payments to the  agency, known as UNRWA, after Israel accused a dozen of its employees of taking part in Hamas-led terrorist attacks on Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: Canada and Sweden are resuming funding for the main United Nations agency supporting Palestinian refugees in Gaza, citing the spiraling humanitarian catastrophe there and saying that the agency had taken steps to improve accountability amid accusations that some of its employees had links to Hamas.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: How a Pioneering Jazz Musician and Teacher Spends Her Sundays
abstract: There weren’t many female jazz musicians when Carol Sudhalter started her career. Now she spends her Sundays sharing what she has learned.
lead_paragraph: Although Carol Sudhalter’s first love was the flute, she was also seduced by the saxophone early in her career as a jazz musician.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How Fraudsters Break Into Social Security Accounts and Steal Benefits
abstract: Thousands of people receiving Social Security benefits have had their money diverted into criminal accounts. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, Liz Birenbaum’s 88-year-old mother, Marge, has received her Social Security check on the second Wednesday of each month. It’s her sole source of income, which pays for her room at a long-term care center, where she landed last October after having a stroke.

headline: Lily Gladstone for Best Actress? Oscars Gamblers Are Betting Big.
abstract: Inside the world of people making bets on the winners of the Academy Awards — with some taking home thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.

headline: Three Is Best: How China’s Family Planning Propaganda Has Changed
abstract: Faced with a shrinking and aging population, China is using propaganda channels to send the message: have more babies.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a shrinking and aging population, China is using propaganda channels to send the message: have more babies.

headline: Four Years On, the Mysteries of Covid Are Unraveling
abstract: Are superdodgers real? Is Covid seasonal? And what’s behind its strangest symptoms? Here’s what we’ve learned.
lead_paragraph: When the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a global pandemic in March 2020, nearly everything about the novel coronavirus was an open question: How was it spreading so quickly? How sick would it make people? Would a single bout buy you protection from future cases?

headline: He Played the Victim. It Earned Him Attention, Success and a Lot of Trouble.
abstract: In Andrew Boryga’s debut novel, a young writer creates a career for himself by exaggerating, or sometimes completely manufacturing, stories of tragedy.
lead_paragraph: There’s real value in being a victim. Serious profit in pity, but only so long as you don’t become too ambitious, too greedy or too arrogant. Veer too far, and you run the risk of becoming dependent on disaster. That’s when real trouble ensues.

headline: They Married, Divorced and Then Married Their Ex-Spouses Again
abstract: Five couples share how and why they decided to reconcile and tie the knot again.
lead_paragraph: Famous couples who marry, divorce and then remarry their former spouses are often fodder for tabloid headlines. Think of the actors Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, who were married to each other twice — first for a decade beginning in 1964, and then again in 1975 before they divorced the next year. Elon Musk and Talulah Riley were wed from 2010 to 2012 and again from 2013 to 2016.

headline: Maps Are for More Than Just Finding Your Way
abstract: In the digital age, old-fashioned maps were expected to die out. But just look around the room.
lead_paragraph: “Looking at a map is like looking into a fire in a fireplace; there’s a sense of something happening all the time, and it draws you in,” said Anders Mattsson, a cabinetmaker for Svenskt Tenn.

headline: Dog Day Afternoon
abstract: My autistic son, the unleashed dogs of Manhattan and me.
lead_paragraph: My young adult son Jason and I are crossing Riverside Drive to get to the park on the other side.

headline: Outfits of Epic Proportions
abstract: Otherworldly silhouettes and extravagant textures characterized the clothes seen on and off the runways at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Intricate textures, big chunky shoes and futuristic silhouettes were prevalent in the crowds at Paris Fashion Week, where Japanese labels like Comme des Garçons, Junya Watanabe and Yohji Yamamoto — all of which have long been favorites of the industry establishment — appeared to have infiltrated the wardrobes of many fans whose only view of the shows was from the streets.

headline: How Trump’s Justice Dept. Derailed an Investigation of a Major Company
abstract: The industrial giant Caterpillar hired William Barr and other lawyers to defuse a federal criminal investigation of alleged tax dodges.
lead_paragraph: In December 2018, a team of federal law enforcement agents flew to Amsterdam to interview a witness in a yearslong criminal investigation into Caterpillar, which had avoided billions of dollars of income taxes by shifting profits to a Swiss subsidiary.

headline: Can You Create a Diverse College Class Without Affirmative Action?
abstract: The Supreme Court effectively ended race-based admissions preferences. But will selective schools still be able to achieve diverse student bodies? Here’s how they might try.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court effectively ended race-based admissions preferences. But will selective schools still be able to achieve diverse student bodies? Here’s how they might try.

headline: A Food Writer Whose Essays Go Heavy on the Salt and Fire
abstract: Geraldine DeRuiter’s “If You Can’t Take the Heat” expands on her viral, award-winning blog posts.
lead_paragraph: Geraldine DeRuiter, the pungent voice behind the Everywhereist blog, knows how to rant.

headline: 13 Things We’re Still Mad About: Oscars Edition
abstract: We asked staffers in Culture and Books about the snubs from years past that still bother them, and they had some things to say.
lead_paragraph: I have never forgiven the Oscars for picking “Birdman” over “Boyhood.” What can I say — “Boyhood” was moving and meaningful, while “Birdman” was pretentious and obtuse, and none of my cinéaste colleagues are going to persuade me otherwise. MICHAEL PAULSON, theater reporter

headline: The Journalist Who Tried to Fight the Nazis With Radio Stories
abstract: In “How to Win an Information War,” Peter Pomerantsev looks to a World War II propagandist for lessons in the battle between Russia and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In 1931, the British journalist Sefton Delmer interviewed Adolf Hitler, whose long-shot presidential campaign he was covering for a British paper. “I realized in a flash the secret to his power,” Delmer wrote in The Daily Express. Hitler had “mesmerized millions of men and women into fanatical allegiance” with his impassioned gaze and “personal zealotry.”

headline: The Meaning of Influence, Written in the Stars
abstract: Celestial bodies have influence. So do drinks, advertisers and a TikTok personality known as Pookie.
lead_paragraph: Madison Malone Kircher, who reports on internet culture for The New York Times, has written about several influencers this year. One competed in the Mrs. World pageant two weeks after giving birth. Another, known as Pookie, drew the fascination — and ire — of TikTok users. A third “rose to viral fame for her leftover salmon recipe.”

headline: Something Old. Something New. Something Thrifted.
abstract: Focused on recycled clothing, some brides are finding their wedding attire on vintage sites and at resale stores.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Emmali Osterhoudt was at a Goodwill store in Birmingham, Ala., when she stumbled upon a Galia Lahav wedding gown. Though she was not yet engaged, Ms. Osterhoudt, 21, couldn’t pass up the opportunity to purchase the find: The gown was priced at $25.

headline: Lisa Ann Walter of ‘Abbott Elementary’ on the Show She’ll Never Forget
abstract: “I would challenge anybody to see Patti LuPone in her prime sing ‘Evita,’” the actress said, “and not say, ‘That was the best show I’ve ever seen in my life.’”
lead_paragraph: It was a Monday morning in Los Angeles and Lisa Ann Walter had the day off from “Abbott Elementary,” the ABC sitcom about an underfunded public school in Philadelphia.

headline: ‘Free to Be … You and Me’ Took the Revolution to the Playground
abstract: Fifty years ago, the TV landmark showed Gen X kids that no one else has the right to tell you who you are.
lead_paragraph: “Free to Be … You and Me,” the 1974 kids-TV special and feminist milestone, begins with footage of children riding a carousel. I was one of them. Not literally — I watched the show on TV like millions of other baby Gen X-ers. But these kids, laughing and spinning, were my cohort at a strange point in history.

headline: This Debut Novel Is a Wondrous Babel of Ideas and Language
abstract: In “The Extinction of Irena Rey,” a writer goes missing and her translators give pursuit — until things get weird.
lead_paragraph: In gist: Oh my mushrooms, “The Extinction of Irena Rey” is incredibly strange, savvy, sly and hard to classify. I also couldn’t put it down.

headline: The Biden-Trump Rerun: A Nation Craving Change Gets More of the Same
abstract: Americans love a candidate who promises something new. But when a sitting president runs against a former one, can either claim the mantle of change?
lead_paragraph: The promise of change has been a powerful force in presidential campaigns for decades, a reliable appeal to a fundamental yearning in the American electorate. It was central to the candidacies of John F. Kennedy, Ronald Reagan, Barack Obama and Donald J. Trump.

headline: These Oscar Snubs Still Rile Up Readers
abstract: You can’t forgive the Academy for passing up “Brokeback Mountain” or omitting Amy Adams in “Arrival,” among other oversights that still sting.
lead_paragraph: Some things will always stick in your craw. When I asked readers, ahead of the Academy Awards on Sunday, if they were still mad about an Oscar snub, boy, did I get an earful.

headline: Toyota’s Hybrid-First Strategy Is Delivering Big Profits
abstract: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, has been criticized for selling few electric vehicles, but its decision to focus on hybrids is paying off financially.
lead_paragraph: In today’s high-tech, high-stakes auto industry, fortunes can change quickly, and there’s no better example of that right now than Toyota Motor.

headline: BMW Is a Surprise Winner in Electric Vehicles
abstract: Once considered a laggard, the German luxury carmaker is one of only a few established automakers that has been able to compete effectively against Tesla.
lead_paragraph: As BMW car bodies glided down an assembly line in Munich recently, showered by sparks from robotic welders, it was hard to tell which vehicles would be powered by batteries, fuel-burning engines or both. In the view of many analysts, that is not a good thing.

headline: A Panorama of Design
abstract: A look at design-world events, products and people.
lead_paragraph: Love’s bonds can be delicate yet feel constraining and require hard work to maintain. How better to express all that than by slicing paper into handmade greeting cards, with whorls that can be pulled up to form gossamer cages for images of lovebirds, bouquets, engagement rings, or even rodents?

headline: The Long, Strange History of ‘Manifesting’
abstract: Americans have long been attracted to the idea that we can shape reality with our will.
lead_paragraph: Reality is what you make it — at least according to those who believe in manifesting, the art and quasi-spiritual science of willing things into existence through the power of desire, attention and focus.

headline: They Want to Make Palm Oil in a Lab. Without Palm Trees.
abstract: Palm oil. It’s in your snacks, your soap, pretty much everything. But palm oil plantations have caused vast deforestation. Can these three tech executives help fix things?
lead_paragraph: A handful of startups are trying to reinvent one of the most ubiquitous, but also environmentally destructive, ingredients in our diets: palm oil.

headline: Miami Beach Is Done With Spring Breakers: ‘It’s Not Us. It’s You.’
abstract: This weekend and next, Miami Beach visitors will face extraordinary measures meant to head off disorderly crowds, including bag checks at beach entrances and closed parking garages.
lead_paragraph: More than two decades ago, Wayne Jones traveled to Daytona Beach, then Florida’s spring break mecca, not to party but to study.

headline: These May Be the Oldest Olive Trees in the World
abstract: While the sentinel trees of Northern Lebanon may not be as old as some traditions hold, one tree might be more than 1,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Olive trees are common in Northern Lebanon, but in the village of Bshaaleh, a handful look downright ancient. Their branches grow in wildly unpredictable directions, and the trees’ gray, gnarled trunks are shot through with holes and crevasses large enough to hide a sleeping child. Many people believe these sentinel trees are thousands of years old. They are known as “Noah trees” because of some people’s belief that the trees are the source of the olive branch carried by the dove back to Noah’s ark.

headline: The Surprising Left-Right Alliance That Wants More Apartments in Suburbs
abstract: The YIMBY movement isn’t just for liberals anymore. Legislators from both sides of the political divide are working to add duplexes and apartments to single-family neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Yimbytown conference was an ideologically safe space where liberal young professionals could talk to other liberal young professionals about the particular problems of cities with a lot of liberal young professionals: not enough bike lanes and transit, too many restrictive zoning laws.

headline: Rains Are Scarce in the Amazon. Instead, Megafires Are Raging.
abstract: Hundreds of square miles of the rainforest have burned as countries in the region battle a record number of fires fueled by extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: By this time of the year, rain should be drenching large swaths of the Amazon rainforest. Instead, a punishing drought has kept the rains at bay, creating dry conditions for fires that have engulfed hundreds of square miles of the rainforest that do not usually burn.

headline: A Former Trump Aide Becomes a Liberal Favorite
abstract: After breaking with her onetime boss, Alyssa Farah Griffin finds a warm welcome on “The View” and CNN.
lead_paragraph: Now and then during an election cycle, a Republican pundit becomes something of a hero to Democrats.

headline: Navalny’s Heirs Seek a Political Future in Russia
abstract: Aleksei Navalny’s team has found a new leader in the opposition leader’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya. But Navalny’s death has so far brought little change to their insular tactics.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny built Russia’s largest opposition force in his image, embodying a freer, fairer Russia for millions. His exiled team now faces the daunting task of steering his political movement without him.

headline: Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson Drank There. Now You Can, Too.
abstract: A bar set built for “The Banshees of Inisherin” was discarded in a backyard after filming, then resurrected by a pub in Ireland. It’s up for sale.
lead_paragraph: It’s a quiet Thursday evening in Ireland’s rural midlands, and Mee’s Bar in Kilkerrin, County Galway, is hardly buzzing. The large space is mostly dark, the stools are mostly empty, and out front, on the only road through town, most cars roll by without stopping — foreboding features that have marked many an Irish country pub for dead.

headline: A Call to End Gambling Ads as Athletes and Celebrities Are Shut Out of Them
abstract: A group wants the federal government to mirror its blanket restrictions on tobacco ads, citing addiction and its effect on sports.
lead_paragraph: With the hockey season winding down, many Canadians have two things on their minds: their teams’ playoff chances and a barrage of television ads for online sports gambling.

headline: Cramming for the Oscars
abstract: It’s been a rough year for Hollywood, but the post-awards season landscape offers some hints of hope for audiences.
lead_paragraph: I’m in competition with no one but myself in trying to view all the major-category nominees for the Oscars before the ceremony tomorrow night. I’m doing well this year, probably because the slate is fairly small: Most of the films with acting and screenplay nominations are also contenders for best picture. If I can get over my aversion to biopics that I wish were documentaries instead, I have a good chance of going into the ceremony with the confidence of a dorky student who’s done all the reading for the final exam.

headline: Heretics
abstract: The Rev. Carlton Pearson was a rising evangelical star — until he rejected hell.
lead_paragraph: The story of the Rev. Carlton Pearson, who was a rising star in the evangelical movement until he cast aside the idea of hell and, with it, everything he’d worked for over his entire life.

headline: I Said the Era of Famines Might Be Ending. I Was Wrong.
abstract: Many things go into the conditions that create a food crisis: crop failures, high food prices, unemployment. But it’s war that has created the famines unfolding today.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight years ago I wrote an essay for New York Times Opinion asking whether the world had finally moved beyond the peril of large-scale famines. My answer was that it might very well have.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Is the Origin Story. These Three Movies Reveal Our Nuclear Present.
abstract: How films and culture help us imagine the unimaginable.
lead_paragraph: The national security writer W. J. Hennigan has spent many years ringing the alarm about the world’s new nuclear era — the subject of At The Brink, a new series from New York Times Opinion — and the crisis on the horizon. For anyone whose interest was piqued by the origin story of nuclear weapons in “Oppenheimer,” Mr. Hennigan, who happens to be a movie buff, recommends three essential films that illuminate our new nuclear era.

headline: This Prophetic Academic Now Foresees the West’s Defeat
abstract: Emmanuel Todd, a historian and anthropologist, has a knack for prediction.
lead_paragraph: “If anybody in this room thinks Putin will stop at Ukraine, I assure you, he will not,” President Biden said during his State of the Union address on Thursday night. Europe is “at risk,” he added, as he welcomed Ulf Kristersson, the prime minister of Sweden, the newest member of NATO.

headline: How ‘Past Lives’ Changed My Mind About My Relationship
abstract: In the movie’s central love triangle, I rooted for one outcome. But my dating life told a different story.
lead_paragraph: My most stressful moviegoing experience last year was not the mushroom cloud in “Oppenheimer” or the murder trial scenes in “Anatomy of a Fall,” but watching the story of a love triangle among a Korean American woman, a Korean guy and a white guy in the Oscar-nominated “Past Lives.” In the film, Nora, our 30-something heroine, and Arthur, her white husband, are living happily in New York when Nora is contacted by Hae Sung, her childhood sweetheart in South Korea, with whom she had reconnected online as a young adult.

headline: ‘People Are Hoping That Israel Nukes Us So We Get Rid of This Pain’
abstract: A father’s desperate texts from Gaza offer a window into five months of suffering there.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden weighs American policy toward Gaza, may he think of a gentle scholar named Mohammed Alshannat.

headline: Why It’s Hard to Explain Joe Biden’s Unpopularity
abstract: A theory of why Biden’s presidency has so far been a political flop.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is one of the most unpopular presidents in modern American history. In Gallup polling, his approval ratings are lower than those of any other president embarking on a re-election campaign, from Dwight Eisenhower to Donald Trump.

headline: New Biden Ad Pokes Fun at His Age: ‘I’m Not a Young Guy. That’s No Secret.’
abstract: The ad, which will target a youthful demographic, represents a shift in tone, trying to turn one of the president’s greatest perceived liabilities into an asset.
lead_paragraph: In a new advertisement for his re-election campaign, President Biden tries to take one of his greatest perceived liabilities as a candidate, his age, and turn it into an advantage.

headline: Two Novels About Social Withdrawal
abstract: A chilly marriage; a catatonic protagonist.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: What Would Paying Student Athletes Look Like?
abstract: A college team’s vote to unionize adds pressure on the N.C.A.A. to abandon rules that forbid paying student athletes like employees.
lead_paragraph: “Unions are tricky for college sports,” Jay Bilas, the ESPN college basketball analyst, said over the phone the other day, “because you’ve got public and private institutions and different state laws.”

headline: Russia’s Advance Around Avdiivka Loses Momentum After Quick Gains
abstract: Ukraine has committed significant forces to defending the area, and Russian troops are now attacking across open fields with little cover.
lead_paragraph: When the eastern city of Avdiivka, a Ukrainian stronghold, fell to Russian forces three weeks ago, Kyiv and its allies feared that Moscow’s troops could build on their momentum and quickly press ahead toward strategic military hubs and population centers.

headline: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Speaks Out About ‘Hateful’ Online Bullying
abstract: In an appearance at SXSW, Meghan said she experienced the heaviest online abuse during her pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: The glare of public attention has often left Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, on the receiving end of strong opinions. And Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, pushed back at that directly on Friday, criticizing a culture of bullying on social media.

headline: Fighting Hopelessness in Treating Addiction
abstract: Readers praise a column by Nicholas Kristof about an effective program.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Luscious Miso Leeks With White Beans
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s satisfying take on leeks vinaigrette combines silky leeks with a mustardy miso dressing and creamy white beans.
lead_paragraph: I respect leeks. They stand firm and tall above their allium kin, their jade-green tops proudly poking out from your grocery bag. They make you work for them, with all that careful washing to rinse the sand and grit from between their layers. (They’re also, as far as I know, the only vegetable to be constantly carried by a Pokémon.) And leeks are thoughtful — they don’t make you cry as you chop them for your meal. (I’m looking at you, onions.)

headline: Ireland Rejects Constitution Changes, Keeping ‘Women in the Home’ Language
abstract: Two proposed amendments, which voters considered on Friday, were intended to reflect the more secular, liberal values of the nation’s modern era.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Ireland rejected two proposed changes to the country’s Constitution that would have removed language about women’s duties being in the home and broadened the definition of family beyond marriage, dealing a blow to the government that analysts said suggested the weakness of their campaign to pass the proposals.

headline: Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns
abstract: At SXSW, a documentary traces the arc of plastics in our lives, and highlights evolving research of the potential harm of its presence in our bodies.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than five decades since Dustin Hoffman’s character in “The Graduate” was offered a kernel of wisdom about the path to prosperity.

headline: Britt Tells Misleading Border Story in State of the Union Response
abstract: The Alabama senator used a story about sex trafficking to criticize the Biden administration’s border policies. But the events occurred in Mexico years ago.
lead_paragraph: The opposition party’s response to the State of the Union address is a golden opportunity for up-and-coming and lesser-known politicians to introduce themselves to the nation and boost their political profile.

headline: Northeast Braces for Heavy Rain After Severe Weather Moves Across the South
abstract: Forecasters said the New York City area could get up to two inches of rain into Sunday morning, with the highest totals expected in northeastern New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A storm system that battered parts of the South with heavy rain on Saturday was expected to reach the Northeast, bringing with it the potential for coastal flooding and powerful winds, forecasters said.

headline: As U.S. Rushes to Build Gaza Port, Major Challenges Loom
abstract: Famine is stalking Gaza, but the American-led initiative faces daunting obstacles in logistics, security and cost.
lead_paragraph: As the United States military rushes to assemble a temporary port on the Gaza coast, daunting practical challenges to the seaborne humanitarian effort to stave off famine in the territory are becoming increasingly apparent. The obstacles include logistics, cost and security issues, diplomats and aid officials say.

headline: Biden Signs Legislation to Extend Funding for Critical Departments
abstract: With a partial shutdown averted, President Biden and Congress face tough negotiations ahead to finance the remaining federal agencies and departments by March 22.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed a $460 billion spending package on Saturday to avert a shutdown of critical federal departments even as lawmakers continue to wrestle over a financing blueprint for many other agencies more than halfway into the current fiscal year.

headline: Frostbitten Kansas City Fans Needed Amputations After Frigid Game
abstract: A Missouri hospital said the amputations involved mostly fingers and toes after a game in January when temperatures were below zero.
lead_paragraph: Several fans of the Kansas City Chiefs who attended a playoff game on a bitterly cold January day in Missouri suffered frostbite that required amputations, according to the hospital that treated them.

headline: Pope Says Ukraine Should Have the ‘Courage of the White Flag’
abstract: His words have raised questions about whether Francis was suggesting that Ukraine surrender, but a Vatican spokesman said the pope meant “cease-fire and negotiation.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has reiterated in a new interview that Ukraine should negotiate to end the war with Russia, but this time he used language — adopting his interviewer’s expression, “white flag” — that has drawn attention and raised questions about whether the pope was suggesting that Ukraine surrender.

headline: With Haiti in Chaos, a Humanitarian Crisis Is Rapidly Unfolding
abstract: As gangs have united in concerted attacks against the state, the prime minister is stranded in Puerto Rico, and food, water, fuel and medical care are in short supply.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald V. LaRoche has not been able to cross into dangerous territory to inspect the hospital he runs in Haiti’s Delmas 18 neighborhood since it was ransacked by gangs last week, but a TikTok video he saw offered clues to its current condition: It was on fire.

headline: Petra Mathers, Author Whose Children’s Stories Soared, Dies at 78
abstract: Her winsome animal characters and their comic adventures expressed universal truths and feelings, rendered in a naïve and often surrealistic style.
lead_paragraph: Petra Mathers, a German-born children’s book illustrator and author whose kindly, often bumbling animal characters were nonetheless quietly heroic and often risked much for love, died on Feb. 6 at her home in Astoria, Ore. She was 78.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Open Criminal Inquiry Into Boeing
abstract: The investigation is tied to an incident on an Alaska Airlines flight in early January. Boeing also told a Senate panel that it cannot find a record of the work done on the Alaska plane.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into Boeing after a panel on one of the company’s planes blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight in early January, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: William Whitworth, Revered Writer and Editor, Is Dead at 87
abstract: After writing memorable character sketches and fine-tuning others’ copy at The New Yorker, he spent two decades as editor in chief of The Atlantic Monthly.
lead_paragraph: William Whitworth, who wrote revealing profiles in The New Yorker and polished the prose of some of the nation’s celebrated writers as its associate editor before transplanting that magazine’s painstaking standards to The Atlantic, where he was editor in chief for 20 years, died on Friday in Conway, Ark., near Little Rock. He was 87.

headline: Rack ’Em Up
abstract: Enrique Henestroza Anguiano and Matthew Stock are friends with words.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Potential Obstacle to Trump Media’s Merger Appears to Have Been Cleared
abstract: Two early founders of Donald Trump’s social media company reached a temporary truce with the company on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The threat of a last-minute obstacle to the merger of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company and a cash-rich shell company appears to have subsided.

headline: National Guard Can’t Carry Long Guns While Checking Bags in Subway
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul issued an order forbidding the weapons at bag-check stations on Wednesday, directly after her announcement that soldiers would be deployed to New York City’s subways.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Wednesday that hundreds of National Guard soldiers would be deployed to patrol the New York City subway system and check riders’ bags, her office made an adjustment: Soldiers searching bags would not carry long guns.

headline: Biden Expresses Regret for Calling an Undocumented Immigrant ‘an Illegal’

When they reached their destination, a small village less than two miles from Russian lines, all that was left were destroyed houses, their shattered roofs visible in the moonlight.

headline: A.I. Is Learning What It Means to Be Alive
abstract: Given troves of data about genes and cells, A.I. models have made some surprising discoveries. What could they teach us someday?
lead_paragraph: In 1889, a French doctor named Francois-Gilbert Viault climbed down from a mountain in the Andes, drew blood from his arm and inspected it under a microscope. Dr. Viault’s red blood cells, which ferry oxygen, had surged 42 percent. He had discovered a mysterious power of the human body: When it needs more of these crucial cells, it can make them on demand.

headline: Wyoming Banned Abortion. She Opened an Abortion Clinic Anyway.
abstract: The only abortion clinic left in the state has been protested and set on fire, rebuilt and opened as Wyoming grapples with what it means to be conservative in a post-Roe nation.
lead_paragraph: It was not such an implausible idea, back in 2020, when a philanthropist emailed Julie Burkhart to ask if she would consider opening an abortion clinic in Wyoming, one of the nation’s most conservative states and the one that had twice given Donald Trump his biggest margin of victory.

headline: Klimt Landscape Show Is More, and Less, Than Expected

lead_paragraph: It was exciting to look forward to the exhibition “Klimt Landscapes,” now at the Neue Galerie. Klimt, of course, is Gustav Klimt (1862-1918), the Austrian modernist widely beloved for his paintings of the most beautiful women of Vienna’s haute bourgeoisie.

headline: Gabriel García Márquez’s Last Book Is an Unsatisfying Goodbye
abstract: “Until August” is a “rediscovered” novel that the Colombian master wrote as his memory began failing.
lead_paragraph: Billed as a “rediscovered” novel, “Until August” is likely to be the last published book of fiction by the Colombian master and Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez. It would be hard to imagine a more unsatisfying goodbye from the author of “One Hundred Years of Solitude” (1967), the book that threw open the doors of Latin American literature with no less force than Boccaccio’s “Decameron” did for 14th-century Italy. “Until August,” nimbly translated by Anne McLean, is a microscopic story, its contents hardly sufficient for it to be called a novella, much less a finished novel. Reading it may provoke unhealthy levels of frustration in those familiar with García Márquez’s most indelible creations.

headline: One Year After Bank Crisis, a Struggle Over What Needs to Change

lead_paragraph: Among the scattered notes taped to the door of the Irish author Colum McCann’s home office in Manhattan is a photograph of James Foley, the American journalist who was murdered by members of the Islamic State in August 2014. In the picture, he leans against a barricade of sandbags in jeans and a flak vest, reading McCann’s novel “Let the Great World Spin.”

headline: He’s Not Just Looking to Make a Quick Billion

He backed a nuclear fusion start-up, and another designing flying taxis. Frustrated with the current state of capitalism, he embarked on plans to build, from scratch, a Bjarke Ingels-designed city of five million in the American West.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Can Humans Endure the Psychological Torment of Mars?’
abstract: NASA is conducting tests on what might be the greatest challenge of a Mars mission: the trauma of isolation.
lead_paragraph: That people will travel to Mars, and soon, is a widely accepted conviction within NASA. Rachel McCauley, until recently the acting deputy director of NASA’s Mars campaign, had, as of July, a punch list of 800 problems that must be solved before the first human mission launches. Many of these concern the mechanical difficulties of transporting people to a planet that is never closer than 33.9 million miles away; keeping them alive on poisonous soil in unbreathable air, bombarded by solar radiation and galactic cosmic rays, without access to immediate communication; and returning them safely to Earth, more than a year and half later. But McCauley does not doubt that NASA will overcome these challenges. What NASA does not yet know — what nobody can know — is whether humanity can overcome the psychological torment of Martian life.

headline: Why Haley Voters Should Support Biden
