abstract: The retailer brings about 2,000 managers a year to its headquarters to discuss how to relate to workers and customers, part of a U.S. corporate trend.
lead_paragraph: On a stormy afternoon in Bentonville, Ark., a Walmart regional manager recounted a story about a moment when his humanity came up short.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: ‘Floor Person’
abstract: Do you enjoy lying on the ground every once in a while?
lead_paragraph: Are you a “floor person”? Do you enjoy sitting or lying on the ground, even when there’s a comfortable couch, chair or bed nearby?

headline: Roswell
abstract: Why did a U.F.O. allegedly crash in Roswell, N.M., of all places? In 1994 the filmmaker Bill Brown set out on a road trip to explore the 1947 incident.
lead_paragraph: Why did a U.F.O. allegedly crash in Roswell, N.M., of all places? In 1994 the filmmaker Bill Brown set out on a road trip to explore the 1947 incident.

headline: Obama, More Than Dickens, Looms Over This ‘Great Expectations’
abstract: Vinson Cunningham’s impressive debut novel finds a watchful campaign aide measuring his ambitions on the trail of a magnetic presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: As much as I pretend that I’m too conscientious, too emancipated, too Black and mostly just too lazy to succumb to a cult, the aesthetic choices I made in 2008 — when a distressed white tee featuring Shepard Fairey’s rendering of Barack Obama was an essential part of my wardrobe — remind me I ain’t that special. Still, I had company. “Great Expectations,” Vinson Cunningham’s brolic and dazzlingly written debut novel, transports us to that time, when America’s most valuable commodity was proximity — real or perceived; burgeoning or dimming — to the soon-to-be president.

headline: What a U.F.O. Crash Teaches Us About Our Time on Earth
abstract: Why did a U.F.O. allegedly crash in Roswell, N.M., of all places? In 1994 the filmmaker Bill Brown set out on a road trip to explore the 1947 incident.
lead_paragraph: It was 1991. I listened to “Motorway to Roswell” by the Pixies a million times, but it’s not exactly where this movie came from. Partly it was the U.F.O. paperbacks I inhaled as a nerdy kid in Lubbock, Texas, and partly it was Lubbock itself. Growing up in West Texas, I learned that the real action is in the sky: dust storms, tornadoes and the occasional mystery light.

headline: At Home With Andre Dubus III
abstract: When the writer built a dream home for his family, he forgot to include one important thing: a place to write. So he found an unconventional solution.
lead_paragraph: When the writer built a dream home for his family, he forgot to include one important thing: a place to write. So he found an unconventional solution.

headline: Sprouts of Hope in a Gloomy Media Landscape
abstract: A handful of digital start-ups are finding success — so far, at least — by learning lessons from their troubled predecessors.
lead_paragraph: This year is looking grim for the news business.

headline: Hanging Out in the Boiler Room With Andre Dubus III
abstract: When the writer built a dream home for his family, he forgot to include one important thing: a place to write. So he found an unconventional solution.
lead_paragraph: The cedar-shingled house that Andre Dubus III built for his family in the seaside town of Newbury, Mass., has four levels that sprawl across 6,000 square feet, with plenty of rooms that could have made a nice writer’s office. But Mr. Dubus plies his trade down in the mechanical room, near the exercise equipment and the boiler, in a lofted space that he built himself out of plywood.

headline: A Biography of a Feminist Porn Pioneer Bares All
abstract: In “Candida Royalle and the Sexual Revolution,” the historian Jane Kamensky presents a raw personal — and cultural — history.
lead_paragraph: The idea on which Candida Royalle’s legend rests was as simple as it was brilliant. In 1984, the porn performer and eventual director-producer  co-founded Femme Productions with a single goal: to explore women’s fantasies. The hope of Royalle and partner Lauren Niemi was to change porn “from within,” as Royalle explained on a TV show, via “egalitarian” images portraying “regular, joyful lovemaking.”

headline: An Artist Who Aims to Be as Eclectic as a Tumblr Feed
abstract: Anthony Cudahy’s lush, figurative works are inspired, in equal parts, by news footage, family photographs and Renaissance paintings.
lead_paragraph: When the artist Anthony Cudahy, 34, was growing up in Fort Myers, Fla., he received plenty of encouragement from his mother, a painter herself. But he still yearned for creative peers, whom he found on the blogging site LiveJournal, on which he’d spend hours messaging with other artists. Even as his world expanded offline — he moved to Brooklyn in 2007 to study graphic design and illustration at Pratt Institute and later earned an M.F.A. in painting from Hunter College — the internet continued to inform his practice. “When I first started painting, I was thinking about the role of a painter as this collector of images, almost like you’re a Tumblr,” he says.

headline: Pharrell and Tyler, the Creator Remix a Classic Tote
abstract: The Louis Vuitton men’s creative director collaborated with the rapper to design a golf bag in the spirit of the brand’s 1930s Keepall.
lead_paragraph: THOUGH LOUIS VUITTON’S name is now synonymous with luxury fashion, his beginnings were remarkably humble: The designer was raised by his father, a farmer, and his mother, a milliner, in the rural town of Anchay in eastern France. In 1835, a 14-year-old Vuitton embarked — by foot — on a 280-mile, two-year pilgrimage to Paris, where he spent nearly two decades mastering the art of box making under the tutelage of a prominent malletier. Following his appointment as the official trunk maker for Napoleon III’s wife, Eugénie de Montijo, Vuitton opened his first luggage shop in 1854 near Place Vendôme, where he sold leather travel goods and canvas steamer trunks. Vuitton’s business was strong enough that in 1888, his only son, Georges, trademarked his now-signature checkerboard Damier print. The company’s steamer bag, which was intended to contain laundry on trans-Atlantic voyages, debuted in 1901; in the 1930s, the brand released the Keepall, a foldable tote, originally made from cotton canvas, that was small enough to be tucked into larger suitcases.

headline: ‘Shogun’ Episode 4 Recap: Fire Away
abstract: Lord Yabushige has managed to split his loyalties between Ishido and Toranaga. A play by younger lords will force his hand.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s episode dropped the ball when it came to depicting visceral combat. This week’s fired it straight at the enemy and pulped them.

headline: A 20-Year-Old Transcriber Is Turning Sheet Music Into Hot Content
abstract: George Collier started his YouTube channel as a way to stay engaged with music during the pandemic. Now nearly a million followers tune in for his notations.
lead_paragraph: For some budding musicians (and even old pros), the very sight of sheet music can elicit a fight-or-flight response, bringing up painful memories of strict piano teachers and high-pressure recitals. George Collier, a 20-year-old music transcriber, is doing his part to change that.

headline: 8 Video Games to Play Next
abstract: Journalists at The New York Times are enjoying role-playing games, roguelikes, Metroidvanias and extraction shooters.
lead_paragraph: Wondering what video game to play next? Get some inspiration from the games — long and short, new and old — that New York Times journalists have been enjoying. (Unless otherwise noted, these are available on the PC and all major consoles.)

headline: How to Parent in a World Under Siege?
abstract: In her elegant essay collection, “Lessons for Survival,” Emily Raboteau confronts climate collapse, societal breakdown and the Covid pandemic while trying to raise children in a responsible way.
lead_paragraph: Emily Raboteau’s “Lessons for Survival: Mothering Against ‘the Apocalypse’” opens with a touch of twisted wit. Pregnant with her first child and on the way to her baby shower, she glimpses a chalk message on a sidewalk sandwich board: “The end of the world is nigh!” The moment — an announcement of impending death colliding with a celebration of imminent birth — encapsulates the tensions that propel Raboteau’s book, a soulful exploration of the fraught experience of caretaking through crisis.

headline: Wegmans Fish Shop Stole My Concept, Merchant Claims
abstract: Sakanaya at the new Wegmans at Astor Place is involved in a legal dispute with a small shop, Osakana, that is a few blocks away.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at a small Manhattan fish market whose owner says the supermarket chain Wegmans copied his operation at a new store nearby. We’ll also get details on developments in some of the cases involving Donald Trump.

headline: ‘Age Is Not a Problem’
abstract: More old(er) models walked on the runways this season, marking a step in the right direction for age representation.
lead_paragraph: There were many head-turning moments at the Balmain show at Paris Fashion Week, which was a love letter by the creative director Olivier Rousteing to his childhood home of Bordeaux. There were twisted gold snail shells hanging from ears and as belt buckles; there were metal handbags cast into clusters of grapes, which were later served up on rhinestone-encrusted minidresses and strapless peplum bustiers.

headline: A Weekend in the Country, Roiled by a Kidnapping
abstract: Colin Barrett’s first novel, “Wild Houses,” follows young, desperate characters in small-town Ireland.
lead_paragraph: In Raymond Carver’s short story “Why Don’t You Dance?,” a man whose wife has left him places the entirety of their home on his front lawn, arranged as it was on the inside, as an act of defiant despair. A young couple, referred to only as the boy and the girl, come along and presume the man is holding a yard sale. They barter for the haunted detritus of a failed marriage, and later the girl senses what the boy never does — that their life together may one day mirror that of the man and his unseen ex-wife.

headline: See-Through Baseball Pants Have Fans, and Brands, Pointing Fingers
abstract: A redesign of M.L.B.’s uniforms has put Fanatics and Nike at the center of a debate about performance versus quality in sportswear.
lead_paragraph: At the end of this month, Major League Baseball will officially commence its 2024 season, and with spring training already in full swing, the chatter among hard-core fans and casual observers has been unusually spirited. In theory, that would be great for M.L.B. as it seeks to expand its reach amid a prolonged decline in the sport’s popularity and cultural cachet that was offset some with a series of popular rule changes last year.

headline: The Designer Who Makes Movie Posters Worthy of Museums
abstract: You’ve seen Dawn Baillie’s posters for thrillers, comedies and dramas outside cineplexes. Now her work is being exhibited at Poster House in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The killer’s knife, a woman cowering before it.

headline: What Popular Fitness Fads Get Wrong
abstract: Viral online exercise challenges, like the 75 Hard or the 12-3-20, might get you in shape in the short run, but they may not help you build sustainable healthy habits.
lead_paragraph: A new trending workout seems to emerge every month. Each guarantees a happier, healthier, stronger and leaner you.

headline: Jack Smith and Robert Hur Are the Latest Examples of a Failed Institution
abstract: The regulations for special counsels have failed to accomplish a key goal.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, when the special counsel Robert Hur testifies before Congress, it will be high presidential-year political theater. This is just the latest example of the inversion of the aims of the special counsel office.

headline: ‘Jamming’: How Electronic Warfare Is Reshaping Ukraine’s Battlefields
abstract: Drones have become a critical weapon for both sides, but a lack of coordination among troops has put Ukraine at a disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian soldier swore and tore off his headset. His video monitor had gone blurry at first, the landscape of shattered trees and shell craters barely visible, before blacking out completely. The Russians had jammed the signal of his drone as it was flying outside the town of Kreminna in eastern Ukraine.

headline: How Does a Tiny Mountain Town, Burned to the Ground, Come Back?
abstract: Lytton, British Columbia, used to draw backpackers, rafters and road-trippers until a wildfire destroyed it in 2021. Now, it’s a microcosm of how climate change is scrambling tourism.
lead_paragraph: Before the fire, Lytton, British Columbia, was the kind of tiny town visitors alighted upon mid-road trip, pulling off the Trans-Canada Highway to get a drink, or take in views of the Fraser and Thompson Rivers, running slate gray and deep blue more than 200 feet below. A mile up the road, also known as Highway 1, Kumsheen Rafting Resort drew 8,000 visitors annually to take half-day trips on raging rapids. Backpackers heading out on the Stein Valley Traverse stopped at the grocery store — known to locals as Ken Mart, after its owner, Ken Wong — to pick up rope, ramen and fuel before they hit the trail.

headline: I Used to Cringe at Self-Help Books. Until This One Changed My Life.
abstract: How a best-selling classic from 1992 helped me rediscover my creativity.
lead_paragraph: I have written about art my whole career. I find it and its creators endlessly fascinating, but I’ve always seen myself as something of a different kind — a journalist and critic, yes, but never an “artist,” with all the imaginative power that word conveys. Recently, though, I conducted a particularly poignant, intimate interview. The artist and I talked about childhood and the struggle of making oneself heard. There were tears. Afterward I had a thought: What would it be like if I were the one being interviewed? Could I be the artist, possessed of creative vision, like one of my subjects? The prospect was equally thrilling and terrifying.

headline: Is It Becoming More Acceptable for Men and Boys to Cry?
abstract: Did you watch Jason Kelce’s tearful retirement announcement? Tell us your reaction to seeing him and his brother, Travis, express their emotions so openly.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you shed tears in public? Afterward, how did you feel? Were you embarrassed by your display of emotion, or relieved? Did you feel judged?

headline: What Deathbed Visions Teach Us About Living
abstract: Researchers are documenting a phenomenon that seems to help the dying, as well as those they leave behind.
lead_paragraph: Chris Kerr was 12 when he first observed a deathbed vision. His memory of that summer in 1974 is blurred, but not the sense of mystery he felt at the bedside of his dying father. Throughout Kerr’s childhood in Toronto, his father, a surgeon, was too busy to spend much time with his son, except for an annual fishing trip they took, just the two of them, to the Canadian wilderness. Gaunt and weakened by cancer at 42, his father reached for the buttons on Kerr’s shirt, fiddled with them and said something about getting ready to catch the plane to their cabin in the woods. “I knew intuitively, I knew wherever he was, must be a good place because we were going fishing,” Kerr told me.

headline: Gaza Is Showing Us We Need New Tools to Measure Trauma
abstract: Diagnoses like PTSD aren’t sufficient.
lead_paragraph: As the physical toll of conflict mounts for Gazan civilians, so too does the emotional and psychological suffering. Yara M. Asi, an assistant professor at the University of Central Florida, believes that we need new language and ways to understand the depth of trauma currently faced by Palestinians in Gaza. In this audio essay, she argues that Western perspectives and diagnostics for mental health are insufficient for measuring and understanding the short- and long-term impact of sustained conflict on civilians.

headline: Subterranean ‘Baby Dragons’ Are Revealed to Sneak to the Surface
abstract: Scientists never imagined that the blind cave salamanders called olms willingly left their caves. But at numerous aboveground springs, there they were.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered that blind cave salamanders in northern Italy leave their underground homes to go on expeditions to the surface.

headline: Anti-Trump Group of Republicans Lays Out $50 Million Plan of Attack
abstract: The group, Republican Voters Against Trump, will run a series of homemade videos of Americans who voted for him in the past but say they can no longer do so in 2024.
lead_paragraph: A Republican group dedicated to opposing former President Donald J. Trump is planning to spend $50 million to stop him through a series of homemade testimonial videos of voters who backed him in past elections but say they can no longer support him in 2024.

headline: Senators Urge Biden to Stop Arming Israel, Citing Violation of U.S. Aid Law
abstract: An independent and seven Democrats argued in a letter that the administration had run afoul of a part of a law that bars military aid from going to any country that blocks humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: A group of Democratic senators urged President Biden on Monday to stop providing offensive weapons to Israel for the war against Hamas until it lifts restrictions on U.S.-backed humanitarian aid going into Gaza.

headline: On the Tripwire of a ‘Red Line,’ It’s Often Presidents Who Trip
abstract: Barack Obama drew one for Syria. George W. Bush drew several, for North Korea and Iran. Now President Biden has drawn one for Israel. The hard part is figuring out what to do when they are crossed.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden declared over the weekend that he was drawing a “red line” for Israel’s military action in Gaza, he appeared to be trying to raise the potential cost for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as their relationship plummets to new depths.

headline: Biden Offers ‘Ironclad’ Commitment to Allies, Defying Russia (and Trump)
abstract: The president hosted leaders of Poland at the White House as he sought to reassure NATO members of American steadfastness in the face of threats from Moscow and former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden pledged an “ironclad” commitment to America’s allies on Tuesday as he sought to reassure NATO members that the United States would not abandon its international obligations despite the threats of aggression by Russia and disruption by his all-but-certain fall election rival, former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Special Counsel Who Investigated Biden Offers Fierce Defense of Report
abstract: At a hearing, Republicans peppered Robert K. Hur about his justifications for not charging the president, and Democrats rebuked him for broad assertions about Mr. Biden’s memory.
lead_paragraph: Robert K. Hur, the special counsel who investigated President Biden, on Tuesday fiercely defended the disparaging assessment of the president’s mental state included in his final report — and his decision not to charge Mr. Biden with a crime.

headline: Mitch McConnell Doesn’t Wear a MAGA Hat. I’m Not Fooled.
abstract: The Senate minority leader may not like the former president, but he has done more for him than many other Republican leaders.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky announced that he would leave his position as Republican leader after the November elections. He’ll depart as the longest-serving party leader in the Senate’s history. He is also the longest-serving senator in Kentucky history.

headline: Is This What Happens When You Build a Real Social Safety Net, Then Take It Away?
abstract: Americans’ economic pessimism.
lead_paragraph: It’s a riddle that economists have struggled to decipher. The U.S. economy seems robust on paper, yet Americans are dissatisfied with it. But hardly anyone seems to have paid much attention to the whirlwind experience we just lived through: We built a real social safety net in the United States and then abruptly ripped it apart.

headline: What a Second Biden Term Would Look Like
abstract: How Biden’s pitch for 2024 — and beyond — has crystallized in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: President Biden gave a raucous State of the Union speech last Thursday, offering his pitch for why he should be president for a second term. It’s the clearest picture we have yet of Biden’s campaign message for 2024. But while he listed off all kinds of proposals, it’s not as easy to parse what a second Biden term might actually look like. So I sat down with my editor Aaron Retica, who had a lot of questions for me about the speech itself and what Biden would be likely to accomplish if he got another four years in the job.

headline: Inflation Ticked Up Last Month, Backing the Fed’s Caution on Rate Cuts
abstract: Consumer prices climbed 3.2 percent last month from a year earlier, down notably from a 9.1 percent high in 2022, but still quicker than the roughly 2 percent that was normal before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Inflation sped up slightly in February on an overall basis and a closely watched measure of underlying price increases was firmer than economists had expected.

headline: Insurance Costs Are Pushing Up Overall Inflation
abstract: Insurance costs are on the rise for various reasons, adding to overall inflation.
lead_paragraph: It is costing Americans more to protect against disaster, a development that is pushing up official inflation figures.

headline: Oregon Decriminalized Drugs. Voters Now Regret It.
abstract: State lawmakers are about to reverse course, making the possession of hard narcotics an offense again.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, motivated to try a different way to combat drug use, Oregon voted to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of hard drugs including fentanyl, heroin and methamphetamine.

headline: Biden’s Budget and Mass Layoffs at R.N.C.
abstract: Plus, a problem with M.L.B.’s new pants.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Convicting Politicians
abstract: As a bribery case against a U.S. senator moves forward, a look at why corruption charges are so hard to prove.
lead_paragraph: In the last decade, it has proved surprisingly hard to put politicians accused of corruption behind bars. Appeals courts have reversed several convictions. And juries have occasionally thought the officeholders’ behavior didn’t meet the high standard for corruption.

headline: Family Goes Missing After Heavy Rains Drench Western Australia
abstract: Seven people, including four children, haven’t been seen in more than a day after 5.5 inches of rain in 24 hours led to floods and closed roads.
lead_paragraph: Seven people are missing in Western Australia after swaths of the outback in the country’s largest and most sparsely populated state were drenched by more than 5.5 inches of rain in 24 hours over the weekend.

headline: Andrew Tate Can Be Extradited to Britain After Romanian Trial, Court Rules
abstract: Mr. Tate and his brother, Tristan, were arrested on charges made between 2012 and 2015, which include allegations of sexual aggression, a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Tate, the wealth-flaunting online influencer known for his misogynistic views, and his brother, Tristan, can be extradited to Britain to face sex crime charges after their trial in Romania concludes, the Bucharest Court of Appeal said on Tuesday.

headline: Citizenship Law That Excludes Muslims Takes Effect, India Says
abstract: The law sparked lethal riots when it was passed. Now, after a four-year delay, it has come into force on the eve of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before a national election, the Indian government has abruptly announced that it will begin enforcing a citizenship law that had remained dormant since late 2019 after inciting deadly riots by opponents who called it anti-Muslim.

headline: Tuxedos Stole the Show at This Year’s Oscars
abstract: And they were more than a fashion statement.
lead_paragraph: The Times reporter and critic Guy Trebay says the Oscars aren’t just about the awards people win that night. They’re also an opportunity for stars to use the red carpet for another kind of campaign.

headline: Hezbollah Fires More Than 100 Rockets Into Israel, Drawing Retaliation
abstract: The barrage by Hezbollah was among the heaviest in the months of cross-border strikes that have fed fears that the war in Gaza could expand.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets into northern Israel on Tuesday morning, according to Israel’s military. It was one of the heaviest barrages in the months of cross-border strikes that have fed fears that the war in Gaza could expand to another front.

headline: How the Special Counsel’s Portrayal of Biden’s Memory Compares With the Transcript
abstract: The special counsel, Robert K. Hur, accused the president last month of “significant” memory problems. The interview transcript offers context to his report.
lead_paragraph: A transcript of a special counsel’s hourslong interview of President Biden over his handling of classified files shows that on several occasions the president fumbled with dates and the sequence of events, while otherwise appearing clearheaded.

headline: The Clock Ticks for TikTok
abstract: Advertisers are sticking with the social media platform, even as the House prepares to vote on a bill to force the company to cut its China ties this week.
lead_paragraph: The warnings against TikTok aren’t letting up, with U.S. security officials saying China is using the platform to meddle in elections and lawmakers calling the video app a global threat.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Super Tuesday, Oscars, SAT
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: The Bay Area Leads the National Shift to Electric Vehicles
abstract: San Jose and San Francisco had the highest E.V. adoption rate among major U.S. metropolitan areas last year.
lead_paragraph: California has been leading the national shift toward electric vehicles. And the Bay Area has led California.

headline: In Hospitals, Affordable Housing Gets the Long-Term Investor It Needs
abstract: Health care systems and affordable housing developers have a mutual financial interest in helping communities live healthier.
lead_paragraph: Ce’Yann Irving, a mother of a 1-year-old daughter, pays $990 a month for a two-bedroom apartment on the site of a former dairy processing plant in the Central City neighborhood of New Orleans. She has amenities, like a 24-hour gym and an on-site community clinic, at arm’s reach.

headline: This 1,000-Year-Old Smartphone Just Dialed In
abstract: An 11th-century astrolabe, a complex instrument for precisely mapping the heavens, recently turned up in an Italian museum.

headline: Ukraine-Backed Russian Exile Groups Stage Assaults on Moscow’s Turf
abstract: The attacks and drone strikes across the southern border were intended to counter President Vladimir V. Putin’s control over Russia, a leader in one of the groups said.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine staged a flurry of cross-border ground attacks with tanks and other armored vehicles and long-range drone strikes into Russia on Tuesday, assaults that appeared aimed at disrupting President Vladimir V. Putin’s re-election campaign messaging that the war had turned in Moscow’s favor.

headline: Trump and Biden could formally clinch their parties’ nominations with Tuesday’s primaries.
abstract: There’s no question that President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will be their respective parties’ nominees, with neither facing any credible challengers, but Tuesday’s primaries could be the ones that make it official.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will be their respective parties’ nominees, with neither facing any credible challengers, but Tuesday’s primaries could be the ones that make it official.

headline: Washington State Will Be Next Test of ‘Uncommitted’ Protest Against Biden
abstract: The state’s primary election on Tuesday is the latest site of a movement to reject the president over his stance on Israel, though it may be days before the results are fully clear.
lead_paragraph: Washington State’s primary voters will offer the next glimpse of how many Democratic voters oppose President Biden’s policy toward Israel’s war in Gaza, though it may be days before a full picture of the results is clear.

headline: A Broadway-Bound ‘Sunset Boulevard’ Leads Olivier Award Nominations
abstract: The musical, starring Nicole Scherzinger, secured 11 nominations at Britain’s equivalent of the Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: A revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard,” starring Nicole Scherzinger as a former screen idol descending into madness, received the most nominations on Tuesday for this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.

headline: Who Are Hamas’s Top Leaders in Gaza?
abstract: Israel targeted Marwan Issa, a Hamas military leader, with a strike over the weekend. He is one of three leaders of the group in Gaza who Israel says were the main planners of the Oct. 7 attack.
lead_paragraph: Marwan Issa, who was the target of an Israeli strike in central Gaza over the weekend, is one of three leaders of Hamas in Gaza who Israel says were the main planners of the Oct. 7 attack, which killed over 1,200 people and led to the kidnapping of about 240 others, according to Israeli officials. It remained unclear on Tuesday whether the strike had hit him.

headline: What to Know About the Accusations Against Andrew Tate
abstract: The antagonistic online influencer is facing charges in two separate cases.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Tate, an online influencer known for his displays of wealth and his misogynistic views, is facing criminal accusations over sexual misconduct in two separate cases.

headline: Five Easy Dill Dinners
abstract: Ginger-dill salmon, skillet chicken with orzo, dill and feta and (frozen) fava bean stew are herbaceously springy.
lead_paragraph: Spring is so close I can taste it — or at least I’m trying to taste it, as I load up my grocery list with green things like arugula, scallions and leafy herbs. We’re still weeks away from peak spring produce, but you can hustle winter out the door if you lean heavily on ingredients that are available in March but are giving May.

headline: Smithsonian American Women’s History Museum Names New Director
abstract: Elizabeth C. Babcock, the chief executive of Forever Balboa Park, will start this summer, after Nancy Yao’s withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: Second time’s the charm?

headline: Audience Snapshot: Four Years After Shutdown, a Mixed Recovery
abstract: Covid brought live performance to a halt. Now the audience for pop concerts and sporting events has roared back, while attendance on Broadway and at some major museums is still down.
lead_paragraph: It was four years ago — on March 12, 2020 — that the coronavirus brought the curtain down on Broadway for what was initially supposed to be a monthlong shutdown, but which wound up lasting a year and a half.

headline: Airbnb Bans All Indoor Security Cameras
abstract: Widespread use of indoor security cameras has raised concerns about privacy in vacation rentals, hotels, public bathrooms, locker rooms and on cruise ships.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb said this week that it was banning the use of all indoor security cameras in its listings worldwide, an update to its current policy allowing the devices to be installed in common areas such as hallways and living rooms.

headline: She Trusted God and Science. They Both Failed Her.
abstract: In “Devout,” an author who grew up in the evangelical church recounts her struggle to find spiritual and psychological well-being after a mental health challenge.
lead_paragraph: In “Devout,” Anna Gazmarian writes of being given a Christmas present she found impossible to keep: a pendant necklace holding a tiny seed. It was a reference to the passage in Matthew where Jesus tells his apostles that faith the size of a mustard seed can move mountains.

headline: Dating Apps Have Hit a Wall. Can They Turn Things Around?
abstract: The apps have changed our love lives, but they haven’t been able to convince enough young users to pay.
lead_paragraph: As online dating became as easy as swiping a finger across your phone screen, the companies who own apps like Tinder and Bumble became Wall Street darlings. But about a decade later, those platforms are now struggling to live up to expectations, and investors have grown frustrated and eager for something new.

headline: Police Officers Used Stun Gun on Migrant Holding Toddler, Video Shows
abstract: The altercation occurred at a migrant shelter in Queens following a dispute between the man and a shelter employee. New York City officials are investigating.
lead_paragraph: Update: After this article was published, several migrant families were moved out of the shelter.

headline: Biden Budget Lays Out Economic Battle Lines Against Trump
abstract: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump offer vastly different policy paths on almost every aspect of the economy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden in his budget this week staked out major economic battle lines with former President Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee. The proposal offers the nation a glimpse of the diverging directions that retirement programs, taxes, trade and energy policy could take depending on the outcome of the November election.

headline: How Education and Experience Can Help Prisoners Achieve Parole
abstract: Responses to a guest essay about the plight of the older incarcerated. Also: Close call on Jan. 6; the killing of innocents; the purpose of college.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: David Mixner, Fierce Fighter for Gay Rights, Is Dead at 77
abstract: He persuaded Ronald Reagan to help defeat a proposed ban on L.G.B.T.Q. schoolteachers in California in 1978, and he sparred with his friend Bill Clinton over “don’t ask, don’t tell.”
lead_paragraph: David B. Mixner, a political strategist who played prominent roles in the anti-Vietnam War movement and in the arduous fight for gay rights, and whose decades-long influence with Bill Clinton spanned both eras, died on Monday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Bitcoin’s Winning Streak Continues
abstract: The cryptocurrency has recently set a series of records, extending a rapid rally that has emboldened the virtual currency industry to flex its political muscle.
lead_paragraph: The price of Bitcoin hovered around $72,000 on Tuesday, extending a rally that has helped mint a new crop of crypto billionaires.

headline: Kenya Hits Pause on Police Deployment to Haiti
abstract: The African nation said it would not send a force until Haiti forms a new government after the Haitian prime minister announced his intention to resign.
lead_paragraph: A deployment of 1,000 Kenyan police officers to Haiti to help quell gang-fueled lawlessness is on hold until a new government is formed in the Caribbean nation, officials in Kenya said Tuesday, as leaders tried to figure out a difficult question: Who is going to run Haiti?

headline: For Some Mammals, Large Adult Daughters, Not Sons, Are the Norm
abstract: Despite a common narrative that male mammals tend to dwarf female ones, fewer than half of mammalian species display that pattern, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Female elephant seals are not delicate creatures. They are rippling tubes of muscle and blubber that can weigh more than 1,000 pounds. Still, female elephant seals are absolutely dwarfed by their male counterparts, which are typically at least three times heavier.

headline: U.S.-Israeli Citizen Itay Chen Was Killed in Oct. 7 Attack, Parents Say
abstract: Ruby and Hagit Chen said that they expected the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and President Biden to do “everything in their power” to bring Itay’s remains and the hostages home.
lead_paragraph: Itay Chen, a 19-year-old U.S. and Israeli citizen thought to have been taken hostage on Oct. 7, was in fact killed that day, his parents said on Tuesday.

headline: An Artist’s Response to a Racist Mural Walks a Fine Line
abstract: Activists urged Tate Britain to take an offensive artwork from 1927 off its walls, but the museum instead commissioned Keith Piper to create a response.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 100 years, a 55-foot-long mural was the backdrop to a high-class restaurant at Tate Britain. As diners quaffed fine wine and ate expensive dishes, they could glance at the painting by Rex Whistler depicting a hunting party riding through a fantastical landscape.

headline: Republicans Can’t Restructure North Carolina Election Boards, Judges Rule
abstract: A panel made up of two Republicans and one Democrat ruled that a law passed last year to change the makeup of election boards is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan panel of three judges in North Carolina ruled that a Republican-led effort in the state legislature to restructure state and county election boards is unconstitutional.
