The 136-acre La Villette Park, with concert halls, museums, theaters, event spaces and other cultural venues, is less than 10 minutes away on foot. A comparable walk in the other direction arrives at the Bassin de la Villette, the largest artificial lake in Paris, and a bohemian area offering shops, restaurants and bars, boating and other attractions.

headline: Thinking of Driving in Manhattan This Weekend? Think Again.
abstract: The St. Patrick’s Day Parade and Half Marathon will tie up traffic on Saturday and Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at why this will be a weekend to love or to hate, depending on where you are going and how you plan to get there. We’ll also get details on a request to delay Donald Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan.

headline: What the Fight Over the Capital One-Discover Merger Misses About Our Terrible Credit Card System
abstract: The deal will do nothing to fix policies that exacerbate the wealth gap and help big business get even bigger.
lead_paragraph: A fight has commenced over Capital One’s effort to acquire Discover, a deal that would birth an enormous credit card company rivaling Visa, Mastercard and American Express. The resulting competition could, in the short run, lower some costs to businesses and consumers. However, over the longer term, the merger would keep intact the broken and predatory system in which credit card companies profit handsomely by rewarding our richest Americans and advantaging the biggest corporations.

headline: What Do You Do if You Hate Both Biden and Trump?
abstract: It’s the election of our discontent.
lead_paragraph: Many voters from both parties are less than enthusiastic about their likely options this November.

headline: New York Is Wilder Than You Think
abstract: The city is a flourishing ecosystem of untamed creatures.
lead_paragraph: New York is about to get really wild. Every spring, millions of birds fly from South and Central America along the Atlantic Flyway, heading for northern breeding grounds. Many of them choose to fly through New York City, sometimes stopping to rest in Central Park. You can take the subway to 81st Street, stroll across the way and maybe see a maraschino-cherry-red male scarlet tanager with black wings, fresh from the foothills of the Andes.

headline: An American Who Has Helped Clear 815,000 Bombs From Vietnam
abstract: Chuck Searcy has spent decades of his life redressing a deadly legacy of America’s war in Vietnam: unexploded ordnance.
lead_paragraph: On a visit to the former battlefield of Khe Sanh, scene of one of the bloodiest standoffs of the Vietnam War, the only people Chuck Searcy encountered on the broad, barren field were two young boys who led him to an unexploded rocket lying by a ditch.

headline: There’s an Art to Arranging a Bookshelf. Here’s How It’s Done.
abstract: Jeremiah Brent, the newest cast member of Netflix’s “Queer Eye,” shows how he styles the shelves in the home he shares with his husband, Nate Berkus.
lead_paragraph: In a public library, styling a bookshelf is easy: Just fill it with books. At home, a bookcase needs to do a lot more than hold books.

headline: Are You Tired of Influencers?
abstract: Do you trust the product recommendations you see on social media? Or are you increasingly skeptical of people trying to sell you stuff online?
lead_paragraph: Are influencers all over your social media feed? How do you feel when you come across videos or photos of product recommendations, “hauls” and “unboxings,” or when creators direct you to their TikTok shops and Amazon storefronts?

headline: ‘Dune: The Popcorn Bucket’ Has a Surprise Ending
abstract: What’s in the $24.99 tub, exactly? Lindsay Moyer, a nutritionist, reviews the contents of the movie-snack “vessel.”
lead_paragraph: In the “Dune” movies, a gigantic sandworm can rise from the desert and devour soldiers and military vehicles in its gaping maw. In real life, humans watching movies devour popcorn. These two ideas have been combined to spawn the “Dune” popcorn bucket, a sandworm-shaped tub that is having a cultural moment. The bucket arrives on the heels of other recent popcorn collectibles, like the 16-inch Barbie Corvette snack holder. But is there more to these vessels than meets the eye?

headline: Making a Scene on the Radio
abstract: In an era of podcasts and influencers, Montez Press Radio is reviving the D.I.Y. spirit of a bygone downtown New York City.
lead_paragraph: “Do you think about your organs, Timmy?” asked Moriah Evans, an experimental choreographer. “How often do you commit yourself to trying to sense the bodies within your body?”

headline: Kacey Musgraves Finds Inner Peace on Her New Album
abstract: Our music critic reviews “Deeper Well.”
lead_paragraph: Our chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles, says Kacey Musgraves’s fifth album of original songs, “Deeper Well,” finds the artist ready to place the youthful mistakes of her past behind her for a quieter, more contented sound. He describes the new songs as “pared down and understated,” and says they are “about finding wonder and gratitude in personal connections and in nature.” Here are some of his favorite tracks from the album.

headline: How to Style Bookshelves: Jeremiah Brent’s Dos and Don’ts
abstract: Interior designer Jeremiah Brent offers guidance on how to style bookshelves.
lead_paragraph: Interior designer Jeremiah Brent offers guidance on how to style bookshelves.

headline: As Putin Pitches His Vision, Voters Avert Their Gaze From the War
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin, casting himself as the only leader able to end the war in Ukraine, is all but assured another term in a rubber-stamp election this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir V. Putin’s vision of Russia — successful, innovative and borderless — is on display at one of Moscow’s biggest tourist attractions, a Stalin-era exhibition center that currently houses a sleek showcase called Russia 2024. The exhibition promotes what the Kremlin portrays as Russia’s achievements in the past two decades, roughly the period Mr. Putin has been in power, and his promises for the future after he secures another six-year term in rubber-stamp elections this weekend.

headline: Gene Wilder and Frida Kahlo in Their Own Words (for Better and Worse)
abstract: These documentaries draw us in by giving the sense that we’re getting the story straight from the artists. But we’re not always getting the full picture.
lead_paragraph: Famous artists are a favorite subject for documentaries right now — probably because people love to watch them. And there are a lot of different ways to tell the story of someone’s life; the more famous they were, the more tools at the filmmaker’s fingertips.

headline: Deadly Foosball, Nefarious Pool Guys and the Loony Musings of ‘Valley Heat’
abstract: Christian Duguay’s podcast purports to be about the neighbors in the Rancho Equestrian District of Burbank. One thing is for sure: It’s masterfully absurd.
lead_paragraph: In the Rancho Equestrian District of Burbank, Calif., they take foosball seriously — and those who don’t, well, they might get their thumbs broken. Or worse. Foosball is life or death there, but mostly death, or at least it can seem that way on “Valley Heat,” a deliriously deadpan fictional podcast about this real neighborhood that delights in ludicrous lore and nonsense.

headline: Who Has the Secret to Well-Being? The Answer May Surprise You.
abstract: Toddlers — full of energy, curiosity and laughter — have a lot to teach adults, experts say.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to happiness and living well, we can learn a lot from toddlers.

headline: Dressing the Part of Barbara Walters
abstract: Women in media recently had a chance to browse and buy clothes owned by the trailblazing TV news anchor.
lead_paragraph: If anyone could make a baby pink suit look intimidating, it was Barbara Walters. The TV news anchor coolly lobbed questions at the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a 1989 interview while sheathed shoulder to knee in pastel Chanel and pearls.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Kacey Musgraves's new album, “Deeper Well.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Kacey Musgraves's new album, “Deeper Well.”

headline: Don’t Think of It as a Contest Between Biden and Trump
abstract: What matters even more than the candidates is the coalitions they lead.
lead_paragraph: It’s official — we have a rematch.

headline: A Looming TikTok Ban, a Royal Photoshop Mystery and Your Snitching Car
abstract: Maybe go ahead and download your favorite TikToks.
lead_paragraph: This week, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a bill that would ban TikTok if its Chinese-owned parent company, ByteDance, doesn’t sell it off. We talk about why, what happens next, and how likely it is that the app will be banned. Then, how a photoshopped image of Kate Middleton undermines trust in photography. And finally, a new report reveals how your car may be tracking you without your knowledge — and how that might raise your insurance bill.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 15, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Why Is Congress Investigating a Union for Being Anti-Israel?
abstract: Republicans issue a subpoena over a resolution condemning the Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: Like many progressive organizations, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys, a union that represents public defenders in the New York City area, has been convulsed by battles over Israel’s war in Gaza. A recent article in the right-leaning Free Press revealed the strident and sometimes ugly language that union members used during a fight over a resolution, passed in December, condemning Israel’s actions and supporting a boycott of the country. In messages from a group chat, defenders of Israel were called “fascists” and, in one case, “mentally disturbed.”

headline: White House Calls on Republicans to End Biden Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The president’s counsel told Speaker Mike Johnson that it was “obviously time to move on,” citing G.O.P. lawmakers’ own doubts about the impeachment bid.
lead_paragraph: The White House insisted on Friday that House Republicans end their effort to impeach President Biden, declaring that “enough is enough” after their monthslong inquiry failed to turn up promised evidence of high crimes and misdemeanors.

headline: ‘The Regime’ and the Dictators I Have Known
abstract: The HBO show is set in a fictional European country, but The Times’s chief diplomatic correspondent recognizes references to many real despots and failed states.
lead_paragraph: “The Regime,” the oddball limited series from HBO, is like a teenager’s dream of dictatorship. In the lengthy and sometimes ponderous tale of an unnamed country in “Middle Europe,” there are various references, more literary than lived, to the top authoritarian hits of the last 50 years.

headline: A Journey Through Putin’s Russia
abstract: Our Moscow-based reporter traveled around the country to gauge the mood before a presidential vote.
lead_paragraph: Russians go to the polls today in the first presidential election since their country invaded Ukraine two years ago.

headline: Trump’s Court Delays Pile Up, and Schumer Says Netanyahu ‘Lost His Way’
abstract: Plus, the chaos in college financial aid.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Proposes Reducing Americans’ Workweek to 32 Hours
abstract: His proposal would pare down the workweek over a four-year period. The 40-hour workweek has stood as the standard in the U.S. since it became enshrined in federal law in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders this week unveiled legislation to reduce the standard workweek in the United States from 40 hours to 32, without a reduction in pay, saying Americans are working longer hours for less pay despite advances in technology and productivity.

headline: What Groups Need Affirmative Action?
abstract: The demise of the old version of affirmative action is likely to affect some of its previous beneficiaries much more than others.
lead_paragraph: Two economists — Ran Abramitzky of Stanford and Leah Boustan of Princeton — embarked on an ambitious project more than a decade ago. They wanted to know how the trajectory of immigrants to the United States had changed since the 1800s. To do so, Abramitzky and Boustan collected millions of tax filings, census records and other data and analyzed upward mobility over time.

headline: A Potentially Hazardous Cat Puts a Japanese City on Alert
abstract: The animal fell into a tank of chemicals at a plating factory in Fukuyama and then wandered off into the night.
lead_paragraph: The first signs of an intruder at the metal-plating factory were footprints, ocher-tinged and varying in number of toes. A review of security footage confirmed the security breach, and the authorities quickly issued a public alert.

headline: The Big Dilemma Facing ByteDance’s U.S. Investors
abstract: Potential bidders are circling TikTok as many in Congress demand its split from its Chinese parent. But obstacles remain, starting with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: As Beijing makes it increasingly clear that it opposes efforts by Congress to force TikTok’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance, to sell the popular video app — government officials in China said American lawmakers were acting like a “bandit” — the tech giant’s U.S. backers are increasingly finding themselves in a quandary.

headline: Data Dump Exposes the Fuzzy Lines Between Money and Politics in India
abstract: Lists of donors and beneficiaries cast government contracts and police investigations in an unflattering new light.
lead_paragraph: Politics in India is an expensive business, and sometimes lucrative, too. In this year’s election, parties are expected to spend more than $14 billion — as much as in the United States. But there has been little in the way of transparency for the huge sums sloshing around.

headline: If Nvidia Keeps Rising Like This, It Will Be Bigger Than the Global Economy
abstract: A.I. fervor has rocketed the chip company’s share price upward. Our columnist asked A.I. chatbots how big Nvidia would become if it kept growing as fast as it had over the past year.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a household name quite yet, but anyone who follows the stock market knows at least a little about Nvidia.

headline: How a Tiny Arts Center Is Helping a Rural County Heal After Wildfires
abstract: The Middletown Art Center in Lake County has turned into a “focal point for the area’s resilience and growth,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: Just north of Napa Valley, famous for its picture-perfect wineries and inviting restaurants, is a California county with a far less flattering reputation.

headline: Closing Costs for Buying a Home Have Risen Along With Rates
abstract: These mortgage fees increased 22 percent from 2021 to 2022. One likely factor is the greater use of discount points to nudge interest rates down.
lead_paragraph: A pricey housing market and higher interest rates have made it harder to afford a house, but related expenses known as closing costs also add to the home-buying challenge.

headline: What China Is Saying About the TikTok Furor in Washington
abstract: A bill to force TikTok’s sale in the United States has been criticized by Beijing but has not triggered a high-alert public response or retaliation.
lead_paragraph: This is not the first time that China has seen a frenzy over TikTok consume Washington.

headline: This Treasure Hunter’s Latest Find? A 1,000-Year-Old Viking Sword.
abstract: Trevor Penny was magnet fishing in an English waterway near Oxford when he pulled out a rusty sword. Experts say it’s a Viking sword that is probably more than 1,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: The long, thin piece of metal looked like a scaffolding pole when Trevor Penny saw it on the banks of an English river last November.

headline: What We Know About the Relationship Between the Trump Prosecutors
abstract: Defense lawyers accused Fani Willis of “self-dealing” by hiring Nathan Wade to manage the Trump prosecution, then going on vacations with him that he paid for, at least in part.
lead_paragraph: The allegations of a romance between Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, and Nathan J. Wade first emerged in a January filing by Ashleigh Merchant, a lawyer for Michael Roman, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants in Georgia.

headline: Read the Judge’s Decision on Disqualification in the Trump Case
abstract: Read the ruling by Judge Scott McAfee.
lead_paragraph: Read the ruling by Judge Scott McAfee.

headline: Schumer’s Critique of Netanyahu Reveals a Growing Gap, Analysts Say
abstract: Many Israelis support the Senate majority leader’s call for early elections, but even Netanyahu’s rivals were reluctant to seize on the criticism while the country is focused on the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer’s harsh critique of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government revealed the widening gap between Israel and its most important ally, the United States, analysts said on Friday, but was unlikely to prompt Israel’s government to chart a new course.

headline: Beach Town Residents Paid $600,000 for Sand. It Lasted a Few Days.
abstract: Residents who live on Salisbury Beach, a seaside community in northern Massachusetts, paid for the sand dunes to protect their beachfront homes from storms. Then a storm came.
lead_paragraph: The owners of beachfront homes in the seaside community of Salisbury Beach in northern Massachusetts spent nearly $600,000 to have around 15,000 tons of sand dropped near their properties to protect themselves from future storms.

headline: Disqualification Isn’t the Only Threat to Fani Willis’s Prosecution
abstract: The Fulton County district attorney faces a series of inquiries that could perpetuate uncertainty about the Trump case for months to come.
lead_paragraph: A special committee of the Georgia State Senate held a hearing last week into accusations of misconduct by the Fulton County district attorney, Fani T. Willis, making it clear that the effort to disqualify her from the prosecution of Donald J. Trump is not the only threat to her case against the former president.

headline: 4 Ways a Settlement Could Change the Housing Industry
abstract: The influential National Association of Realtors agreed to make several changes to its policies to settle class-action lawsuits brought by home sellers who say they were forced to pay inflated commissions to real estate agents.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Friday morning, the National Association of Realtors agreed to a global settlement deal that would resolve several lawsuits against the trade group.

headline: Powerful Realtor Group Agrees to Slash Commissions to Settle Lawsuits
abstract: The National Association of Realtors will pay $418 million in damages and will amend several rules that housing experts say will drive down housing costs.
lead_paragraph: American homeowners could see a significant drop in the cost of selling their homes after a real estate trade group agreed to a landmark deal that will eliminate a bedrock of the industry, the standard 6 percent sales commission.

headline: Here’s How the Decision in the Trump Case Could Be Appealed
abstract: The defendants could ask the judge to go straight to an appeals court before trial, delaying the prosecution of the former president and his allies.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump and his co-defendants in Georgia could appeal a judge’s decision allowing Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, to remain on the election interference case. But it will be up to the judge whether their appeal could go forward right away, or if it would have to wait until after a trial.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Eleanor Catton, Catherine Lacey, Ilyon Woo and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Eleanor Catton, Catherine Lacey, Ilyon Woo and more.

headline: The Obstacles to Buying Your First Home
abstract: The rate of homeownership continues to lag among Black, Latino, Asian American and Native American people, compared with America’s white population.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: A Columbia Surgeon’s Study Was Pulled. He Kept Publishing Flawed Data.
abstract: The quiet withdrawal of a 2021 cancer study by Dr. Sam Yoon highlights scientific publishers’ lack of transparency around data problems.
lead_paragraph: The quiet withdrawal of a 2021 cancer study by Dr. Sam Yoon highlights scientific publishers’ lack of transparency around data problems.

headline: Macron and Scholz Meet, Looking to Patch Up Differences on Ukraine
abstract: The leaders of France and Germany tried to heal an increasingly public rift over their approach to the war, holding talks alongside Poland’s prime minister on support for Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Berlin on Friday looking to smooth over their differences on how to support Ukraine in its war with Russia and allay concerns that the Franco-German “engine of Europe” is sputtering.

headline: What’s the Best ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Strategy?
abstract: For 40 years, contestants on “Wheel of Fortune,” the TV game show staple, have hoped to reach the final puzzle, called the bonus round. A correct guess can mean a new car, $40,000 or even $1 million.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years, contestants on “Wheel of Fortune,” the TV game show staple, have hoped to reach the final puzzle, called the bonus round. A correct guess can mean a new car, $40,000 or even $1 million.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: TikTok was a big topic this week for the late-night hosts, as a bill to force the app’s sale made its way through the U.S. legislature. The hosts also discussed last Sunday’s Oscars. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: TikTok was a big topic this week for the late-night hosts, as a bill to force the app’s sale made its way through the U.S. legislature. The hosts also discussed last Sunday’s Oscars. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Once You Watch an Ernie Gehr Film, You’ll Never See the World the Same Way
abstract: A MoMA series shows how the artist pushes the boundaries of cinema in short movies that both delight and baffle.
lead_paragraph: Movies have been around for well over a century, and for roughly half that time, the American filmmaker Ernie Gehr has — playfully, thoughtfully, beautifully — shown us just how far out, exciting and liberating they can be.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Time loops in Japan, a seductive interface for agoraphobes and artificial intelligence battles make up this month’s science fiction streaming picks.
lead_paragraph: Rent or buy it on most major platforms.

headline: Make Guinness Beef Stew on Saturday for Sunday
abstract: That way the flavors have time to deepen in the fridge, with plenty of celery root, carrots and parsnips, and lemon juice to make it pop.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you doing? This week marks four years since many of us went into lockdown after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus to be a pandemic. Amid the fear and illness there would turn out to be, for some, scant pleasures: fragrant, crusty sourdough boules, long walks on quiet streets, seeking beauty amid the darkness. But for many there was simply dread, dread unending, and only pantry meals to mark the passage of time.

headline: Senegal’s Leading Opposition Politicians Freed From Jail Just Before Election
abstract: The presidential candidate of the main opposition party, as well as its powerful founder, was released 10 days before the West African country is set to hold a national election.
lead_paragraph: Two opposition party politicians were released from jail in Senegal on Thursday night, just 10 days before a nationwide election in which one of them is running for president.

headline: Soho House Seeks to Knock Back Its Critics
abstract: The members club operator disclosed improving financial results as it faces criticism from a short seller and weighs going private again.
lead_paragraph: Since going public nearly two years ago, the members club chain Soho House has endured a sharp decline in its stock price, economic turmoil and a short seller’s declaring that its shares are worthless.

headline: Highlights of the Judge’s Decision in the Georgia Trump Case
abstract: The district attorney, Fani T. Willis, was given two choices: have her ex-boyfriend withdraw from the prosecution team or step aside herself.
lead_paragraph: A judge overseeing the criminal election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump in Georgia declined on Friday to disqualify the district attorney leading the prosecution, Fani T. Willis, over a romantic relationship she had with the lawyer she hired to manage the case, Nathan J. Wade.

headline: Russian Missile Strikes Kill at Least 20 in Odesa, Ukraine Says
abstract: Two missiles hit the same spot, Ukrainian authorities said, killing some rescuers who had responded to the first attack.
lead_paragraph: A Russian missile attack on Odesa killed at least 20 people and injured 73 others, Ukrainian authorities said on Friday, the latest in a series of deadly air assaults on the southern Ukrainian port city.

headline: First Ship Carrying Food Aid Arrives in Gaza
abstract: The ship, the Open Arms, carried some 200 metric tons of rice, flour and other food from Cyprus. It is seen as a pilot effort for a new maritime aid corridor.
lead_paragraph: A humanitarian aid ship arrived on Friday in Gaza for the first time since the start of the war, a first step in a fledgling maritime operation to bring more aid to hungry Palestinians as aid groups say that Israel is restricting more efficient deliveries by road.

headline: Where’s the Next Generation of Great Coaches?
abstract: A trip back to 2004 suggests even sure things can sometimes be a gamble.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years, it would appear, is a very long time indeed. This week, a brief video montage fluttered through the flotsam and jetsam that clog my (and your) social media feeds — the engagement-farming banalities, the craven attention-seekers, the willfully deranged Kate Middleton theories — to celebrate the glorious madness of 2004.

headline: When Debuts Flop: Katie Britt Is the Latest in a Long Line of Botched Opening Acts
abstract: The Republican senator, whose State of the Union response drew savage criticism, is not the first novice lawmaker from the South to see her introductory event veer off the rails.
lead_paragraph: Senator Katie Britt, Republican of Alabama, had not finished delivering her breathless, overly dramatized and fact-challenged response to President Biden’s State of the Union address last week when the ridicule and criticism began pouring in from Republicans and Democrats alike.

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole in Search of a Few Frames of Irish American History
abstract: The silent film “The Callahans and the Murphys” was pulled after an uproar over stereotyping. What happened next tantalized one fan of old movies.
lead_paragraph: One moment I am sprawled on a couch in my New Jersey home, lost in another classic old movie. The next, I am falling through the floorboards and tumbling like Alice into the wondrous unknown, only to land in a bunkerlike government structure built into the side of a Virginia mountain.

headline: Man Who Shot Another on Subway Train Unlikely to Be Charged, D.A. Says
abstract: Evidence indicates that a 32-year-old man acted in self-defense when he shot a man with whom he had been fighting on a moving A train, Brooklyn’s top prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: A 32-year-old man who took a gun from a second man and shot him in the head during an altercation on a moving A train Thursday evening appears to have acted in self-defense and will not be criminally charged for now, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Friday.

headline: The Big Number: $40 Billion
abstract: The market values of Match Group and Bumble have tumbled since 2021.
lead_paragraph: The market values of Match Group and Bumble have tumbled since 2021.

headline: AMC Theaters, Looking for Movies, Turns to Blumhouse
abstract: The theater chain and the entertainment company are teaming up for a five-day festival of old horror films in 40 cities, compensating for a lack of new films.
lead_paragraph: For five days starting on March 29, people who buy tickets to certain movies at certain AMC Theaters will see video messages starring … Jason Blum?

headline: Netanyahu calls Hamas’s demands ‘ludicrous’ and proceeds with plans for a ground invasion in Rafah.
abstract: The Israeli prime minister rejected the latest cease-fire deal proposed by Hamas, but signaled he was open to more talks.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Friday rejected the latest cease-fire deal proposed by Hamas, calling its demands “ludicrous,” and said Israel would move forward with plans for a ground offensive in Rafah, the southern Gazan city where more than half the enclave’s population is sheltering.

headline: U.S. and Allies Warn Iran Not to Send Missiles to Russia
abstract: The Group of 7 major industrial powers threatened “significant measures” against Tehran if it aids Moscow’s war against Ukraine, including a cutoff of Iran Air flights to Europe.
lead_paragraph: The United States and six other major world powers warned Iran on Friday not to provide ballistic missiles to Russia to aid Moscow’s war against Ukraine and threatened to retaliate if it does by cutting off Iranian air travel to Europe, among other measures.

headline: Supreme Court Sets Rules for Blocking Citizens From Officials’ Accounts
abstract: In two unanimous rulings, the justices tried to distinguish between private conduct, which is not subject to the First Amendment, and state action, which is.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, in a pair of unanimous decisions on Friday, added some clarity to a vexing constitutional puzzle: how to decide when elected officials violate the First Amendment by blocking people from their social media accounts.

headline: ‘Welcome to Hell’: U.N. Panel Says Russian War Crimes Are Widespread
abstract: In a report headed to the Human Rights Council in Geneva next week, an investigative commission outlines the ongoing torture and starvation of Ukrainian prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, United Nations investigators say they have uncovered new evidence of systematic and widespread torture of Ukrainian prisoners held by Russian security forces.

headline: Overlooked No More: Miriam Solovieff, Lauded Violinist Who Suffered Tragedy
abstract: She led a successful career despite coping with a horrific event that she witnessed at 18: the killing of her mother and sister at the hands of her father.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Welcome to the London Book Fair, Where Everyone Knows Their Place
abstract: If you want to understand the power map of the publishing industry, just look at this event’s floor plan.
lead_paragraph: Everybody knows that the publishing industry is a rigorously stratified world, characterized by a reverence for hierarchy and a near-fanatical observance of ritual. Or maybe we suspect as much — but for those who would like to have those beliefs starkly confirmed, I would recommend a visit to the London Book Fair, which took place in the city’s Kensington district this week.

headline: Thomas Adès Takes a Step Toward the Classical Music Canon
abstract: As Adès premieres an orchestral work, “The Exterminating Angel” is receiving something rare in contemporary opera: a new production.
lead_paragraph: Pity living composers, toiling away in a field that has long favored dead ones. If they get a precious commission, the cycle tends to go something like this: The work premieres, and then travels to any other ensemble or company that helped to pay for it. After that, who knows. The fate of contemporary music typically comes down to marketability — hits still exist! — and to that strange, slippery thing called legacy.

headline: How Revelations of a Prosecutors’ Romance Upended the Georgia Trump Case
abstract: A timeline of when the relationship between Fani Willis and Nathan Wade came to light, and how defense lawyers used it to attack the prosecutors.
