abstract: A struggle for a position held by Ukrainian forces in the eastern city of Avdiivka underlines how the conflict is increasingly being fought in close-quarter combat.
lead_paragraph: The two Ukrainian soldiers were trapped. After repelling waves of Russian attempts to storm their small bunker in a cellar near an abandoned house, the enemy was on top of them.

headline: We Spent Months With India’s Sugar Cutters. Here’s What We Found.
abstract: Indebted workers, facing brutal working conditions, are pushed to get hysterectomies as a treatment for routine ailments. Sugar mills disclaim responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Women who cut sugar cane in the Indian state of Maharashtra are getting unnecessary hysterectomies, often as a way to keep working, undistracted by periods, pregnancies or gynecological checkups.

headline: Senegal Votes in an Election That Almost Didn’t Happen
abstract: The top opposition politician, Ousmane Sonko, is barred from running. So Sunday’s vote is widely seen as a choice between his handpicked candidate and the departing president’s designated successor.
lead_paragraph: She had badgered her friends and family to persuade them to vote for a major change of government. And on Friday, Aminata Faye, 22, stood at the front of a stadium in Senegal, in the city of Mbour, waiting to hear the opposition politician who had inspired her — and his presidential candidate — in the last stop in a breakneck campaign.

headline: ISIS-K, Group Tied to Moscow Attack, Has Grown Bolder and More Violent
abstract: The militant group violently opposes the Taliban leaders of Afghanistan, where it is based. It is increasingly targeting foreign foes.
lead_paragraph: Few know better than the Taliban what a relentless foe the Islamic State’s affiliate in Afghanistan can be.

headline: The Brutality of Sugar: Debt, Child Marriage and Hysterectomies
abstract: An investigation into the sugar-cane industry in the Indian state of Maharashtra found workers ensnared by debt and pushed into child marriages and unnecessary hysterectomies.
lead_paragraph: The two soft-drink makers have helped turn the state of Maharashtra into a sugar-producing powerhouse. But a New York Times and Fuller Project investigation has found that these brands have also profited from a brutal system of labor that exploits children and leads to the unnecessary sterilization of working-age women.

headline: China’s Dispute With Taiwan Is Playing Out Near This Frontline Island
abstract: A fatal episode off Kinmen, a Taiwanese-controlled island, has become the latest occasion for Beijing to warn and test Taiwan’s president-elect.
lead_paragraph: A small island controlled by Taiwan a few miles off China’s coast lived for decades in constant readiness for war. At one point in 1958, troops there hunkered in bunkers as Communist forces rained hundreds of thousands of shells on them.

headline: When It Comes to Politics, Are Any of Us Really Thinking for Ourselves?
abstract: Demography often determines what you believe.
lead_paragraph: If you’re trying to guess whether people are Republicans or Democrats, knowing a few basic facts about them will take you a long way. What’s their race and gender? How far did they get in school? What part of the country do they live in and is their community urban, suburban or rural?

headline: Corrections: March 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz misidentified Charles Elson. He is a former director of the John L. Wein­berg Center for Corporate Govern­ance at the University of Delaware, not its current director.

headline: China’s Plan to Spur Growth: A New Slogan for Building Factories
abstract: As China’s leaders promote their strategy, other countries worry about manufacturing overcapacity and plans for more exports.
lead_paragraph: From the top of the government, China is heavily promoting a plan to fix the country’s stagnant economy and offset the harm from a decades-long housing bubble.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 41 Days in a Bunker: ‘How Much Can One Person Endure?’
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, March 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I made a decision for myself: Either I leave now, or we both die. I even thought that if I came out and they shot me there, at least it would be quick rather than dying of hunger or thirst.”

headline: Patients Hate ‘Forever’ Drugs. Is Wegovy Different?
abstract: The new obesity drugs might be an exception to a chronic, deadly problem: the failure to stick with medication.
lead_paragraph: Most people, study after study shows, don’t take the medicines prescribed for them. It doesn’t matter what they are — statins, high blood pressure drugs, drugs to lower blood sugar, asthma drugs. Either patients never start taking them, or they stop.

headline: The Man Who Helped Redefine Campus Antisemitism
abstract: In government and as an outsider, Kenneth Marcus has tried to douse what he says is rising bias against Jews. Some see a crackdown on pro-Palestinian speech.
lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, as the uprising known as the second intifada instilled fear in Israelis through a series of suicide bombings, Kenneth Marcus, then an official in the U.S. Department of Education, watched with unease as pro-Palestinian protests shook college campuses.

headline: The Hotel Guest Who Wouldn’t Leave
abstract: Mickey Barreto’s five-year stay cost him only $200.57. Now it might cost him his freedom.
lead_paragraph: On a June afternoon in 2018, a man named Mickey Barreto checked into the New Yorker Hotel. He was assigned Room 2565, a double-bed accommodation with a view of Midtown Manhattan almost entirely obscured by an exterior wall. For a one-night stay, he paid $200.57.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Dogs Helping the Covenant Children Find Their Way Back
abstract: To heal after a mass shooting, the Covenant School families have turned to therapy, faith, one another — and a lot of dogs.
lead_paragraph: Two of April Manning’s children, Mac and Lilah, had just survived the mass shooting at the Covenant School in Nashville. They needed stability and time to grieve.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: ‘I Got Into a Cab on a Rainy Night to Go See My Child’s Nanny in a Play’
abstract: A cabby takes the stage, gambling on a red balloon and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: An Editor Who Makes Times Visuals Accessible to All
abstract: Jaime Tanner, The New York Times’s first accessibility visuals editor, wants to remove barriers to make sure readers with disabilities can engage with Times visual journalism.
lead_paragraph: When Jaime Tanner joined The New York Times as its first accessibility visuals editor in July 2022, it was also her first time in a newsroom.

headline: What Would Make the Subway Feel Safer? Experts Have 5 Suggestions.
abstract: A recent shooting on a train in Brooklyn has put some New Yorkers on edge. Several measures could help ease their concerns, experts say.
lead_paragraph: A string of frightening attacks in the subway amid a broader increase in crime in the system so far this year has put some New Yorkers on edge.

headline: Trump Will Face His Greatest Fears as Two Legal Threats Coincide Monday
abstract: Donald J. Trump could receive a trial date for his criminal hush-money case on the same day that he must provide a half-billion bond for a civil fraud judgment.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is expected to spend his Monday morning in the courtroom of a New York judge who might soon preside over his criminal trial and, ultimately, throw him behind bars. And that’s not even the legal predicament that worries Mr. Trump most that day.

headline: Famously Obstinate, Bill Ackman Is Now Real-Life Famous. What Next?
abstract: The hedge-funder who loves a public crusade — and taking charge — is on to a new stage of his career: online warrior.
lead_paragraph: In June 2017 — as he was reeling from the end of his marriage of more than two decades and some of the most disastrous investments of his career — Bill Ackman, the billionaire hedge-fund financier, joined Twitter.

headline: Let’s Say Someone Did Drop the Bomb. Then What?
abstract: In “Nuclear War” and “Countdown,” Annie Jacobsen and Sarah Scoles talk to the people whose job it is to prepare for atomic conflict.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to nuclear catastrophe, there is a large and ever-expanding body of books and films.

headline: The Hidden Figures Who Spread the Gospel
abstract: In “God’s Ghostwriters,” the historian Candida Moss explores the many people who penned the Scriptures.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the Epistle to the Galatians, the Apostle Paul adds a comment on his clumsy penmanship: “Look at what big letters I have written to you with in my own hand.”

headline: Choosing to Skip Sex and Go Straight to I.V.F.
abstract: Well aware of how difficult conception or carrying a baby to term can be, some couples who hope to exercise a bit of control over an unpredictable experience are opting to do in vitro fertilization first.
lead_paragraph: In February, in vitro fertilization, or I.V.F., was thrown into the spotlight when the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos in the state should be considered children. The decision led to a pause on I.V.F. procedures in parts of the state, and even a pause on shipping embryos out of state, to avoid potential criminal liability. In early March, a law was passed to protect I.V.F. providers, prompting some clinics to resume the procedure, though legal challenges could still emerge.

headline: For Girlhood Friends, the Tech Revolution Is a Dividing Line
abstract: In Lisa Ko’s adventurous novel “Memory Piece,” youthful exploration takes a dark turn for an artist, an activist and a web developer.
lead_paragraph: Before doomscrolling, what did we do with all that spare time? Sometimes it’s difficult to recall. And some people will never know.

headline: Sparks Fly in Spicy New Romances
abstract: Our columnist reviews saucy new books by Rebecca Ross, Rebekah Weatherspoon and Felicia Grossman.
lead_paragraph: Romantasy loves to gild its protagonists with royal lineage and awe-inspiring powers, but sometimes we find books that take the ground-up view rather than the crown-down one. Rebecca Ross’s DIVINE RIVALS (Wednesday Books, 357 pp., $18.99) and RUTHLESS VOWS (Wednesday Books, 420 pp., $20) is just such a duology, starring a pair of prickly young reporters who banter and flirt against the backdrop of a war between newly awakened gods.

headline: Could Trump’s Properties Really Be Seized?
abstract: Real estate experts say that getting a judgment is a lot easier than foreclosing on a major piece of real estate. And pinning a value to Trump’s buildings is a guessing game.
lead_paragraph: Rejected by more than two dozen bond companies, Donald J. Trump has so far been unable to come up with the nearly half-a-billion dollar penalty owed by Monday in his civil fraud trial.

headline: In Hezbollah’s Sights, a Stretch of Northern Israel Becomes a No-Go Zone
abstract: For the few Israelis remaining in the evacuated zone along the northern border with Lebanon, the simmering conflict there has become intensely personal.
lead_paragraph: More than 60,000 Israelis who live far from Gaza but close to the front line of another spiraling conflict have in recent months been ordered from their homes along Israel’s northern border with Lebanon — the first mass evacuation of the area in Israeli history.

headline: Behind Our Investigation Into India’s Sugar Industry
abstract: Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have helped turn the Indian state of Maharashtra into a sugar-producing powerhouse. But a New York Times investigation has found that these brands finance a brutal system of labor that exploits young girls and leads to the unnecessary sterilization of working-age women. The investigation was produced in collaboration with The Fuller Project.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have helped turn the Indian state of Maharashtra into a sugar-producing powerhouse. But a New York Times investigation has found that these brands finance a brutal system of labor that exploits young girls and leads to the unnecessary sterilization of working-age women. The investigation was produced in collaboration with The Fuller Project.

headline: Judith Butler Thinks You’re Overreacting
abstract: How did gender become a scary word? The theorist who got us talking about the subject has answers.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I did when reading Judith Butler’s new book, “Who’s Afraid of Gender?”, was to look up the word “phantasm,” which appears 41 times in the introduction alone. (It means illusion; the “phantasm of gender,” a threat rooted in fear and fantasy.)

headline: Furry Slippers and Sweatpants: Young Chinese Embrace ‘Gross Outfits’ at Work
abstract: The social media movement is the latest sign that some of China’s young people are resisting the compulsion to strive.
lead_paragraph: When the weather turned cold in December, Cindy Luo started to wear her fluffy pajamas over a hooded sweatshirt at the office. Wearing cozy sleepwear to work became a habit, and soon she didn’t even bother to wear matching tops and bottoms, selecting whatever was most comfortable.

headline: How a Pandemic Malaise Is Shaping American Politics
abstract: Four years later, the shadow of the pandemic continues to play a profound role in voters’ pessimism and distrust amid a presidential rematch.
lead_paragraph: In March 2020, when Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Donald J. Trump competed for the White House for the first time, American life became almost unrecognizable. A deadly virus and a public health lockdown remade daily routines with startling speed, leaving little time for the country to prepare.

headline: A Lunar Eclipse Warms Up the Moon for April’s Solar Eclipse
abstract: The subtle event, known as a penumbral eclipse, can be observed by everyone on Earth’s nightside.
lead_paragraph: As the moon prepares to blot out the surface of our sun in two weeks, it’s warming up with a penumbral lunar eclipse on Sunday night or Monday morning, depending on your time zone.

headline: 100 Days of Javier Milei
abstract: It is an open question whether Mr. Milei has misread his voters on how far they are willing to go to turn Argentina’s economy around.
lead_paragraph: Argentina’s new president, Javier Milei, has been in office for just over 100 days. Since his inauguration on Dec. 10, Mr. Milei, a far-right libertarian, has been on a mission to end what he has described as “an orgy of public spending” by previous administrations that left him with “the worst inheritance” of any government in Argentina’s history.

headline: What Would You Have Israel Do to Defend Itself?
abstract: If the current Israeli military approach is inhumane, is there an alternative?
lead_paragraph: There seems to be a broad consensus atop the Democratic Party about the war in Gaza, structured around two propositions. First, after the attacks of Oct. 7, Israel has the right to defend itself and defeat Hamas. Second, the way Israel is doing this is “over the top,” in President Biden’s words. The vast numbers of dead and starving children are gut wrenching, the devastation is overwhelming, and it’s hard not to see it all as indiscriminate.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘My Goldendoodle Spent a Week at Some Luxury Dog ‘Hotels.’ I Tagged Along.’
abstract: How exactly did dogs take over our world? This writer journeys into the bespoke pet care industry to find out.
lead_paragraph: By the time Sam Apple pulled up with his goldendoodle, Steve, to their resting place, he was tired from the long drive and already second-guessing his plan. He felt a little better when they stepped inside the Dogwood Acres Pet Retreat. The lobby, with its elegant tiled entrance, might have passed for the lobby of any small countryside hotel, at least one that strongly favored dog-themed decor. But this illusion was broken when the receptionist reviewed their reservation — which, in addition to their luxury suite, included cuddle time, group play, a nature walk and a “belly rub tuck-in.”

headline: Russia’s Battle With Extremists Has Simmered for Years
abstract: The Islamic State has long threatened to strike Russia for helping the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, stay in control.
lead_paragraph: In the past few months, deep in the forbidding deserts of central Syria, Russian forces have quietly joined the Syrian military in intensifying attacks against Islamic State strongholds, including bombing what local news reports called the dens and caves where the extremist fighters hide.

headline: A New Game From The Times
abstract: It’s a word search with a few twists.
lead_paragraph: I still hear from readers who learned about the Connections game from this newsletter and now play it every day. Today, I want to tell you about The Times’s newest game, called Strands. It’s another quick, entertaining way to exercise your brain.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 25, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Tired of Sucking It Up as a Climber, I’ve Embraced a Softer Strength
abstract: As a professional climber, I needed to be able to suffer to stand out. Then I began to question that mentality.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know what time it was when my husband at the time, the rock climber Tommy Caldwell, finally scrambled over the summit. The sun had risen sometime during the first part of the climb and had set again hours later. I squinted up at him, tired eyes burning as I watched his shadow moving in the beam of my headlight. He had just completed the second free ascent of the Direct Route on the northwest face of Half Dome, a 2,000-foot climb in Yosemite National Park.

headline: There’s New Energy in Rome’s Esquilino Neighborhood. Here’s Where to Go.
abstract: Plus: fountain pens for special occasions, moon phase watches and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: Set between the Colosseum and the tracks leading to Termini station, Rome’s Esquilino neighborhood occupies the Esquiline Hill, one of the city’s seven ancient mounds. In the Roman era, it served as a paupers’ cemetery. In the late 19th century, much of the neighborhood was razed to make room for a bourgeois residential district populated with handsome stone apartment buildings and anchored by Piazza Vittorio Emanuele II, the largest square in Rome — named for Italy’s first king to rule after the country’s unification in 1861. By the middle of the 20th century, though, the city had let the area degrade. “It was completely abandoned and a bit shady,” says Matteo Soddu, 40, an architect at the firm Studiotamat who lives in the area.

headline: Dozens of Children Abducted in Nigeria Have Been Released, Officials Say
abstract: The military of the West African nation, which is plagued by kidnappings largely driven by demands for ransom payments, said 137 children had been freed in the country’s north.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Nigerian schoolchildren who were kidnapped this month have been released, officials said on Sunday. The Nigerian military said that 137 children had been freed by security forces in the northwest of the country.

headline: Former Deacon Excommunicated After His Son Is Sexually Abused by a Priest
abstract: A Louisiana priest was convicted in the sexual abuse of the ex-deacon’s son. What followed was a lawsuit and now the Catholic Church’s highest censure.
lead_paragraph: A Catholic priest who sexually assaulted an altar boy in Louisiana is in prison, and a diocese has paid a settlement to the victim’s family. Now the diocese’s bishop has punished the victim’s father, a former deacon, with the Church’s highest censure: excommunication.

headline: Pope Lets Silence Speak for Him as He Skips a Palm Sunday Speech
abstract: Pope Francis’ choice to skip the strenuous speech at the outset of Easter week immediately raised concerns about his health, but he spoke in a clear voice before and after it.
lead_paragraph: As tens of thousands of faithful holding palm fronds in St. Peter’s Square looked on, the moment arrived in the Palm Sunday Mass for Pope Francis to deliver his homily in a service marking the beginning of Holy Week, one of the most demanding and significant on the Christian calendar.

headline: Witnesses Describe Fear and Deprivation at Besieged Hospital in Gaza
abstract: Several patients have died as a result of the Israeli military assault, the Gazan authorities say. Israel says the operation is targeting Hamas leaders.
lead_paragraph: Seven days after Israel’s military began a raid on the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital, Al-Shifa, a picture of the sustained assault on the complex and its surrounding neighborhood emerges in fragments.

headline: Practice Makes Perfect Biscuits
abstract: Make these all-purpose biscuits today and they’ll be terrific. Make them three weekends in a row and they’ll be the best biscuits ever.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. If you make biscuits (above) today — and you ought to — they ought to be terrific. But if you make biscuits today and do so again next weekend and the weekend after and the weekend after that, they will be terrific, the best biscuits ever. This is a matter of practice related to what martial artists call kata — a set pattern that rewards repetition with excellence.

headline: Insurance Companies and the Prior Authorization Maze
abstract: Responses to an Opinion video by Alexander Stockton. Also: Elect the attorney general; friendship memories; a leadership gap.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Fund-Raising Blitz, Trump Warns Democrats: Hands Off Trump Tower
abstract: With a deadline on Monday to secure a $454 million bond in his civil fraud case, Donald Trump’s campaign emails have claimed Democrats are trying to seize his marquee property.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, with a deadline fast approaching to secure a roughly half-billion-dollar bond in his civil fraud case in New York or risk seizure of his assets and flagship properties, sent an email on Saturday morning to his campaign’s supporters.

headline: With Charles and Catherine Sidelined, It’s Camilla’s Time to Shine
abstract: The woman whose very existence once seemed to threaten the royal family’s stability has emerged as a stabilizing force during a major health crisis.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, as illness has sidelined two of Britain’s most visible royal figures, Catherine, Princess of Wales, and King Charles III, one member of the family’s frontbench has stepped into the vacuum: Queen Camilla.

headline: Amid Questions About Security Failures, Russian State Media Focus on a Different Narrative
abstract: Russian state news outlets barely mentioned the claim of responsibility made by the Islamic State group.
lead_paragraph: As Russia mourned the victims of the worst terrorist attack in the Moscow area in more than two decades on Sunday, differing narratives about the attack were spreading and taking hold in the country.

headline: Chuck Todd and ‘Morning Joe’ Hosts Object to NBC’s Hiring of Former R.N.C. Chair
abstract: The extraordinary comments on “Meet the Press” revealed tensions in NBC’s news divisions over Ronna McDaniel, who recently stepped down as head of the Republican National Committee.
lead_paragraph: The veteran NBC anchor Chuck Todd publicly attacked the leadership of his own network on Sunday, questioning why NBC News hired Ronna McDaniel, the former chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, and declaring live on air, “There’s a reason why there are a lot of journalists at NBC News uncomfortable with this.”

headline: Police Say They’ve Cracked Rio de Janeiro’s Most Notorious Murder Mystery
abstract: Two politicians were arrested in the assassination of a rival, Marielle Franco, who was known for fighting corruption and police violence.
lead_paragraph: “Who killed Marielle Franco?” That has been the question haunting Rio de Janeiro for the past six years, ever since a gunman assassinated the Black, gay, feminist councilwoman who had fought the city’s entrenched corruption and powerful gangs.

headline: ‘Vigorous Storm’ to Bring Blizzard Conditions to Plains States and Midwest
abstract: A potent storm was expected to make travel “near impossible at times” starting overnight on Sunday in the Upper Midwest and Central and Northern Plains, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A developing storm in the Plains and Upper Midwest is expected to deliver heavy snow and gusty winds across several states into Tuesday, with blizzard conditions possible in some areas.

headline: For Once, the British Tabloids Held Back. It Didn’t Make a Difference.
abstract: The online frenzy over Catherine’s health escalated despite a reserved approach by Fleet Street — which promptly blamed Americans for the furor.
lead_paragraph: Days before Catherine, Princess of Wales, ended the wild speculation over her absence from public life by revealing that she is battling cancer, a top royal journalist appeared on British national television and delivered a stark message to the media: Knock it off.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Noncommittal on Gaza, the Border and TikTok
abstract: In an interview with ABC News on Sunday, the vice president declined to offer details on several issues facing the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: In a carefully worded interview broadcast on ABC News on Sunday, Vice President Kamala Harris declined to provide details on how the Biden administration would respond if Israel invaded the city of Rafah in southern Gaza, if Congress continued to refuse to pass border-security legislation and if TikTok’s Chinese parent company refused to sell the service.

headline: Ben Stern, Who Opposed a Nazi Rally in Illinois, Dies at 102
abstract: He was held prisoner in nine concentration camps. Decades later, he fought a battle against American Nazis that became a major free-speech case.
lead_paragraph: When a band of Nazis proposed to exercise their right to free speech by staging a rally in Skokie, Ill., in 1977, Ben Stern was incensed.

headline: Breyer Says He Is Open to Supporting a Supreme Court Age Limit
abstract: The retired justice suggested that an 18- or 20-year term could dissuade members of the court from “thinking about the next job” just as effectively as a lifetime appointment does now.
lead_paragraph: Justice Stephen G. Breyer, the liberal judge who retired from the Supreme Court in 2022, said in an interview aired on Sunday that he would be open to supporting an age limit for the justices.

headline: Screams and Blank Stares of Shock: Horror at a Russian Concert
abstract: The violent attack on Moscow’s outskirts on Friday was a scene of chaos and terror. “You’re just running to figure out where else to run,” one attendee said.
lead_paragraph: Once they heard the shots ring out on Friday night at Crocus City Hall, Efim Fidrya and his wife ran down to the building’s basement and hid with three others in a bathroom.

headline: Mountain Lion Kills Man and Injures His Brother in California
abstract: Since 1890, there have been fewer than 50 verified mountain lion attacks on humans in California, and of those, only six have been fatal, officials said.
lead_paragraph: In a rare attack against humans, a mountain lion killed a man and injured his brother while the men were in a remote area of Northern California on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Tammy Murphy Drops Out of Race for Menendez’s Senate Seat
abstract: Ms. Murphy, the first lady of New Jersey, had racked up early endorsements from Democratic Party leaders in the state, but she struggled to gain support among rank-and-file voters.
lead_paragraph: Tammy Murphy, New Jersey’s first lady, has ended her run for a U.S. Senate seat now held by the state’s embattled senior senator, Robert Menendez, she announced on Sunday in a video posted to social media.

headline: Murkowski Won’t Vote for Trump and Declines Ruling Out Leaving the G.O.P.
abstract: In an interview with CNN on Sunday, the veteran Republican senator from Alaska said, “I just regret that our party is seemingly becoming a party of Donald Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said in an interview released on Sunday that she would not vote for former President Donald J. Trump. She also did not rule out the possibility of leaving the Republican Party.

headline: Monday Briefing: Two Charged in Moscow Attack
abstract: Plus, the hotel guest who wouldn’t leave.

headline: Ready, Set, Garçon! Paris Waiters Race as Storied Contest Returns
abstract: Contestants rushed through the streets with croissant-laden trays in a moment for the French capital to showcase its cafe culture ahead of the Summer Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The contestants warmed up with stretches and squats in front of City Hall, carefully repositioned croissants and glasses on their trays and tightened their aprons as pop music blared from loudspeakers.

headline: Reef Composition
abstract: Shannon Rapp and Will Eisenberg make their New York Times collaboration debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Big Republican Donor Jeff Yass Owned Shares in Trump Media Merger Partner
abstract: The billionaire Wall Street financier is also a major investor in ByteDance, the Chinese parent company of TikTok, which faces a possible ban in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Yass, the billionaire Wall Street financier and Republican megadonor who is a major investor in the parent company of TikTok, was also the biggest institutional shareholder of the shell company that recently merged with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company.

headline: Shani Mott, Black Studies Scholar Who Examined Power All Around Her, Dies at 47
abstract: Her work looked at how race and power are experienced in America. In 2022, she filed a lawsuit saying that the appraisal of her home was undervalued because of bias.
lead_paragraph: Shani Mott, a scholar of Black studies at Johns Hopkins University whose examinations of race and power in America extended beyond the classroom to her employer, her city and even her own home, has died in Baltimore. She was 47.

headline: In Russia, Fingers Point Anywhere but at ISIS for Concert Hall Attack
abstract: Russian state media pushed the idea that Ukraine was the obvious culprit, but at least three of the four suspects charged on Sunday are from the Central Asian nation of Tajikistan.
lead_paragraph: Bodies were recovered, flowers were laid and fingers were pointed on Sunday as competing narratives took shape over who was behind the terrorist attack on a Russian concert hall where at least 137 people out to enjoy an evening of music were killed.

headline: 4 Men Showing Signs of Beating Charged With Terrorism After Moscow Attack
abstract: The four accused of carrying out an assault at a concert hall near Moscow are migrant laborers from Tajikistan. They face a maximum sentence of life in prison.
lead_paragraph: The four men suspected of carrying out a bloody attack on a concert hall near Moscow, killing at least 137 people, were arraigned in a district court late Sunday and charged with committing a terrorist act.

headline: Germany’s Solar Panel Industry, Once a Leader, Is Getting Squeezed
abstract: Domestic manufacturers are caught between China’s low prices and U.S. protectionist policies, even as demand increases.
lead_paragraph: Before China came to dominate the solar panel industry, Germany led the way. It was the world’s largest producer of solar panels, with several start-ups clustered in the former East Germany, until about a decade ago when China ramped up production and undercut just about everyone on price.

headline: Has China Lost Its Taste for the iPhone?
abstract: Apple has deep ties in the country, its second-largest market. But there are signs that Chinese consumers are becoming a harder sell.
lead_paragraph: For years, Apple dominated the market for high-end smartphones in China. No other company made a device that could compete with the iPhone’s performance — or its position as a status object in the eyes of wealthy, cosmopolitan shoppers.

headline: To Live Past 100, Mangia a Lot Less: Italian Expert’s Ideas on Aging
abstract: Valter Longo, who wants to live to a healthy 120 or 130, sees the key to longevity in diet — legumes and fish — and faux fasting.
lead_paragraph: Most members of the band subscribed to a live-fast-die-young lifestyle. But as they partook in the drinking and drugging endemic to the 1990s grunge scene after shows at the Whisky a Go Go, Roxy and other West Coast clubs, the band’s guitarist, Valter Longo, a nutrition-obsessed Italian Ph.D. student, wrestled with a lifelong addiction to longevity.

headline: ISIS Affiliate Linked to Moscow Attack Has Global Ambitions
abstract: The Islamic State in Khorasan is active in Afghanistan, Pakistan and Iran and has set its sights on Europe and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago this month, an American-backed Kurdish and Arab militia ousted Islamic State fighters from a village in eastern Syria, the group’s last sliver of territory.

headline: Kevin Hart Receives the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
abstract: The prolific comic was honored at the Kennedy Center for a 25-year career that has included movies, TV series and many live events.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Hart stepped into the spotlight on Sunday night with his usual swagger to accept the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, occupying a stage lit up with his signature pyrotechnics.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Covid Malaise Is Killing Trust in U.S. Politics
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We’re experiencing long Covid as a social disease.”

headline: No Corrections: March 25, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Heavy Lies the Crown
abstract: The fascination of the monarchy will always be the tension between a venerable institution and the human beings like Catherine who are trapped inside it.
lead_paragraph: I was in London last week when the febrile madness of Where Is Kate? was blowing up social media, and the Curious Mystery of the Doctored Mother’s Day Photograph consumed every news outlet and dinner table conversation.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Bachelor’ and ‘The Truth vs. Alex Jones’
abstract: Joey Graziadei hands out his final rose on ABC, and HBO airs a documentary about the trial of Alex Jones.
lead_paragraph: For those like myself who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, March 25-31. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: jeer
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word jeer has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 5 in The New York Times Magazine Letter of Recommendation “Why I Love Doing Homework (Even If My Kids Hate It)” by Saul Austerlitz:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Is Sam a Dangerous Dog? A Lawsuit Divides a Manhattan Building.
abstract: A suit claims that an emotional support dog named Sam attacked several tenants at an Upper West Side building and that the animal’s owners failed to take preventative action.
lead_paragraph: The rental building at 175 West 79th Street — in the heart of the Upper West Side — would seem like a dream, roughly equidistant from the American Museum of Natural History and Zabar’s.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Trump Criminal Trial Is Set for April 15 as His Attempt at Delay Fails
abstract: Donald Trump is poised to become the first ex-president to go on trial on criminal charges, in a case related to hush money paid to a porn star.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is all but certain to become the first former American president to stand trial on criminal charges after a judge on Monday denied his effort to delay the proceeding and confirmed it would begin next month.

headline: New Group Plans to Spend Big in Support of YIMBY Campaigns
abstract: The group, Abundant New York, will work to elect candidates who support building more housing. It is yet another sign that the state’s housing politics are changing.
lead_paragraph: Housing advocates in New York have created a super PAC that aims to spend tens of thousands of dollars to help elect political candidates who welcome development in their districts.

headline: Trump’s Options Dwindle as $454 Million Judgment Bears Down on Him
abstract: If no one will post a bond guaranteeing Donald Trump’s financial obligation, New York’s attorney general can start trying to seize his accounts and properties.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the latest on Trump’s bond in the N.Y. civil fraud case.

headline: Waiters Compete in Paris’ Revived Cafe Race
abstract: About 200 restaurant workers participated in the revived tradition, each one speeding through the course with a tray carrying a croissant, a glass of water and a coffee cup.
lead_paragraph: About 200 restaurant workers participated in the revived tradition, each one speeding through the course with a tray carrying a croissant, a glass of water and a coffee cup.

headline: A House Is Not a Home
abstract: Israel has been destroying Palestinian houses for decades. Palestinians carry the story of their homes and their homeland wherever they go.
lead_paragraph: On July 9, 1998, a small house in Anata, a village northeast of Jerusalem, was destroyed for the first time. Home to the Shawamrehs, a Palestinian family of nine, the house was built four years earlier in a part of the West Bank over which Israel has military control. House demolitions occur routinely in this territory, where Palestinians like Arabiya and Salim Shawamreh are denied building permits on land that they have purchased and rightfully own.

headline: ‘Yo Soy la Mamá’: A Migrant Mother’s Struggle to Get Back Her Son
abstract: She came to the United States fleeing her abuser. When child welfare got involved, she risked losing her son forever.
lead_paragraph: Over the final four months of 2021, Olga, a Honduran immigrant in Hollywood, Fla., grew increasingly panicked. She could not find her 5-year-old son, Ricardo. After she’d fled her homeland to escape her abusive husband, the man also migrated, disappeared with the boy and broke off contact.

headline: Aurora Tourism in Iceland: You Can Seek, but You May Not Find
abstract: The country markets itself as a destination to see the northern lights — especially this year, which is a peak time for solar activity. But they can be elusive, as one writer recently found.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, it may seem like the northern lights dance across Iceland’s skies each night. On Icelandair ads, planes fly across shimmering curtains in the sky. On social media, travelers gaze at the green bands above them. The lights are even on some recycling bins in Reykjavík, the capital: “Keep Iceland Clean.”

headline: Once a Roadside Attraction, a Native Burial Site Nears Repatriation
abstract: Centuries-old grave mounds in Illinois became a flashpoint in the debate over displaying Native American remains. Now, tribes are close to seeing them reburied.
lead_paragraph: In 1927, on a bluff overlooking the Illinois River Valley, a chiropractor named Don Dickson took a shovel to his family’s farmland in Fulton County, Ill., and uncovered burial mounds dating back eight centuries.

headline: Cosmic Forecast: Blurry With a Chance of Orbital Chaos
abstract: Astronomers have gotten better at tracking the motions of stars just beyond the solar system. But that’s made it harder to predict Earth’s future and reconstruct its past.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of what stock market analysts, political pollsters and astrologers might say, we can’t predict the future. In fact, we can’t even predict the past.

headline: The Mayor of Los Angeles Wants to Prove Homelessness Can Be Solved
abstract: More than a year into her term, Mayor Karen Bass has cleared encampments and moved thousands of people into motels. What happens next is unclear.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Bass took office as Los Angeles mayor with a mandate to tackle homelessness, Venice Beach was at the top of her agenda.

headline: Where Are All the Cool Gays Hanging Out?
abstract: In “Long Live Queer Nightlife,” the L.G.B.T.Q. studies scholar Amin Ghaziani visits a new generation of ad hoc dance parties that have risen from the ashes of the gay bar.
lead_paragraph: The sociologist Amin Ghaziani wants to turn a funeral into a party.

headline: Trump’s Third Act? American Gangster.
abstract: Why does the former president keep talking about Al Capone?
lead_paragraph: In recent months, Donald Trump has been trying out a new routine. At rallies and town halls across the country, he compares himself to Al Capone. “He was seriously tough, right?” Mr. Trump told a rally in Iowa in October, in an early rendition of the act. But “he was only indicted one time; I’ve been indicted four times.” (Capone was, in fact, indicted at least six times.) The implication is not just that Mr. Trump is being unfairly persecuted but also that he is four times as tough as Capone. “If you looked at him in the wrong way,” Mr. Trump explained, “he blew your brains out."

headline: A Critic’s Plea for Maximalism: ‘Crack Us Open Like Eggs’
abstract: In her first essay collection, Becca Rothfeld demonstrates that sometimes, more really is more.
lead_paragraph: The essays I love favor abundance over economy, performance over persuasion. Zadie Smith’s exemplary “Speaking in Tongues” juggles Barack Obama, Shakespeare, Shaw’s “Pygmalion,” Pauline Kael on Cary Grant, Thomas Macaulay on the Marquess of Halifax and her own “silly posh” speaking voice. Its modest argument, that “flexibility of voice leads to a flexibility in all things,” disappears into the spectacle of a nimble mind reveling in its omnivorous erudition.

headline: The First Flight of Their Lives: An Airlift After Agony in Gaza
abstract: The evacuees make up only a tiny fraction of the thousands of civilians, including many children, who have suffered grievous injuries over the course of Israel’s monthslong campaign against Hamas and its bombardment of Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Each of the children survived horrors. Each lost relatives in the strikes that injured them. All have struggled with the emotions of what they went through and what they face ahead.

headline: ​Should Wildlife Advocates Help Set Hunting Rules in Vermont?
abstract: A bill that would add people who don’t hunt to the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Board has stirred an outcry in a state known for both progressive politics and rural traditions.
lead_paragraph: Legislators in Vermont are considering shaking up the state board that drafts hunting and fishing rules — by adding members who don’t hunt or fish.

headline: Why Are Restaurants Filling Up With Fake Flowers? Ask This Guy.
abstract: They’re popping up all over the dining world: huge, elaborate arrangements of faux blossoms and plants — many of them the work of one enterprising man.
lead_paragraph: Marigolds don’t generally thrive in 30-degree weather. Yet on a cool March afternoon, they bloomed in golden bunches outside Bungalow, a new Indian restaurant in the East Village. The petals appeared perky and thriving, as did the man, Carlos Franqui, expertly twisting them into a colorful archway that crawled around the entrance.

headline: Are Teenagers Obsessing Too Much About Skin Care?
abstract: Should we worry that young people are using acne and anti-aging products meant for adults?
lead_paragraph: Is anyone you know especially interested in skin care? Do they seem to know, or want to know, everything about various products, skin types and beauty treatments? Are you someone who fits into this category?

headline: Stephen King’s First Book Is 50 Years Old, and Still Horrifyingly Relevant
abstract: “Carrie” was published in 1974. Margaret Atwood explains its enduring appeal.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King’s “Carrie” burst upon an astonished world in 1974. It made King’s career. It has sold millions, made millions, inspired four films and passed from generation to generation. It was, and continues to be, a phenomenon.

headline: Chuck Scarborough’s 50 Years of Delivering News to New York
abstract: The WNBC anchor started on the job in 1974 and has covered blackouts, Sept. 11, Covid, seven mayors and eight governors.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a local news anchor who has 50 years on the job. We’ll also take a look at some of the legal threats facing Donald Trump.

headline: Spring Allergy Season Is Getting Worse. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Experts explain how to tell if you have allergies, and how to find relief if you do.
lead_paragraph: Spring is here — and if you’re among the estimated one in four adults in the United States who suffers from seasonal allergies, your sneezing and scratching may have already started.

headline: Has Fashion Canceled Canceling?
abstract: The recent history of John Galliano, Dolce & Gabbana and even Ye suggests the answer may be yes.
lead_paragraph: ““High & Low: John Galliano,” the feature-length documentary about the former Dior designer’s fall from grace after a drunken antisemitic rant in a Paris bar in 2011, and his long climb back, is interesting for a number of reasons. It is a chance to hear from Mr. Galliano himself about his struggles, for one, and to look back at the fashion world of the 1990s. But just as striking is the number of think pieces it has spawned meditating on Mr. Galliano’s transgressions, repentance and, it seems, current state of forgiveness.

headline: This Small New Jersey Town Became a Different Kind of Suburb
abstract: A small New Jersey town allows two homes on each lot, making room for more housing and more people.
lead_paragraph: A potential remedy for New York’s housing crisis — and the similar crises in other coastal cities — is on display in this small New Jersey town two miles west of the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Could First-Time Home Buyers Lose Out Under New Commission Rules?
abstract: Economists and real estate experts warn that changes in how agents are paid could have unintended consequences for people buying their first homes.
lead_paragraph: With a landmark legal settlement poised to upend a decades-old norm that has dictated who pays real estate agents and how much, economists, agents and lenders are beginning to worry that the burden could now be on first-time home buyers.

headline: A Complete Guide to Allergy Treatments
abstract: You’re sniffling, sneezing and staring at the pharmacy shelf. Here’s how to choose the right option for your symptoms.
lead_paragraph: With tree pollen counts already hitting peak levels in some parts of the United States, now is the time to start preparing for — and treating — your spring allergy symptoms.

headline: Allison Holker Is Dancing Through the Ups and Downs
abstract: The performer stopped dancing after the death of her husband, Stephen Boss. Now she’s a judge on “So You Think You Can Dance,” the show where they met.
lead_paragraph: When dealing with overwhelming emotions, dancers often want to move — to work it all out physically. It makes sense: If you’ve spent your life learning to speak with your body, other forms of communication begin to seem incomplete.

headline: This Is the Best Way for Biden to Talk About the Economy
abstract: He is defying 40 years of orthodoxy on the center-left.
lead_paragraph: Since the early 2000s, most Americans have generally been dissatisfied with the economy, and many are insecure about their place in it. The dissatisfaction peaked during the Great Recession of 2007 to 2009 but persists, even as the economy is growing and unemployment and inflation combined are roughly where they were during the relatively upbeat days of the Kennedy administration. This is a stubborn, long-term disgruntlement.

headline: With a Second Term, Biden Could Reverse This National Health Emergency
abstract: Our leaders should turn their attention to Americans’ worsening life expectancy.
lead_paragraph: I began my public health career more than 20 years ago, at a time when H.I.V. was ravaging many countries around the world. The U.S. government’s strategic response to attack this cruel disease abroad was PEPFAR, an American initiative that has saved more than 25 million lives and shaped my understanding of what muscular public health policy could accomplish.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco, a three-bedroom cottage in Los Angeles and a ranch house in San Luis Obispo.
lead_paragraph: This condominium is in Cow Hollow, a few blocks from the Fillmore Street shopping corridor and from walking trails winding through the Presidio, one of the city’s largest public parks. It is less than a mile from the Palace of Fine Arts, built for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition of 1915, and less than a 10-minute drive from Crissy Field East Beach, which offers sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: 83 Years After His Killing, a Black Soldier Gets an Army Funeral
abstract: Pvt. Albert King, shot dead by a white military police officer in Georgia in 1941, was blamed for his own death and buried in an unmarked grave.
lead_paragraph: In a Georgia cemetery, surrounded by tombstones cracked and worn by decades of rain and sun, Pvt. Albert King’s gleams new and bright. The Army unveiled it Sunday in a full military funeral, 83 years late.

headline: What’s the Point of a Tiny Evening Bag?
abstract: Our fashion critic explains why some may prefer clutches and small evening purses when more practical alternatives exist.
lead_paragraph: There’s an essential contradiction at the heart of the small-evening-purse question that speaks to our long and fraught history with the accessory.

headline: Biden, Promising Corporate Tax Increases, Has Cut Taxes Overall
abstract: President Biden has called for $5 trillion in new taxes on corporations and high earners. But his record so far is as a net tax cutter.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, amping up a populist pitch in his re-election campaign, has repeatedly said he would raise taxes on the wealthy and corporations to make them pay their “fair share.”

headline: A Memoir of a Marriage Cut Short and the Secrets Left Behind
abstract: After his partner, Molly Brodak, died by suicide, Blake Butler found painful truths in her journals and personal items.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that “Molly” is not going to be a typical memoir arrives on Page 20. That’s when the author, Blake Butler, finds himself on his hands and knees in agony beside his wife, whose body he has found in wild grass after she has ended her life with a handgun. It is at this moment that he is stung by a bee — the first bee sting of his life — on his right eyelid. It is as if the universe is declaring: Here is some extra awfulness, friend, just for you.

headline: A Dire Threat to a National Wildlife Treasure
abstract: The Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge belongs to the planet. And we can still save it.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest things to reconcile about living in the American South is how this region of extraordinary natural beauty, this still wild place of irreplaceable biodiversity, is mostly in the hands of politicians who will gladly sell it to the highest bidder. It’s hard to reconcile how even land that’s ostensibly protected is never truly safe. And how state regulators charged with protecting it will often look the other way when the highest bidder violates the state’s own environmental regulations.

headline: Energy Dept. Awards $6 Billion for Green Steel, Cement and Even Macaroni Factories
abstract: Industries produce 25 percent of America’s planet-warming emissions but so far have proved very hard to clean up. The Biden administration is trying.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration plans to spend up to $6 billion on new technologies to cut carbon dioxide emissions from heavy industries like steel, cement, chemicals and aluminum, which are all enormous contributors to global warming but which have so far been incredibly difficult to clean up.

headline: Nearly Everything in American Politics Is Topsy-Turvy
abstract: The many ways 2024 is turning into honorable versus dishonorable.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. It goes without saying that we wish Catherine, Princess of Wales, health and strength in her battle with cancer. Other than that, I think the best we can do to respect her privacy is to say as little about it as possible.

headline: A Terrorist Attack in Russia
abstract: The tragedy in a Moscow suburb is a blow to Vladimir V. Putin, coming only days after his stage-managed election victory.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: Trump Is Back in Court, and an ISIS Group Looks Beyond Russia Attack
abstract: Plus, a new golden age for shipwreck discoveries.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode

headline: Challenging Abortion, Again
abstract: A Supreme Court suit against the F.D.A. could change the national abortion landscape.
lead_paragraph: How safe is it to take abortion pills? The F.D.A., the nation’s authority on drug regulation, says that it’s very safe. But the agency’s judgment is the topic of a sweeping challenge that the Supreme Court will hear tomorrow. The case could curtail Americans’ access to mifepristone, the first pill taken in a two-drug regimen for a medication abortion.

headline: Putin Acknowledges ‘Radical Islamists’ Committed Moscow Attack
abstract: But President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held fast to the idea that a Western-backed Ukraine could have been the ultimate mastermind of the assault that killed 139 people.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday acknowledged for the first time that the bloody assault on a concert hall near Moscow was executed by “radical Islamists,” but he insisted that Ukraine could still have played a role despite the Islamic State’s claim of responsibility.

headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Alphabet, Apple and Meta in Wide-Ranging Investigations
abstract: The inquiries signal the bloc’s intention to tightly enforce sweeping new competition rules that took effect this month.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Apple and Meta were told by European Union regulators on Monday that they were under investigation for a range of potential violations of the region’s new competition law.

headline: The Long Case for Machine Shorthand
abstract: Court reporters and online communities are keeping stenography in style.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Stanton’s “aha!” moment while learning stenography happened when she stopped questioning why typing an H and an R together made an L.

headline: A Higher Bid, and National Security Concerns, for an Ammunition Maker
abstract: MNC Capital has raised its takeover offer for Vista Outdoor, the owner of Remington ammunition — and amplified worries about a non-American rival bidder.
lead_paragraph: A battle over Vista Outdoor, the company behind top ammunition brands like Remington and Camelbak water bottles, is escalating — and national security is becoming a bigger factor in the fight.

headline: How an Aid Group Built a Jetty to Get Food Into Gaza
abstract: Workers with World Central Kitchen were still finishing a jetty made from the rubble of bombed buildings when a ship arrived carrying the first aid into the enclave by sea in nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: Just a few hours before sunset in mid-March, World Central Kitchen workers scrambled to put the final touches on a makeshift jetty built out of rubble, as the ship carrying the first aid to reach the Gaza Strip by sea in nearly two decades backed toward the shore.

headline: Boeing C.E.O. to Step Down in Major Reshuffle at Embattled Plane Maker
abstract: The company’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, said he would leave at the end of the year. Stan Deal, Boeing’s head of commercial planes, departed immediately.
lead_paragraph: Boeing abruptly said on Monday that it was overhauling its leadership amid its most significant safety crisis in years, announcing sweeping changes that included the departure of its chief executive, Dave Calhoun, at the end of the year.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: What the terrorist attack means for Russia.
lead_paragraph: Investigators brought charges yesterday against four men who they said killed at least 137 people at a concert hall near Moscow on Friday.

headline: Can California Legislate Its Way to Happiness?
abstract: A first-in-the-nation committee hopes to figure out how to make the Golden State a joyous place.
lead_paragraph: Are you happy?

headline: 1949: ‘Red Star’ Says Labour Increases British Taxes
abstract: The Soviet Army newspaper report blamed the government’s foreign policy for the higher cost of living for the working class.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Moscow Radio quoted the Soviet Army newspaper “Red Star” today as blaming the Labour government for high taxes in Britain.

headline: Maps of the April 2024 Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: On April 8, the moon will cast a shadow across much of North America.
lead_paragraph: On April 8, the moon will cast a shadow across much of North America.

headline: Nicole Scherzinger to Star in ‘Sunset Boulevard’ on Broadway in the Fall
abstract: The revival, birthed in London, is a radically reimagined version of the 1993 Andrew Lloyd Webber musical based on a 1950 Billy Wilder film.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Lloyd’s radically reimagined revival of “Sunset Boulevard,” in which Nicole Scherzinger plays the faded film star Norma Desmond, will come to Broadway this fall after a rapturously received run in London.

headline: Ariana Grande Holds Off Kacey Musgraves for a Second Week at No. 1
abstract: “Everything I Thought It Was,” Justin Timberlake’s first new album since “Man of the Woods” six years ago, opens in fourth place.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Grande holds the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s album chart this week with “Eternal Sunshine,” beating out new releases by Kacey Musgraves and Justin Timberlake.

headline: Watch: The Solo of ‘Solitude’
abstract: Click through as Joseph Gordon performs a section from Alexei Ratmansky’s new dance for New York City Ballet, a reaction to the horrors of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Click through as Joseph Gordon performs a section from Alexei Ratmansky’s new dance for New York City Ballet, a reaction to the horrors of the war in Ukraine.

headline: Young Opposition Candidate Set to Become Senegal’s President
abstract: Bassirou Diomaye Faye, who turned 44 on Monday, was little known until he received the backing of Ousmane Sonko, Senegal’s most formidable opposition politician. Both men were released from jail only 10 days ago.
lead_paragraph: With the concession of his main rival, a young political outsider backed by a powerful opposition figure has won a surprise outright victory in Senegal’s presidential election only 10 days after being released from jail.

headline: U.K. Accuses China of Cyberattacks Targeting Voter Data and Lawmakers
abstract: The British government believes China has overseen two separate hacking campaigns, including one that yielded information from 40 million voters.
lead_paragraph: The British government on Monday accused China of cyberattacks that compromised the voting records of tens of millions of people, a sharp rebuke that underlined the hardening of Britain’s stance toward China since its leaders heralded a “golden era” in British-Chinese relations nearly a decade ago.

headline: Do You Know These Novels and Their Recent Television Adaptations?
abstract: Try this short literary quiz highlighting books written by women and adapted into streaming shows within the past few years.
lead_paragraph: Try this short literary quiz highlighting books written by women and adapted into streaming shows within the past few years.

headline: Spicy Tofu and Mushroom Mazemen; Chicken Koftas With Lime Couscous
abstract: And plenty more minimum-effort, maximum-rewards dinner ideas.
lead_paragraph: Hang on to your hats, because Hetty Lui McKinnon has done it again. Why do we all go so nuts for Hetty’s recipes? Because she somehow manages to coax maximum character out of minimal ingredients, techniques and prep work. Her creations are always satisfying and never fussy, a true boon for busy people who care deeply about what they cook.

headline: 6 Books for Adults Living With A.D.H.D.
abstract: Psychiatrists, counselors and researchers shared their recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Staying focused in a world of distractions can be incredibly challenging. But for people living with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder — a neurodevelopmental disorder often marked by difficulty maintaining attention, disorganization, hyperactivity and impulsivity — it can be even harder. Adults are diagnosed less often than children, but A.D.H.D. can still create problems at work and in friendships and romantic relationships.

headline: Inside a C.E.O.’s Bold Claims About Her Hot Fintech Start-Up
abstract: Amira Yahyaoui, a human rights activist, promoted the success of her student aid start-up, Mos. Some of her statements do not add up, according to internal data and people familiar with the company.
lead_paragraph: As a Tunisian human rights activist in the 2000s, Amira Yahyaoui staged protests and blogged about government corruption. In interviews, she described being beaten by the police. When she was 18, she said, she was kidnapped from the street, dropped off at the Algerian border and placed in exile for several years.

headline: Use of Abortion Pills Has Risen Significantly Post Roe, Research Shows
abstract: Two new studies show fast-growing use of the pills on the eve of the Supreme Court’s consideration of a case seeking to ban or restrict them.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of oral arguments in a Supreme Court case that could affect future access to abortion pills, new research shows the fast-growing use of medication abortion nationally and the many ways women have obtained access to the method since Roe v. Wade was overturned in June 2022.

headline: Trump’s Bond in Civil Fraud Case Is Reduced to $175 Million
abstract: The former president was racing to secure a half-billion-dollar bond, but an appeals court lowered the amount. The surprise decision may help him stave off financial disaster.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump on the clock to secure a nearly half-billion-dollar bond in his civil fraud case, a New York appeals court handed the former president a lifeline on Monday, saying it would accept a far smaller bond of $175 million.

headline: This Easy, Make-Ahead Easter Brunch Only Feels Expensive
abstract: This spring menu — a showstopping frittata, a snappy salad and a chewy cookie from a celebrated restaurant chef — isn’t just surprising. It’s surprisingly simple.
lead_paragraph: No matter what’s going on outside, by the end of March, it can be pretty much spring in the kitchen. It’ll probably be a few weeks until the season’s produce trickles in, but this shouldn’t stop you from making a meal that feels jubilantly of the moment.

headline: Angela Alsobrooks Picks Up Senate Endorsements After Opponent Uses Racial Slur
abstract: Five House members backed Ms. Alsobrooks over their colleague, David Trone, who has apologized for a racial slur he said he used inadvertently during a recent hearing.
lead_paragraph: Five Black Democrats in the House of Representatives have endorsed Angela Alsobrooks in the party’s Senate primary in Maryland after her main opponent, Representative David Trone, used a racial slur in a House hearing.

headline: Lawsuit Alleging Racial Bias in Home Appraisals Is Settled
abstract: Nathan Connolly and the estate of Shani Mott, who recently died, will receive a payment from their mortgage lender, which also agreed to several policy changes to discourage discrimination.
lead_paragraph: A Black couple who claimed an appraisal company undervalued their Baltimore home based on their race have settled their lawsuit against their mortgage lender, loanDepot, which has agreed to a number of sweeping policy changes that could offer significant relief to homeowners who allege racially biased appraisals in the future.

headline: Judge Takes One of Trump’s Lawyers, Todd Blanche, To Task
abstract: During the first hour of a hearing on a possible delay or even a dismissal of the criminal trial facing his client, Mr. Blanche faced withering questioning from the trial’s judge, Juan M. Merchan.
lead_paragraph: When Todd Blanche, Donald Trump’s pugnacious defense attorney, arrived in state court on Monday morning, he was smiling and seemingly confident.

headline: U.S. and Britain Accuse China of Cyberespionage Campaign
abstract: The actions on both sides of the Atlantic, which included sanctions, underscored the escalation of cyberconflict between Western allies and Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Britain imposed sanctions on China’s elite hacking units on Monday, accusing Beijing’s top spy agency of a yearslong effort to place malware in America’s electrical grids, defense systems and other critical infrastructure, and of stealing the voting rolls for 40 million British citizens.

headline: Ukrainians Dismiss Kremlin Suggestions Their Country Was Behind Moscow Attack
abstract: Officials and ordinary citizens say Russia is blaming Ukraine in order to shore up support for its war in Ukraine and escalate the fighting there.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainians have reacted with a mixture of concern and mockery to the narrative pushed by the Kremlin and Russian state media that Ukraine was behind the terrorist attack Friday on a Moscow concert hall, a claim made despite the Islamic State’s claim of responsibility.

headline: X’s Lawsuit Against Anti-Hate Research Group Is Dismissed
abstract: Elon Musk’s social media company sued a group that exposed hate speech on the site, but a judge ruled that the suit was designed to punish speech.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in California on Monday dismissed X’s lawsuit against a nonprofit organization that studies hate speech online, ruling that the social media company’s case was designed to punish researchers for speaking freely about the social media platform, formerly known as Twitter.

headline: Netanyahu Cancels U.S.-Israel Meetings on Rafah, to Protest U.N. Resolution
abstract: President Biden had requested the high-level meetings to discuss alternatives to a planned Israel ground offensive into Rafah, which U.S. officials say would cause mass casualties.

It had been three decades since she had worked on the action-adventure cartoon, which ran on Fox from 1992 to 1997, and the idea that it would be returning, let alone returning with its original cast, seemed so unlikely that she could hardly entertain it.

headline: Why I Can’t Wait for the Sun to Go Dark
