headline: ‘Shortcuts Everywhere’: How Boeing Favored Speed Over Quality
abstract: Problems have plagued the manufacturer even after two fatal crashes, and many current and former employees blame its focus on making planes more quickly.
lead_paragraph: In February last year, a new Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 Max plane was on one of its first flights when an automated stabilizing system appeared to malfunction, forcing the pilots to make an emergency landing soon after they took off.

headline: 36 Hours in Mumbai
abstract: Explore ancient caves, catch a concert in a former textile mill, feast on mangoes and go on a poetry crawl in this fast-changing Indian city.
lead_paragraph: Explore ancient caves, catch a concert in a former textile mill, feast on mangoes and go on a poetry crawl in this fast-changing Indian city.

headline: T’s 25 Most Defining Pieces of Furniture From the Last 100 Years: Everything We Considered
abstract: From a Marcel Breuer chair to Metro shelving, all the nominated objects.
lead_paragraph: Before sitting down to debate the 25 most defining pieces of furniture from the past 100 years, all six panelists — the curator Paola Antonelli; T’s design and interiors director, Tom Delavan; the actress and furniture collector Julianne Moore; the artist Katie Stout; and the architects and designers Daniel Romualdez and Rafael de Cárdenas — were asked to nominate about 10 objects apiece from which the list would be winnowed down. When coming up with his selections, Romualdez rightly figured that the others would include what he called “the anointed chairs.” Like Antonelli, he wanted to surprise readers, while also incorporating objects that, he says, “had become part of the vernacular.”

headline: For Young Offenders in Maine, Justice Varies With Geography
abstract: Maine has tried to send fewer teenagers to prison, emphasizing rehabilitation programs instead. But the rural north of the state shows the effort has played out unevenly.
lead_paragraph: Aroostook County, in Maine’s far north, is the largest county east of the Mississippi, a sparsely populated region of fields and forests with just two small cities and about 50 smaller towns. Police chiefs describe their jurisdictions as sleepy, with little serious crime.

headline: He’s Got a Plan for Cities That Flood: Stop Fighting the Water
abstract: A landscape architect in China has a surprising strategy to help manage surges of water from storms supercharged by climate change.
lead_paragraph: Cities around the world face a daunting challenge in the era of climate change: Supercharged rainstorms are turning streets into rivers, flooding subway systems and inundating residential neighborhoods, often with deadly consequences.

headline: When Larry Met Jean-Michel
abstract: A new exhibition tells the dealer’s story of how two rising stars, Larry Gagosian and Jean-Michel Basquiat, worked together in Los Angeles in the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: In October 1981, when the art dealer Larry Gagosian first laid eyes on a painting by Jean-Michel Basquiat, he had never heard of the artist. “My hair stood on end,” he said of seeing the 20-year-old’s work. Just six months later, when Basquiat opened a solo show at Gagosian’s gallery in West Hollywood, the place, Gagosian recalled in an interview, “was absolutely mobbed.”

headline: ‘Winners and Losers’ as $20 Fast-Food Wage Nears in California
abstract: The nation’s highest state minimum wage for fast-food workers takes effect on Monday. Owners and employees are sizing up the potential impact.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Jamie Bynum poured his life savings into a barbecue restaurant now tucked between a Thai eatery and a nutrition store in a Southern California strip mall.

headline: ‘The Listener’ Review: The Side Effects of Pandemic Living
abstract: Tessa Thompson’s still and luminous performance makes this post-Covid drama about loneliness, directed by Steve Buscemi, worth watching.
lead_paragraph: “The Listener” — directed by Steve Buscemi — opens with the sound of an unanswered phone and the thrum of a city before turning its lens on Tessa Thompson’s character, who lies in bed, staring upward, before beginning her late shift as the crisis helpline volunteer “Beth.” Written by Alessandro Camon and shot in 2021, this hushed drama takes on a pandemic many Americans experienced and continue to, even post-quarantine: loneliness.

headline: ‘Wicked Little Letters’ Review: Prim, Proper and Profane
abstract: Olivia Colman and Jessie Buckley elevate a comedy about a weird true tale of defamation and dirty words.
lead_paragraph: “This is more true than you’d think,” handwritten text informs us at the start of “Wicked Little Letters.” I looked it up, and they weren’t kidding. The movie involves tweaks and elisions to history, of course. But at least in its major outlines, the true story matches the film, in which a dour spinster named Edith Swan (Olivia Colman) and her raucous next-door neighbor Rose Gooding (Jessie Buckley) tangle over a series of mysteriously obscene letters that started arriving at the homes of people in the English coast village of Littlehampton in 1920. As you may intuit, this movie belongs to a very particular subgenre summed up in one declaration: boy, small English towns are full of weirdos.

headline: How Much Higher Are Your Post-Pandemic Property Taxes?
abstract: Real estate taxes on single-family homes increased about 24 percent from 2019 to 2023.
lead_paragraph: The median price for a single-family home in the United States rose about 40 percent from 2019 to 2022, peaking at $480,000 before receding to about $417,000 at the close of 2023. The higher home prices have led to higher property taxes, adding even more to a monthly housing budget. A recent study by CoreLogic found that from 2019 through 2023, the median U.S. single-family property-tax bill rose by about 24 percent, to about $2,826.

headline: A Building With Possibilities, on East 77th Street, Is Listed for $18 Million
abstract: The estate of Maurice Kanbar, an entrepreneur, is selling his Upper East Side home. There is an art gallery on the first two floors and four vacant rental apartments upstairs.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Kanbar never saw the sense in accepting things as they were. The lifelong inventor and entrepreneur, who died in 2022 at age 93, developed, among other things, a comb for “defuzzing” sweaters, New York’s first multiplex cinema, and Skyy vodka, which he — somewhat dubiously — claimed wouldn’t leave you with a hangover.

headline: No Eclipse Plans? Try These Last-Minute Strategies.
abstract: On April 8, parts of 13 U.S. states, Mexico and Canada will plunge into midday darkness. Miss this spectacle and you’ll have to wait till 2044 for the next one so close to home.
lead_paragraph: On April 8, a total solar eclipse will blot out the sun for roughly 4,200 miles stretching from Mexico to Canada — a cosmic show that so much of North America won’t see again for about 20 years. Many made their plans to view it well in advance.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: Julia Perry’s Violin Concerto, a collection of Copland works conducted by Copland and a program of songs by Black composers are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Julia Perry, who would have turned 100 this month, achieved some real recognition during her lifetime, but — in a tale all too common for composers who aren’t white men — fell into obscurity after her death in 1979. There have been recent efforts to revive her works, including her Violin Concerto, written in the 1960s and now recorded by the Experiential Orchestra under James Blachly, with Curtis Stewart as the soloist.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and on Staten Island
abstract: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, Hell’s Kitchen and St. George.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,140-square-foot apartment with an open floor plan, a breakfast bar, a dining alcove, a primary suite with a walk-in closet and a balcony on the 11th floor of a 19-story doorman building with a live-in super, a package room, shared laundry, a bike room, parking, a gym, a children’s playroom, a residents’ lounge and a waiting list for basement storage cages. James Michael Angelo, Christie’s International Real Estate, 917-373-8343; christiesrealestate.com

headline: Is Threads the Good Place?
abstract: An alternative to X, it turns out, is just another battlefield.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time on social media, the nicest app of them all, Instagram, home to animal bloopers and filtered selfies, established a land called Threads, a hospitable alternative to the cursed X, Formerly Known as Twitter. X had been taken over by the Dark Lord Musk, he who reopened X’s gateway to its banished demons Donald Trump, Kanye West and Andrew Tate.

headline: With This Ring, I Unwed
abstract: The model Emily Ratajkowski’s “divorce rings” are part of a trend for jewelry that signals a new beginning after a marriage ends.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Emily Ratajkowski shared on Instagram that she had created a pair of “divorce rings” by remodeling the pear- and princess-cut diamonds from her toi et moi engagement ring into two separate rings. Alison Chemla, a New York-based jeweler and creative director at Alison Lou (who also crafted Ms. Ratajkowski’s original engagement ring), created the new pieces. The post has since received over one million likes.

headline: The Ellis Island Museum Gets a Face-Lift
abstract: The museum, opened 34 years ago in a 19th-century building, will be refurbished and reimagined, the president of the foundation that operates it said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why a construction trailer has arrived at the museum on Ellis Island. We’ll also get details on a significant vote on the congestion pricing plan.

headline: How to Deal With a Narcissist
abstract: In her best-selling self-help book, Ramani Durvasula offers tips for surviving a person who only has eyes for mirrors.
lead_paragraph: “Narcissist” is a word many of us throw around casually, using it to describe anyone from an energy vampire to a friend who posts too many selfies on Instagram. But as Ramani Durvasula makes clear in her best-selling book, “It’s Not You,” the people who actually fit the bill are more complicated, wily and attention-seeking than we might imagine. She focuses on the ones who fall in the middle of the spectrum — those toxic charmers who, she writes, give you “enough bad days to take a toll and enough good days to keep you hooked.”

headline: The Menu That Has Made One José Andrés Restaurant Endure
abstract: A look behind the scenes at Zaytinya, which over two decades has remained one of the globe-trotting humanitarian’s most beloved spots.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon this January, I watched the celebrity chef José Andrés flip through the page proofs of his newest cookbook, “Zaytinya.” He had the pages spread out over the glass top of a custom-made foosball table inside the Washington, D.C., headquarters of the sprawling food group that bears his name. Here Andrés was like a king in his throne room. The José Andrés Group now directs more than 30 eateries — from a two-Michelin-starred restaurant to a food truck — as well as retail products, a podcast, newsletters and television programs. (His charitable organization, World Central Kitchen, runs through a separate nonprofit.)

headline: How A.I. Chatbots Become Political
abstract: We may soon rely a lot on A.I. chatbots, so keeping an eye on their political leanings is becoming more and more important.
lead_paragraph: We may soon rely a lot on A.I. chatbots, so keeping an eye on their political leanings is becoming more and more important.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Paramus, N.J., and Chappaqua, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-bath house built in 1950 but fully remodeled this year, featuring an open kitchen with a center island, dining area and living rooms and a separate family room and bedroom suite, four other bedrooms, a finished basement and one-car attached garage, a deck and a fenced yard on 0.25 acres. Besmir Vatoci, Realty One Group Legend, 201-294-2885; realtyonegroup.com

headline: ‘Hey, Meta, What Am I Looking At?’
abstract: What happens when a columnist and a reporter use A.I. glasses to scan groceries, monuments and zoo animals?
lead_paragraph: What happens when a columnist and a reporter use A.I. glasses to scan groceries, monuments and zoo animals?

headline: In Raymond Saunders’s Paintings, an Education on How to Rebel
abstract: “Post No Bills,” a four-decade overview of the artist’s work, is a sprawling map of his searching mind and hard-to-categorize work.
lead_paragraph: As much as they are works of art, the assemblage-like paintings of Raymond Saunders are works of archaeology.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Epic Fail in Puerto Rico
abstract: While she did not toss paper towels, her visit was what Puerto Ricans call a papelón — an embarrassing spectacle.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris arrived in San Juan, P.R., last Friday for her first official visit as vice president. The trip was meant, in part, to highlight the Biden administration’s dedication to aiding the island’s recovery. What unfolded instead was a revealing tableau of Democrats’ missteps and misjudgments.

headline: Tired of Doomscrolling? Try Ringing a Doorbell for Fish.
abstract: Viewers are glued to an underwater livestream meant to help fish migration in the Netherlands. Devotees welcome the distraction — and the chance to help a fish get frisky.
lead_paragraph: When friends visit Aliza Haskal’s apartment in Syracuse, N.Y., she offers them gripping entertainment: a live feed from a camera six feet below the surface of a cloudy river in the Netherlands.

headline: Meta’s Smart Glasses Are Becoming Artificially Intelligent. We Took Them for a Spin.
abstract: What happens when a columnist and a reporter use A.I. glasses to scan groceries, monuments and zoo animals? Hilarity, wonder and lots of mistakes ensued.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that the tech industry keeps getting weirder, Meta soon plans to release a big update that transforms the Ray-Ban Meta, its camera glasses that shoot videos, into a gadget seen only in sci-fi movies.

headline: Bogus Election Fraud Claims Still Run Rampant in Maricopa County
abstract: Ever since Donald Trump’s 2020 loss, election officials in Arizona’s largest county have faced relentless harassment. But one official got good news this week in a defamation case against Kari Lake.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after Joseph R. Biden Jr. flipped Arizona blue, the state — and in particular its largest county, Maricopa — remains a hub for debunked claims of election fraud.

headline: What About the People Who Don’t Vote?
abstract: Lessons from nonvoters and what might change their minds.
lead_paragraph: The people who don’t vote are often left out of the political conversation. Campaigns don’t spend much money on them, and the media doesn’t devote much coverage to them. But to understand a presidential contest like the 2024 race — one that threatens to be extremely close — we have to understand not just the people who show up to vote, but also those who sit out elections.

headline: Biden, Fighting for Credit and Raising Cash, Gets Help From Clinton and Obama
abstract: A fund-raiser on Thursday intends to raise $25 million to help re-elect the president, who has amassed a roster of achievements, but whose approval ratings are the lowest of the three.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will lock arms with two of his Democratic predecessors at a campaign fund-raising event on Thursday evening in New York City, a public display of support from the two men who understand like few others what he faces.

headline: The Japanese Sensei Bringing Baseball to Brazil
abstract: Once a semipro baseball player in Japan, Yukihiro Shimura has now become a baseball missionary.
lead_paragraph: Yukihiro Shimura always arrives first. He quietly puts on his baseball uniform. He rakes the dirt field meditatively. He picks up the coconut husks and dog poop. And, finally, when he finishes, he bows to Rio de Janeiro’s only baseball field.

headline: What Author Would You Most Like to Meet?
abstract: Has a book ever touched you so personally that you felt a deep connection to the writer?
lead_paragraph: Has a book ever made such a big impression on you that you felt a deep connection with the author? Perhaps you found it to be extremely moving, or you thought it spoke directly to your experiences in life.

headline: Who Would Want to Go to a College Like This?
abstract: The national debate about so-called woke campuses does not reflect what most college students care about.
lead_paragraph: The moral panic about “woke” campuses has metastasized into actual legislation, and not just in the swampy idylls of Florida. Last week the governor of Alabama signed a bill that purports to limit the teaching of “divisive” topics in its colleges and universities. The bill is similar to Florida’s ban on diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives in public colleges, which was signed into law last May. Both are all-out attacks on learning by excommunicating liberal ideas from the classroom. Other state legislatures have also been busy. The Chronicle of Higher Education reports that Republican lawmakers have proposed 81 anti-D.E.I. bills across 28 states. (So far, 33 haven’t become law, and 11 have.)

headline: A Simple New Technique Could Make Your Eggs More Humane
abstract: A system that determines the sex of chicks before they hatch eliminates the need to destroy young males.
lead_paragraph: The egg industry hides a dark secret.

headline: Before Beyoncé: Black Artists Who Crossed Over to Country
abstract: From the Pointer Sisters to Darius Rucker, a brief history of those who paved the way for this moment.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s new album “Cowboy Carter” releases tonight at midnight, and still very little is known. She has released two songs from the record and a track list. “Texas Hold ’Em”  hit No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot Country Songs chart, making her the first Black woman to hold that spot. But of course Beyoncé is not the first Black pop artist to try her hand at the genre. Hank Shteamer, our music writer, spotlights other Black artists who helped pave the way to this moment.

headline: 4 Takeaways About Boeing’s Quality Problems
abstract: The company’s issues date back years, employees said, and were compounded by the pandemic, when it lost thousands of experienced workers.
lead_paragraph: Boeing has faced intense scrutiny and pressure since a panel blew off a 737 Max 9 shortly after the plane, an Alaska Airlines flight, took off on Jan. 5. The episode raised fresh questions about the quality of the planes the company produces several years after two Max 8 planes crashed, killing nearly 350 people.

headline: Use Your Allusion: See How Many Literary References You Recognize
abstract: Put your cultural knowledge to the test with these 12 questions.
lead_paragraph: Put your cultural knowledge to the test with these 12 questions.

headline: On the Upper West Side, a Good Kitchen and Room to Grow: Which Home Did They Choose?
abstract: Looking to explore a new neighborhood in Manhattan and create a better work setup, a couple embarked on a search for a prewar two-bedroom.
lead_paragraph: Looking to explore a new neighborhood in Manhattan and create a better work setup, a couple embarked on a search for a prewar two-bedroom.

headline: Biden Administration Finalizes Rule Curbing Use of Short-Term Health Plans
abstract: The new regulation reverses a Trump-era policy that expanded access to health plans with fewer benefits than those sold on the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Thursday that it had finalized a new regulation that curbs the use of short-term health insurance plans that do not comply with the Affordable Care Act, reversing a move by the Trump administration to give consumers more access to cheaper but skimpier plans.

headline: The Many Ways Men’s Sweet 16 Players Are Being Paid
abstract: Every team in the Sweet 16 round has been touched by “name, image and likeness” rules, which allow student athletes to be paid for endorsements, appearances and other work.
lead_paragraph: Every team in the Sweet 16 round has been touched by “name, image and likeness” rules, which allow student athletes to be paid for endorsements, appearances and other work.

headline: The Dali Is a Big Ship. But Not the Biggest.
abstract: The ship that crashed into the bridge in Baltimore holds barely half of what some of the largest container ships these days can carry — a sign of how huge the industry has become.
lead_paragraph: The ship that crashed into the bridge in Baltimore holds barely half of what some of the largest container ships these days can carry — a sign of how huge the industry has become.

headline: The Overlooked Truths About Biden’s Age
abstract: The president is a decision maker, not an action figure.
lead_paragraph: In terms of optics and in terms of energy, I wish President Biden were younger. There’s no point in pretending otherwise. And from the casual conversations all around me and the formal polling of voters, I know I’m in robust company. A great many Americans consider his age unideal, and that belief is why there’s no wishing away the focus on it. The swell of attention to it over the past few months is more beginning than end. There are tsunamis yet to come.

headline: The Newest Tech Start-Up Billionaire? Donald Trump.
abstract: Trump Media, which went public this week, attracted a frenzy of interest on its first day of trading.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, Donald Trump’s social media platform, Truth Social, has been dismissed as a money-losing boondoggle.

headline: Inside the Scramble to Evacuate the Bridge, and an Investigation Into Boeing’s Safety Record
abstract: Plus, the man who was nearly vice president.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Crisis-Hit British Museum Gets New Leader
abstract: Nicholas Cullinan will take over the London institution as it faces the fallout from a theft scandal and calls for the return of objects in its collection.
lead_paragraph: The British Museum on Thursday named Nicholas Cullinan, an art historian who currently runs the National Portrait Gallery in London, as its new director, ending an unsettled period in which the august institution lacked a permanent leader.

headline: The World’s Unpopular Leaders
abstract: Why Biden isn’t alone with his low approval ratings.
lead_paragraph: By many measures, President Biden is very unpopular. Since at least World War II, no president has had a worse disapproval rating at this point in his term.

headline: What We Know About Palestinians Detained in Israel
abstract: Since Oct. 7, Israel has detained thousands of Palestinians suspected of militant activity. Rights groups allege that Israel has abused some detainees or held them without charges.
lead_paragraph: More than 9,000 Palestinians imprisoned under Israel’s military and national security laws are being held in Israeli detention facilities, the highest figure in more than a decade, according to rights groups, who say that many of the detainees are being held without charges and have been abused while in custody.

headline: ‘Asphalt City’ Review: Arbiters of Life and Death
abstract: Sean Penn plays a flinty paramedic showing a rookie the ropes in this maddening drama about emergency medical workers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Two paramedics — Ollie Cross (Tye Sheridan), a wide-eyed rookie, and Gene Rutkovsky (Sean Penn), a gruff veteran of the trade — traverse the mean streets of East New York, Brooklyn, by ambulance in the solemn drama “Asphalt City.” Flooded with neon and sirens, the movie opens during Cross’s first nights on the corps, tracking his and his new partner’s efforts to provide care for an array of challenging patients.

headline: ‘The Beautiful Game’ Review: A Different Kind of World Cup
abstract: This heart-string-tugging Netflix movie about a homeless soccer team, featuring Bill Nighy and Micheal Ward, puts the emphasis on play and uplift.
lead_paragraph: It’s moderately surprising that it’s taken filmmakers two decades to concoct a heart-string-tugging underdog story out of the annual coed sport event known as the Homeless World Cup, a weeklong international competition featuring homeless soccer players.

headline: ‘Lousy Carter’ Review: Blackboard Bungle
abstract: A college professor gets a grim diagnosis in this comedy from Bob Byington.
lead_paragraph: Death be not tragic in “Lousy Carter,” a repellently watchable curiosity from the Austin cult filmmaker Bob Byington. Carter (David Krumholtz) is a self-involved literature professor with little interest in his students, his family, and his past and present lovers. So when he’s given six months to live, no one cares. Turn the concept of a laugh-out-loud comedy inside-out and you’ll have a feel for Byington’s sense of humor: a sustained cruel hum, the room tone of a crypt.

headline: ‘DogMan’ Review: Crackers for Animals
abstract: An electrifying Caleb Landry Jones plays the damaged heart of this oddly wonderful tale of resilience and revenge.
lead_paragraph: Drag queens, disability and dozens of canines converge in Luc Besson’s “DogMan,” which opens with a quotation from a 19th-century French poet and closes with a symbolic crucifixion. In between is the strangest, possibly silliest movie of the veteran director’s idiosyncratic career. It is also borderline brilliant.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: Ethan Coen’s survey of a rock ’n’ roll icon, Frederick Wiseman’s take on haute cuisine and a searing portrait of PTSD are this month’s picks.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Life Magazine Will Come Back to, Well, Life
abstract: The investor Josh Kushner and his wife, Karlie Kloss, have struck a deal with Barry Diller’s media company to revive it as a regular print title.
lead_paragraph: Life, the iconic photography-focused chronicler of the 20th century, has taken on many forms, including a weekly magazine, a website and the occasional special issue.

headline: U.C. Berkeley Parents Hired Private Security to Patrol Near Campus
abstract: The parents were worried about crime, but the university said that the move raised concerns about training and experience, and that security was better left to its own police force.
lead_paragraph: Some parents of students at the University of California, Berkeley, hired private security workers to patrol near the campus, something the school says should be left up to the campus police.

headline: Just How Wet Has California’s Rainy Season Been?
abstract: Before the season officially ends on Sunday, another storm is headed for the California coast.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, California’s rainy season officially comes to an end.

headline: Bold Tiles in 64 Different Shades
abstract: Plus: a Venetian retreat, hand-knotted rugs and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: If Indiana Jones took a turn toward the elegant and developed an obsession with textiles, he might be a bit like Louis Barthélemy, the French illustrator and designer who travels to Africa and the Middle East to work with weavers and craftspeople who are skilled in traditional techniques. Ishkar, a London-based company that collaborates with NGOs and artisans to create job opportunities for those living in isolated areas of countries often affected by war, recently commissioned him to create a capsule collection with women weavers in Afghanistan. Barthélemy typically works with artisans in person to create tapestries or rugs but, since the Taliban retook power in 2021, he’s had to connect with the weavers remotely. At the start of their collaboration, Barthélemy asked the weavers to draw a place that symbolized beauty to them. Many of the women chose the 14th-century Bagh-e Babur (Babur’s Garden) in Kabul. Images from those drawings, and one by Barthélemy himself, were then combined to create the patterns for three different rugs. Each one took about six months for the women to hand knot from Ghazni Wool. They are, Barthélemy says, “a collective dream of an ancient paradise.” The rugs can be seen in London at Sunbury Workshops on Swanfield Street from April 24-26, and through September at the Ishkar flagship showroom; from about $4,000, ishkar.com.

headline: Old Newspaper Stories Offer Clues to 19th-Century Shipwreck in Lake Michigan
abstract: It took researchers only two days to find the wreckage of the Milwaukee, a steamship that sank in 1886 after colliding with another ship. They were guided by details from newspaper accounts of the accident.
lead_paragraph: On July 9, 1886, the steamship Milwaukee was crossing Lake Michigan on its way to the lakefront town of Muskegon, Mich., to pick up a load of lumber when disaster struck.

headline: A Fiery Finale for a Rocket That Brings the Heat
abstract: The Delta IV Heavy, a rocket that briefly bursts into flame just before it lifts off, is set to launch for the last time soon.
lead_paragraph: The ignition of the Delta IV Heavy rocket is perhaps the most visually striking liftoff you’ll ever see — the rocket seemingly burns itself up on the launchpad before it heads to space. Now, the very last Delta IV Heavy ever is on the launchpad.

headline: Lawsuits Accuse 2 Michigan Jails of Banning Family Visits to Increase Revenue
abstract: The suits contend that two counties entered into agreements with telecommunications companies that would bring more money because of increased use of phone calls and electronic messaging.
lead_paragraph: Two county jails in Michigan banned in-person family visits for inmates several years ago as a way to boost county revenues from the increased number of phone calls and electronic messaging that resulted, a pair of lawsuits filed this month claim.

headline: The Revolutionary Power of Women’s Rage and Grief
abstract: Käthe Kollwitz’s fierce belief in social justice and her indelible images made her one of Germany’s best printmakers. A dazzling MoMA show reminds us why.
lead_paragraph: An artist friend texted me recently, asking how to contend with the anger and sadness she was feeling about the state of the world. I can think of no better balm than the Museum of Modern Art’s Käthe Kollwitz retrospective, the first ever at a New York museum that encompasses this German artist’s groundbreaking prints and drawings and her sculpture, posters and magazine illustrations.

headline: Biden Will Campaign Alongside Bill Clinton and Barack Obama
abstract: The star-studded event in New York City is aimed at building on the already significant financial advantage President Biden has over former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will depart Washington today for a two-day trip to New York, turning his attention away from swing states to campaign and raise funds in a liberal stronghold.

headline: When Richard Serra’s Steel Curves Became a Memorial
abstract: The sculptor had a breakthrough in the late 1990s with his torqued metal rings. Then the attack on the World Trade Center, which Serra witnessed, gave them a sudden new significance.
lead_paragraph: After the yelling, the hearings, the lawsuit, the dismantlement, Richard Serra entered the last decade of the last century with his mind cast toward the classics.

headline: The Last Coal-Fired Power Plants in New England Are to Close
abstract: The company that owns the Merrimack and Schiller stations in New Hampshire plans to turn them into solar farms and battery storage for offshore wind.
lead_paragraph: The last two coal-fired power plants in New England are set to close by 2025 and 2028, ending the use of a fossil fuel that supplied electricity to the region for more than 50 years.

headline: Health Concerns Mount for Migrant Children at Outdoor Waiting Sites
abstract: A federal judge is expected to rule soon on whether the government must provide shelter, food and medical care to minors while they await processing.
lead_paragraph: To Dr. Theresa Cheng, the scene was “apocalyptic.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 10, 2024
abstract: What do you notice about how electricity generation around the world is changing? What do you wonder?
lead_paragraph: The above graph was previously published in The New York Times. The data, which excludes both imports and exports, is a 2022 estimate made by Ember, an energy think tank. The hydroelectric category includes other renewable sources of power besides wind and solar. The oil category includes fossil fuels besides coal and gas.

headline: Live Like Karl
abstract: What happened when Karl Lagerfeld’s last residence, where he worked and where Choupette lived, was offered at auction.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld was a mega-collector. Of high-collared white shirts (1,000). Of books (300,000). Of period décor (Art Deco, Memphis Group, 18th-century European). And of homes — at least 20, in Europe and in New York.

headline: Metro Boomin Is Headed to No. 1 (Again). Here’s a Guide to His Music.
abstract: The producer has helped shape rap for the past decade, providing moody beats for Atlanta’s biggest stars and beyond. His latest LP, with Future, arrived last week.
lead_paragraph: Since 2013, Metro Boomin has crafted the beats behind more than 75 songs that reached Billboard’s Hot 100, including 12 Top 10 hits. The Atlanta-via-St. Louis producer has turned contemporary radio into a shadowy world of nocturnal 808 drums and sinister synths while providing breakout moments for Atlanta rappers including Future, Migos and 21 Savage.

headline: ‘A Chance to Live’: How 2 Families Faced a Catastrophic Birth Defect
abstract: Cases of trisomy 18 may rise as many states restrict abortion. But some women choose to have the babies, love them tenderly and care for them devotedly.
lead_paragraph: Ashlee Wiseman, a waitress at a Sizzler in Idaho Falls, Idaho, was 10 weeks pregnant when a nurse phoned with crushing news: a test of fetal DNA in her blood had found that her baby girl had trisomy 18, a catastrophic genetic abnormality, and was unlikely to survive.

headline: Are You Getting the Most Out of Your Sheet Pan?
abstract: Sheet-pan japchae makes easy work of caramelizing a rainbow of vegetables before tossing with noodles.
lead_paragraph: Hello! It’s Eric Kim, reporting for duty and filling in for Mia Leimkuhler this week. How are we doing today?

headline: U.S. Officials Order Better Tracking of a Political Flashpoint: America’s Diversity
abstract: New survey questions in federal forms will draw a more detailed portrait of racial and ethnic origins. Officials point to the benefits, but the changes could face a conservative backlash.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration ordered changes to a range of federal surveys on Thursday to gather more detailed information about the nation’s ethnic and racial makeup.

headline: Valentino Enters Its Alessandro Michele Era

lead_paragraph: The song has stopped in at least one game of fashion musical chairs. Valentino has a new creative director: Alessandro Michele, the former Gucci designer who left that brand in 2022.

headline: Ireland to Intervene in South Africa’s Genocide Case Against Israel at the World Court
abstract: Ireland did not outline the argument it planned to advance at the court, but the country’s lawmakers have made repeated calls to prioritize the protection of civilians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Ireland plans to file an argument in South Africa’s genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, according to the Irish government, making the move as the country has strongly condemned Israel’s actions against civilians in Gaza.

headline: Matt Schlapp Accuser Dropped Groping Lawsuit After a $480,000 Settlement
abstract: A Republican operative dropped the lawsuit against Mr. Schlapp, the head of one of the nation’s largest conservative advocacy groups, this week.

headline: ‘On the Adamant’ Review: A Psychiatric Facility on the Seine
abstract: This documentary by Nicolas Philibert drifts along, with unnamed patients and their caretakers, on a large houseboat in Paris.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to tell the difference between the patients and staff in “On the Adamant,” Nicolas Philibert’s documentary about an alternative psychiatric facility in Paris. The treatment center, located in a large houseboat with louvered windows, floats tranquilly on the Seine.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Sentenced to 25 Years in Prison
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried, who was convicted of stealing $8 billion from customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, faced a maximum sentence of 110 years.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange who was convicted of stealing billions of dollars from customers, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Thursday, capping an extraordinary saga that upended the crypto industry and became a cautionary tale of greed and hubris.

headline: How Sam Bankman-Fried’s Sentence Compares With Other White-Collar Cases
abstract: Here’s how the former crypto mogul’s 25-year sentence stacks up against the prosecutions of Michael Milken, Bernie Madoff and others.
lead_paragraph: Two years in prison for tax and securities violations. Eleven years for deceiving investors. A 150-year sentence for the largest Ponzi scheme in history.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: A Fun Historical Crime Drama
abstract: In its best and most exciting moments, “Manhunt” is the only show brilliant enough to ask: Why can’t Abraham Lincoln be in the “The Fugitive”?
lead_paragraph: So much of “Manhunt” is a deft modern chase thriller that one can almost feel the phantom F.B.I. windbreakers. You’d swear you can hear a ’90s office phone ringing, or that someone’s face is lit only by their late-night computer session. Yes, there’s an investigator’s crazy wall, but those photos aren’t 8x10s. They’re milky tintypes, because it is 1865, and we’re chasing John Wilkes Booth.

headline: At Tiffany’s Flagship, Luxe Art Helps Sell the Jewels
abstract: Turrell. Hirst. Basquiat: This 10-story palace is filled with famous names, for a heady fusion of relevant, and discomfiting, contemporary art and retailing.
lead_paragraph: Now that tickets to the Museum of Modern Art are priced at an astonishing $30 apiece, you could be forgiven for timing your visits carefully, making sure that they count.

headline: ‘Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire’ Review: Running Out of Steam
abstract: The latest in the Warner Bros. Monsterverse franchise shows signs of an anemic imagination.
lead_paragraph: Nothing about “Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire” makes sense, which is not, on the face of it, a problem. We have not settled into cushy cinema seats with our comfortingly stale popcorn to engage in discourse about metaphors and science; we are here for the stars in the title. About that title: “Godzilla x Kong” (meant to echo various other titles in other, non-Hollywood Godzilla movies) could mean Godzilla times Kong, or Godzilla crossed with Kong, or Godzilla against Kong — some permutation of titans. Whatever it is, there will be punching. We are here for the punching.

headline: Biden Administration Restores Wildlife Protections Weakened Under Trump
abstract: The rules give federal officials more leeway to protect species in a changing climate. Industry groups are expected to sue.
lead_paragraph: After three years of planning and navigating the slow bureaucracy of federal rule-making, the Biden administration is restoring a series of protections for imperiled animals and plants that had been loosened under President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Credit Card Swipe Fees Are Going Down. Are Points Going With Them?
abstract: A new agreement by Visa and Mastercard to reduce fees charged to merchants may drain the lucrative rewards that grant free travel to many credit card users.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the largest credit card companies in the United States reached an agreement with merchants to reduce the so-called swipe fees retailers pay for accepting credit card payments, potentially saving the retailers $30 billion.

headline: New York Will Test Gun-Detecting Technology in Subway System, Mayor Says

lead_paragraph: For almost two years, I had managed to avoid a New York inevitability: attending an improv comedy show. That streak came to an end this month.

headline: They Were Punched and Took to TikTok
abstract: Several young women have posted video accounts of being hit by a stranger, touching off apprehension and concern.
lead_paragraph: A series of viral videos from several young female TikTok users, who posted emotional dispatches about getting punched on city streets, caused concern this week about the topic among fans online.

headline: When Sean Combs Was ‘Living the American Dream’

lead_paragraph: While most experts agree that you should wear sunscreen year-round to prevent damage from the sun, harmful ultraviolet rays are strongest during the late spring and early summer.

headline: ‘La Chimera’ Review: A Treasure Trove
abstract: In her latest dreamy movie, the Italian director Alice Rohrwacher follows a tomb raider, played by Josh O’Connor, who’s pining for a lost love.
lead_paragraph: Like the yellow brick road, the bright red thread in “La Chimera” winds through a world that is both dreamy and touched by magic. The thread has begun unraveling from a long knit dress worn by a woman beloved by the movie’s hero. It trails across the ground, flutters in the air and beguiles you, just like this film. And, like all loose threads — in fraying fabric and in certain stories — this slender cord tempts you to pull it, urging you to see what happens next.

Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary. headline: What We Know About the Crew on the Ship That Hit the Baltimore Bridge

headline: Film Club: ‘Island in Between’

lead_paragraph: In “Island in Between,” an Oscar-nominated 19-minute Op-Docs video, the filmmaker S. Leo Chiang reflects on his relationship with Taiwan, the United States and China from the islands of Kinmen, just a few miles from mainland China. Having split the last 15 years of his life going between the three, Chiang says, “More and more, I feel like a kid whose parents are involved in a three-way custody battle — hostile, codependent, manipulative, each pair with their own dysfunctions. They all think they know what’s best for me. They don’t care what I want.”

headline: Linda Bean, an L.L. Bean Heir and a Conservative Donor, Dies at 82
abstract: A granddaughter of the celebrated Maine brand’s founder, she set out as an entrepreneur in her mid-60s and used her wealth to fund right-wing causes.
lead_paragraph: Linda Bean, an heir to the Maine outdoor retailer L.L. Bean who created a company of her own to market other famous Maine products, chiefly lobster rolls and seaside rentals, and who was an outspoken conservative in a state with a tradition of favoring political independents, died on Saturday. She was 82.

headline: Send the Hosts of ‘Serial’ Season 4 Your Questions About the Podcast
abstract: As you listen to the new season, which features insider stories of life at Guantánamo Bay, share your questions with the hosts, Sarah Koenig and Dana Chivvis.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve listened to “Serial” before, you know that we’re interested in criminal justice stories. Our new season, which kicks off this week, is about Guantánamo — a justice system unlike any other. Guantánamo is the prison and court that the U.S. built after 9/11 to hold people suspected of being members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

headline: U.K. Backsliding on Civil and Political Protections, U.N. Rights Body Says

headline: Vernor Vinge, Innovative Science Fiction Novelist, Dies at 79

So in the early 2000s he found his way to Baltimore, a city where strivers have long found a home and where Mr. López made one for himself and his family.

headline: Friday Briefing: Sam Bankman-Fried Gets 25 Years
abstract: Plus, three video game adventures for the weekend.

Bankman-Fried was also ordered to forfeit $11.2 billion in assets.

headline: Having Trouble With Your Homeowners Insurance? Tell Us.

headline: Robert Moskowitz, Abstract Painter of New York’s Skyscrapers, Dies at 88

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

So is Oyeyemi, who was one of Granta’s “Best Young British Novelists” in 2013, while Orange, at 42, has won the PEN/Hemingway Award, the John Leonard Prize and the American Book Award. The future is in good hands.)

abstract: President Biden raised $25 million at a Radio City Music Hall event, adding to his huge cash edge, after Donald Trump pushed his law-and-order message at a wake for a police officer killed on duty.
lead_paragraph: The epicenter of the presidential campaign shifted to New York on Thursday, as the incumbent president and three of his predecessors descended on the area for dueling events that illustrated the kinds of political clashes that could come to define the general election.

headline: The Rent Was Too High So They Threw a Party
abstract: During the Harlem Renaissance, some Black people hosted rent parties, celebrations with an undercurrent of desperation in the face of racism and discrimination.
lead_paragraph: During the Harlem Renaissance, some Black people hosted rent parties, celebrations with an undercurrent of desperation in the face of racism and discrimination.

headline: Review: ‘Tommy’ Goes Full Tilt in a Relentless Broadway Revival
abstract: Will the Who’s rock opera about a traumatized boy hit the jackpot again?
lead_paragraph: That its plot makes no sense is not really the problem with “Tommy.” When it first appeared as a concept album, in 1969, it was, after all, billed as a rock opera. And let’s face it, if you’ve ever paid attention to its story unstoned, you’re going to have some questions, just as you might with “The Magic Flute.”

headline: Sweet Message Bearer
abstract: Jake Bunch makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: To solve Sam Ezersky’s puzzle, go forward (and sideways, and backward).
lead_paragraph: MARCHING BANDS — This grid, which is wide open except for one black square in the center, has a little bit in common with a regular crossword puzzle, and a little bit that’s different. On the similar side, there are two sets of clues, and every letter is used by two entries. However, there are no spaces between words, and one set of clues solves to entries that run in four directions — down, across, up and backward. This makes for a fun challenge.

headline: Shohei Ohtani Is Home and Focused on Baseball. Dodgers Fans Are Relieved.
abstract: Los Angeles finally got a close look at baseball’s megastar on Thursday, as a gambling situation involving his former interpreter took a back seat to opening day.
lead_paragraph: The top deck of Dodger Stadium is far from the action but may have the best view in baseball. Straight ahead are the San Gabriel Mountains. During night games, as the sun goes down, the sky glows pink. Down below, the full choreography of the game is on display, offering a panoramic view shunned by the movie stars and moguls who fill the sections behind home plate.

headline: A River Awakens, Bringing Green Magic to a Desert Town
abstract: After a stunning week of rain, the Todd River in Alice Springs flows once again, bringing a beleaguered community together.
lead_paragraph: Whenever there’s rain in the forecast for the desert town of Mparntwe, otherwise known as Alice Springs, the same question usually surfaces: “Do you think the Todd will flow?”

headline: Woman Who Received 5-Year Sentence in Voter Fraud Case Is Acquitted
abstract: A Texas appeals court reversed its earlier opinion that had upheld the conviction of Crystal Mason, who was found guilty of illegally casting a provisional ballot in 2016, even though she claimed she hadn’t known she was ineligible to vote.
lead_paragraph: In a case that has prompted outrage from voting-rights activists for years, a Texas appeals court reversed itself on Thursday and acquitted a woman who had been sentenced to five years in prison for illegally casting a provisional ballot in the 2016 election.

headline: Georgia Lawmakers Approve Tougher Rules on Immigration After Student’s Killing
abstract: A bill prompted by the death of Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student, would force law enforcement agencies to report undocumented immigrants to federal officials.
lead_paragraph: Georgia lawmakers voted on Thursday to tighten the state’s already strict immigration laws in response to the killing of Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student, whose death became ensnared in the broader fight over immigration policy after a man from Venezuela who entered the country illegally was charged with her murder.

headline: Fish Stew and Black Fettuccine, an Unexpected Recipe for Love
abstract: Maxwell Da Silva, who is from Brazil, and Jane Satsuk, who is from Russia, immediately connected over their “very humble beginnings.” But it was Mr. Da Silva’s cooking that won her heart.
lead_paragraph: It was Sept. 1, 2020, and Maxwell Dayvson Da Silva and Evgenia Satsuk were wearing masks during their first date at Leuca, an Italian restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He freaked her out just a bit when he asked her to lower her mask and kissed her.

headline: He Expresses Himself Through Art. She Through Math.
abstract: Alexandra Plzak and Sharif Farrag met in college and had very little in common on paper. But you know what they say about opposites.
lead_paragraph: The last weekend of February, Sharif Hussein Farrag, a ceramic artist, raced colorful clay rats that he sculpted and placed on motorized vehicles around a sports field outside the Santa Monica Airport.

headline: He Offered Her a Seat at His Table, and Later, a Place in His Heart
abstract: Arnim Kaiser and Pamela Grace were both out-of-towners dining alone in Arles, France. Their waitress was watching in the wings.
lead_paragraph: If accidental matchmakers got Yelp reviews, Pamela Grace and Arnim Ludwig Kaiser would give five stars to the waitress who served them on Oct. 11, 2022, at Le Plaza-La Paillotte, a restaurant in Arles, France. A half-star deduction for one too many tableside visits might be justified, though.

headline: After a Missed Connection, a Union of Mythic Proportions
abstract: After seeing Joelle Gamble’s “Lord of the Rings” tattoo on her dating profile, Zachary Copeland believed he had found his soul mate. But he would have to wait more than a year to find out.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Brian Lee Copeland’s dating app adventures in Washington, D.C., weren’t worthy of lunchtime discussion with his co-workers until the autumn of 2019, when he matched with Joelle Carissa Gamble on Hinge.

headline: How I Learned to Trust (Some) Men
abstract: When an Italian stranger approached me, I listened to my intuition, and it changed my life forever.
lead_paragraph: Too early in life, the male species began to fail me. As an adolescent, I was lied to, cheated on, harassed and assaulted. As a young adult, more of the same. Nevertheless, I ended up in a healthy marriage with a kind, trustworthy man. Sometimes I think it’s because of what happened that summer more than 30 years ago at the Vatican.

headline: No Corrections: March 29, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, March 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: One Architect’s Advice for Flood-Prone Cities: Act as a Sponge Would
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You cannot fight water. You have to adapt to it.”

headline: ‘Every Day Is Hard’: One Year Since Russia Jailed a U.S. Reporter
abstract: In a notorious high-security prison, Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal stays connected with supporters through letters as they keep up the pressure for his release.
lead_paragraph: One year ago on Friday, Ella Milman and Mikhail Gershkovich received a chilling phone call from the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. Their son, Evan, a foreign correspondent for The Journal who was on a reporting assignment in Russia, had missed his daily security check-in.

headline: Scheming and Sex in a Queer King’s Court
abstract: In the historical drama “Mary and George,” new on Starz, Julianne Moore plays an ambitious mother whose son catches the eye of King James I of England.
lead_paragraph: Standing in a shadowy archway on a bridge leading into Broughton Castle in Oxfordshire, England, sheep nibbling the grass below, Julianne Moore curtsied deeply, lowering her eyes before a splendidly gowned woman. “Your Majesty,” she began, before being drowned out by a loud “baa” from the sheep. Moore burst out laughing, as did her fellow actress, Trine Dyrholm, who was playing Queen Anne of England. “Talk to the sheep!” Moore commanded the director, Oliver Hermanus. “Tell them we’re doing a TV mini-series!”

headline: A Very Royal Scavenger Hunt
abstract: Taking part in mass online sleuthing can feel thrilling. But the same impulses can take a dark turn.
lead_paragraph: In 1933, a new craze took New York society by storm: the scavenger hunt. It began at a party that Elsa Maxwell, a prominent gossip columnist, threw at the Waldorf Astoria. Her guests were divided into small teams who competed against each other to obtain a list of items that included a live monkey, a red lantern and “the most beautiful woman in New York (not present at the party).”

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Is Here, and It’s Much More Than Country
abstract: The superstar’s new LP is a 27-track tour of popular music with a Beatles cover, cameos by Willie Nelson and Dolly Parton, and features from Miley Cyrus and Post Malone.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé has gone country, sure … but it turns out that’s only the half of it.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: One year since Russia jailed a U.S. reporter.
lead_paragraph: One year ago today, the Russian authorities detained Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, and accused him of spying for the U.S. government. He is the first American reporter since the end of the Cold War to be held on espionage charges in Russia.

headline: Putin’s Next Escalation Is Coming
abstract: Even without the terror attack in Moscow last week, the Russian president was primed to step up his assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the terrorist attack at Moscow’s Crocus City Hall last Friday, which killed at least 143 people, Russia is in mourning. The country’s leaders, on the other hand, are doing something else: They’re plotting.

headline: Word of the Day: extravaganza
abstract: This word has appeared in 90 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word extravaganza has appeared in 90 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 21 in “A Light Display With Many, but Not All, Glowing Reviews” by Ronda Kaysen:

headline: Trump’s Stock Is Rising, and Seth Meyers Is Skeptical
abstract: “I’m willing to bet most of the people investing in this company have never even used Truth Social,” Meyers said of Trump’s social media outlet on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Inside a High-Stakes Fight to Limit Social Media’s Hold on Children
abstract: A push by leading Democrats to restrict how social media companies use algorithms to serve content to children has been met by a high-stakes lobbying effort.
lead_paragraph: When New York’s governor and attorney general joined forces to pass a law trying to restrict social media companies’ ability to use algorithms to shape content for children, they expected Big Tech to put up a battle.

headline: A Reporter Appraises the State of Real Estate
abstract: Change is coming for many American home buyers and sellers, as well as the agents representing them. Debra Kamin, who covers real estate, explains the shift.
lead_paragraph: The American housing market is under renovation.

headline: Watching
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Breaking the Ramadan Fast With Some of Brooklyn’s Newest Arrivals
abstract: New migrants from Africa have joined a changing community in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where they have injected more youthful energy but also brought challenges.
lead_paragraph: The migrants in Bed-Stuy are mostly from Sudan and West Africa, and they have energized the neighborhood’s Muslim community. They bring youthful crowds to its mosques and businesses, but are also in desperate need of assistance and basic services, including food, long-term housing and work authorization.

headline: Glorious Germs, Ready for Their Close-Up
abstract: The micro becomes macro in Tal Danino’s surreal, mesmerizing photographs of bacteria.
lead_paragraph: Open “Micrographia” (1665), the otherworldly illustrated treatise by the microscopist Robert Hooke, and you’ll see why scientists have gone smaller and smaller ever since.

headline: A Twisty, Gloriously Grim Novel That Makes for Great Listening
abstract: A brother and sister battle for supremacy in 19th-century Newfoundland in Michael Crummey’s latest novel, “The Adversary.”
lead_paragraph: THE ADVERSARY, by Michael Crummey. Read by Mary Lewis.

headline: This Is the Way the World Ends (According to Novelists)
abstract: A new kind of disaster fiction is serving as scenario planning for real global crises. Call it the apocalyptic systems thriller.
lead_paragraph: In the opening chapters of “2054,” a new thriller co-written by Elliot Ackerman and Adm. James Stavridis, the action shifts every page or two — from a private jet, to the White House, to a Ritz-Carlton hotel, to Capitol Hill and elsewhere. The short sections are titled with locations and time stamps (including time zones) to signify global scope and high stakes. We understand at once that this is a story too big to be told from one perspective.

headline: From New England to Notre-Dame, a U.S. Carpenter Tends to a French Icon
abstract: Hank Silver, a timber framer based in Massachusetts, is one of a handful of foreigners who are helping to rebuild the Paris cathedral after the devastating fire in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Notre-Dame Cathedral sat in the pre-dawn chill like a spaceship docked in the heart of Paris, its exoskeleton of scaffolding lit by bright lights. Pink clouds appeared to the east as machinery hummed to life and workers started clambering around.

headline: Rise of the Ronin Sends Players Into a Chaotic Japan
abstract: Team Ninja showed its talent for finely tuned combat in games like Ninja Gaiden and Nioh. Its first open-world game presents new design challenges that are not always met.
lead_paragraph: After decades of designing linear video game adventures such as the Ninja Gaiden and Nioh series, Team Ninja has dropped the guardrails and loosed players into an open world.

headline: Our Bunnies, Ourselves
abstract: How the bunny became the reigning star of children’s literature.
lead_paragraph: We have a complicated relationship with bunnies.

headline: San Francisco’s ‘Twitter Menace’ or True Believer? He Might Be Both.
abstract: The deep pockets of the tech investor Garry Tan are valued by his allies, but his pugnacious online habits are creating plenty of enemies in the city he says he wants to save.
lead_paragraph: Under cathedral ceilings and soaring stained glass windows, Garry Tan clutched a microphone as he greeted a crowd of political centrists, including San Francisco’s mayor, local prosecutors and police brass.

headline: A Harsh Mongolian Winter Leaves Millions of Livestock Dead
abstract: Mass death caused by a weather event known in Mongolia as dzud has devastated herds, leaving thousands of families short of food.
lead_paragraph: An unusually brutal winter in Mongolia has left much of the country’s grazing land frozen and snow-covered, starving or freezing millions of animals and upending thousands of lives in a country where a third of the population depends on herding and agriculture to make a living.

headline: The Team Effort Behind One of Classical Music’s Greatest Hits
abstract: Gustav Holst composed “The Planets” with crucial help from others. Firsthand accounts and the score reflect how collaborative its creation was.
lead_paragraph: In 1916, the composer Gustav Holst took a young conductor, Adrian Boult, on a long walk through Kew Gardens and Richmond Park in London. A few years earlier, Boult had written to Holst asking whether he had composed any music for small orchestra that he could perform. On this day, though, they discussed a much grander prospect: a suite for large orchestra that would become “The Planets.”

headline: An Idyll on the Shores of a Toxic Lake
abstract: The town of Bombay Beach, Calif., offers its residents a tight-knit community in the midst of catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: There are two ways to experience the town of Bombay Beach, Calif., as a visitor: gawk at the spectacle or fall into the vortex. Thousands of tourists cruise through each year, often without getting out of their cars to see decaying art installations left over from an annual mid-March gathering of artists, photographers and documentarians known jokingly as the Bombay Beach Biennale. When I went to the town for the first time in 2021, I was looking for salvation in this weird desert town on the Salton Sea south of Palm Springs and Joshua Tree National Park. I dropped in, felt vibes and left with stories. I stared at the eccentric large-scale art, posted photos on Instagram of ruin porn and a hot pink sign on the beach that said, “If you’re stuck, call Kim.” I posed in front of a mountain of painted televisions, swung on a swing over the edge of the lake’s retreating shoreline and explored the half-buried, rusted-out cars that make up an abandoned ersatz drive-in movie theater. On that trip, it felt as if I were inside a “Mad Max” simulation, but I was only scratching the surface of the town.

headline: Can Reed Hastings Disrupt Skiing?
abstract: The Netflix co-founder bought Powder Mountain, in Utah, and is turning half of it into a private club for wealthy homeowners who pay a hefty annual fee. Will the public-private model fly?
lead_paragraph: On a Monday morning in early March, Reed Hastings, the billionaire co-founder and former chief executive of Netflix, clicked into the bindings on his snowboard and started off down one of the slopes at Powder Mountain, a ski area in Utah’s northeast corner. He quickly veered off the groomed trail into some well-spaced trees, and as he made turns over bumpy snow, you could hear his edges scratch against patches of ice.

headline: The Anxiety of Watching Risk Takers Clash Over Life-or-Death Decisions
abstract: On “Arctic Ascent With Alex Honnold,” big-wall climbers set out to make history. Their tense conversations give a peek inside the interpersonal dynamics of those who regularly risk death.
lead_paragraph: Spoilers follow.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Leaving Half a Banana Uneaten
abstract: What to do when your wife won’t eat the remaining half?
lead_paragraph: Anthony writes: My wife loves fresh bananas. When she was pregnant, she wanted only half a banana at a time. Her solution? Take a knife and cut a banana in half while it was still attached to the bunch. She won’t eat the remaining half, so it hangs there, turning brown within hours. She gave birth three weeks ago, and her appetite has returned. But she continues to do this. Please make her stop.

headline: A.I.-Generated Garbage Is Polluting Our Culture
abstract: An insidious creep of artificial intelligence is already penetrating our most important institutions.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly, mounds of synthetic A.I.-generated outputs drift across our feeds and our searches. The stakes go far beyond what’s on our screens. The entire culture is becoming affected by A.I.’s runoff, an insidious creep into our most important institutions.

headline: Something Other Than Originalism Explains This Supreme Court
abstract: It’s actually traditionalist. Which is a good thing.
lead_paragraph: It is a sign of the polarizing nature of the current Supreme Court that even knowledgeable critics of its opinions make diametrically opposed arguments.

headline: $900,000 Homes in Rome
abstract: A one-bedroom apartment near the Trevi Fountain, a two-bedroom duplex on the western edge of town, and a spacious pied-à-terre across from the Basilica of Santa Cecilia.
lead_paragraph: This one-bedroom, one-bath apartment is on the top floor of a four-story 18th-century building near the Trevi Fountain. Built in the Renaissance style, it features cornices above the windows and wood shutters. An inscription above the main entry has the Latin motto, “Ne Gloriari Liberat Alienis Bonis” (“Do not boast of the merits of others”), taken from an ancient fable by Phaedrus.

headline: The Rise of ‘Middle-Finger Politics’
abstract: The political writer John Ganz walks through the long history of Trump’s brand of right-wing populism in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump can seem like a political anomaly. You sometimes hear people describe his connection with his base in quasi-mystical terms. But really, Trump is an example of an archetype — the right-wing populist showman — that recurs across time and place. There’s Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil, Boris Johnson in Britain, Javier Milei in Argentina. And there’s a long lineage of this type in the United States too.

headline: ‘Romancing the Stone’ and Its Screenwriter’s Tragic Tale
abstract: Diane Thomas was a waitress when she made headlines for the script sale of what would become a box office smash. But the Cinderella story had a sad ending.
lead_paragraph: Each day, before her waitressing shift began, Diane Thomas would plop herself onto the floor of her tiny Malibu studio apartment, in front of a low-slung desk, and begin typing. Throughout late 1978 and early 1979, she worked daily, hours on end, conjuring the tale of Joan Chase, a mousy romance novelist suddenly thrust into a life-or-death adventure.

headline: 10 Red Wines to Drink Now: Austria Edition
abstract: There’s more to Austrian wines than grüner veltliner. Its reds range from juicy and refreshing to satisfyingly complex.
lead_paragraph: Austria is best known for its white wines, grüner veltliners and rieslings primarily. But it also produces brilliant reds, which, because they often seem like afterthoughts, can be great values.

headline: Why Jonathan Haidt Is ‘Wildly Optimistic’ About Gen Z
abstract: The social psychologist and author of “The Anxious Generation” talks about how to combat the toll of smartphones and social media.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, less than 9 percent of American teens reported having had at least one major depressive episode in the previous year, according to the U.S. National Survey on Drug Use and Health. By 2022, that number had risen to roughly 20 percent. Incidence of anxiety and depression among college students, emergency room visits for self-harm and suicide rates among young people likewise rose at alarming rates in that period.

headline: Finding the Line Between Celebrity and Politician With Tressie McMillan Cottom
abstract: What Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Donald Trump all understand.
lead_paragraph: The sociologist and New York Times columnist Tressie McMillan Cottom joins the hosts of “Matter of Opinion” this week to discuss the role of celebrity in politics. Could Beyoncé and Taylor Swift, with their tens of millions of fans, sway the presidential election? And beyond brand-name pop stars, what role does celebrity play within the political system?

headline: ​Why School Absences Have ‘Exploded’ Almost Everywhere
abstract: The pandemic changed families’ lives and the culture of education: “Our relationship with school became optional.”
lead_paragraph: The pandemic changed families’ lives and the culture of education: “Our relationship with school became optional.”

headline: Those Billion-Dollar Lottery ‘Jackpots’ Aren’t Even Half That Big
abstract: The latest enticing lottery prizes are the product of misleading advertising and high interest rates, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Lottery fever is rising again in the United States. But buyer beware. The advertised jackpots aren’t nearly as big as they look.

headline: After a Year of Turmoil, Harvard’s Applications Drop
abstract: With the exception of Brown University, some other highly selective schools saw a record rise in the number of students who applied for admission.
lead_paragraph: Applications to Harvard College were down this year, even as many other highly selective schools hit record highs.

headline: How Trump Paid $100 Million in Legal Fees
abstract: Since leaving office in 2021, former President Donald Trump has spent more than $100 million on costs related to investigations, indictments and his coming criminal trials. Shane Goldmacher, a politics reporter for The New York Times, explains where the funds came from.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving office in 2021, former President Donald Trump has spent more than $100 million on costs related to investigations, indictments and his coming criminal trials. Shane Goldmacher, a politics reporter for The New York Times, explains where the funds came from.

headline: As Bridge Cleanup Gets Underway, Officials Warn of ‘Daunting’ Process
abstract: Clearing the debris from the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge will be a complex but urgent task, officials said. And rebuilding it may take several years, they cautioned.
lead_paragraph: With search and rescue efforts over, officials have fully turned to the cleanup and rebuilding phase in the aftermath of the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore. Clearing the debris, which is blocking a vital shipping lane into the Port of Baltimore, is likely to be completed in a matter of weeks, engineering and salvage experts say. But reconstructing the bridge will be a long process, federal and state officials cautioned.

headline: TV’s Saviors Are Here, and They’re Wearing Spandex
abstract: A reboot of “Gladiators,” the musclebound 1990s staple, has attracted millions of viewers in Britain. Is appointment television back?
lead_paragraph: First it was the streamers: the seismic arrival of Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Apple TV+ and the rest, offering television’s previously captive viewers the chance to watch seemingly whatever they wanted, whenever they wanted. Then TikTok joined YouTube in conclusively shattering what was once a unified small-screen audience into a billion individual fragments.

headline: Stock Market Surges to Start the Year: 22 Record Highs in 3 Months
abstract: The S&P 500, rising 10 percent, set the pace as investors looked forward to interest rate cuts.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a blistering start to the year for the stock market.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 29, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

abstract: This week's selection includes titles by Harlan Ellison, Idra Novey, Leila Aboulela and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's selection includes titles by Harlan Ellison, Idra Novey, Leila Aboulela and more.

headline: Feeling Overwhelmed? Try Tallying Your Tiny Wins.
abstract: Taking stock of small achievements can keep you motivated when times are tough, experts say.
lead_paragraph: When I joined The New York Times as a columnist in 2022, I hadn’t worked in an office in over two decades. Before, I wrote freelance articles and books at home; my only co-worker was Tux, my tuxedo cat.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Beyoncé's new album, “Cowboy Carter.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Beyoncé's new album, “Cowboy Carter.”

headline: Behind Closed Doors, Biden Campaign Gathers Major Donors in New York
abstract: At a daylong retreat, 175 of the president’s biggest financiers and fund-raisers will hear from top campaign officials.
lead_paragraph: The morning after President Biden’s fund-raiser with former Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, his campaign has planned a daylong retreat on Friday for 175 of his biggest financiers and fund-raisers in New York.

headline: A.I.’s Messy Moment + Listeners Respond to Jonathan Haidt + Shrimp Jesus
abstract: “Being a C.E.O. sucks. Elon was right. It is like looking into the abyss and chewing glass.”
lead_paragraph: This week, we look at a mess of corporate drama in artificial intelligence. Stability AI has announced that its founder and C.E.O., Emad Mostaque, is leaving the company. Meanwhile, Microsoft hired away two of the co-founders and much of the staff of Inflection, without actually acquiring the company itself. Both moves surprised tech insiders. Then, we talked with listeners who had something to say about our interview with Jonathan Haidt on smartphones, social media and young people. And finally, we examine the true motives behind “Shrimp Jesus” and other hugely popular images on social media that were generated with artificial intelligence.

headline: The Latest on Sean Combs’s Legal Woes
abstract: Federal agents raided the hip-hop mogul’s homes this week. This is what we know.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Homeland Security investigators raided the homes of Sean “Diddy” Combs in Los Angeles and Miami. The raids come as Combs, one of hip-hop’s most recognizable performers and producers, faces several civil lawsuits accusing him of rape and sexual assault. There has been a tremendous amount of speculation this week. Here’s what we know so far.

headline: Wanted in South Korea: Imperialism-Free Cherry Blossoms
abstract: Activists want to replace a variety of cherry tree associated with the Japanese colonial era with one they say is Korean. The science is messy.
lead_paragraph: Shin Joon Hwan, an ecologist, walked along a road lined with cherry trees on the verge of blooming last week, examining the fine hairs around their dark red buds.
