headline: A Crisis of School Absences
abstract: Fewer children are attending school, across rich and poor districts.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a troubling phenomenon began to spread in U.S. education: Students were not showing up to school.

headline: Days After U.N. Cease-Fire Resolution, Has Anything Changed in Gaza?
abstract: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Monday that demands an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip. Here’s a closer look at where the situation stands.
lead_paragraph: Although the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Monday that demands an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, it remains to be seen whether ​i​t ​w​ill have a concrete effect on the war or prove merely to be a political statement.

headline: Does Trash Talk Have a Place in Sports?
abstract: A guest essayist wants to bring taunting back to baseball. What do you think? Is trash talk harmless fun or bad sportsmanship?
lead_paragraph: Do you play or watch sports? If so, is trash talk ever a part of those games or matches? Do you think taunting, jeering and disparaging your opponents makes sports more fun? Or is it just bad sportsmanship?

headline: Girl, 8, Is Sole Survivor of Bus Plunge: ‘No One Can Explain This Miracle’
abstract: Forty-five church pilgrims from Botswana, along with the driver, were killed when the bus plunged off an overpass into a rocky ravine in South Africa. The only survivor was a little girl.
lead_paragraph: Lauryn Siako is the rare 8-year-old who springs out of bed to get herself ready for church, her family said. She loves the singing, the dancing, the worshiping.

headline: Memoirs Are Powerful Currency for This Hmong American Writer
abstract: Kao Kalia Yang talks about her recently published memoir, “Where Rivers Part,” which is about her mother’s life.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Empty Roads and Spewing Lava: 4 Months Into Iceland’s Eruptions
abstract: Volcanic eruptions are continuing in the Reykjanes Peninsula in Iceland. Streets are empty and the Blue Lagoon resort remains closed.
lead_paragraph: The scene is as spectacular as it is dangerous: flowing rivers of shimmering lava and a dramatic plume of toxic gas.

headline: A Key Inflation Gauge Hovers Above Fed’s Target
abstract: The Fed’s preferred inflation gauge climbed 2.5 percent in the year through February, in line with economists’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: The latest reading of the Federal Reserve’s favorite inflation gauge was in line with economists’ expectations, as price increases hovered above the central bank’s target even after months of cooling.

headline: U.S.-Funded Broadcaster Leaves Hong Kong, Citing Security Law
abstract: Radio Free Asia, which ran a small operation in Hong Kong, said its staff was at risk because of the law’s sweeping definition of “external interference.”
lead_paragraph: The United States-funded news service Radio Free Asia said on Friday that it has closed its office in Hong Kong because of concerns about the city’s recently enacted national security law that targets so-called foreign interference.

headline: A Common Link in Mideast Conflicts: Iran and Its Proxies
abstract: A monitoring group said that an Israeli strike on Syria hit multiple targets, including a weapons depot belonging to Hezbollah, the Iran-backed Lebanese militia. Here’s a closer look at Iran’s proxies in the region.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Gaza. Yemen and the Red Sea. Lebanon, Iraq, Pakistan and Syria.

headline: Readers Share Why They Love the Golden State
abstract: Readers have been writing in about some of their favorite things about California, including the biodiversity and the sense of community.

headline: How Many Easters Remain for This Century-Old Boys’ Choir School?
abstract: St. Thomas Church in New York is considering closing its renowned boarding school for choristers, one of only a few in the world, because of financial woes.
lead_paragraph: At the St. Thomas Choir School in Manhattan the other morning, more than two dozen boys, dressed in matching white polo shirts and gray pants, gathered in a gymnasium to rehearse hymns for Holy Week services, as their predecessors have for more than a century.

headline: New Pollution Rules Aim to Lift Sales of Electric Trucks
abstract: The latest in a string of ambitious climate regulations aims to clean up the heaviest polluters on the road. But truckers are worried.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday announced a regulation designed to turbocharge sales of electric or other zero-emission heavy vehicles, from school buses to cement mixers, as part of its multifront attack on global warming.

headline: Biden and Trump appeal to their voters and address their weaknesses.
abstract: President Biden and Donald J. Trump are trying to defang some of the most damaging lines of attack against them, another sign that the tight campaign for president is intensifying as the country moves into the election year.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Donald J. Trump are trying to defang some of the most damaging lines of attack against them, another sign that the tight campaign for president is intensifying as the country moves into the election year.

headline: Charged With Sexual Offenses, Influential Politician in Northern Ireland Steps Down
abstract: Jeffrey Donaldson, the leader of the Democratic Unionist Party and a backer of strong ties with the U.K., has resigned after being arrested on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Donaldson, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party and one of Northern Ireland’s most prominent and influential politicians, resigned his leadership of the party on Friday, after being charged with “historical” sex offenses.

headline: Stream These 12 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in April
abstract: A Ryan Gosling detective comedy, a Formula One racing drama and the romantic musical “Mamma Mia!” are among the movies exiting the streaming service.
lead_paragraph: Fast cars, jazz drummers, time travelers, bounty hunters — you’ll find everything but the kitchen sink in this month’s roundup of noteworthy titles leaving Netflix in the United States. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: A Loyal Israel Ally, Germany Shifts Tone as the Toll in Gaza Mounts
abstract: Supporting Israel is seen as a historic duty in Germany, but the worsening crisis has pushed German officials to ask whether that backing has gone too far.
lead_paragraph: Days after Hamas launched its Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, was one of the first Western leaders to arrive in Tel Aviv. Standing beside the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, he declared that Germany had “only one place — and it is alongside Israel.”

headline: Louis Gossett Jr., 87, Dies; ‘An Officer and a Gentleman’ and ‘Roots’ Actor
abstract: His portrayal of a drill instructor earned him the Oscar for best supporting actor. He was the first Black performer to win in that category.
lead_paragraph: Louis Gossett Jr., who took home an Academy Award for “An Officer and a Gentleman” and an Emmy for “Roots,” both times playing a mature man who guides a younger one taking on a new role — but in drastically different circumstances — died early Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Teacher Secretly Sold His Students’ Art on Mugs and Shirts, Lawsuit Says
abstract: Parents of a dozen students at a school near Montreal accused an art teacher in a lawsuit of reproducing portraits from a class assignment and putting them on items that he offered for sale online.
lead_paragraph: In January, students at a junior high school outside Montreal received an assignment to draw a classmate or a self-portrait in the style of Jean-Michel Basquiat.

headline: They Can’t See the Eclipse, but This Device Will Help Them Hear It
abstract: A device called LightSound is being distributed to help the blind and visually impaired experience this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 21, 2017, Kiki Smith’s teenage sons giddily prepared to watch the partial solar eclipse in Rochester, N.Y. As Ms. Smith listened to their chatter, she felt excluded.

headline: Why It’s So Expensive to Live in Phoenix
abstract: Arizona is a presidential election battleground state, and a dire shortage of affordable housing there is sowing economic anxiety among voters.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since they began their life together in the desert sprawl of greater Phoenix, Devon Lawrence and Eren Mendoza have bounced from one itinerant home to another.

headline: Our Favorite Watering Cans
abstract: Any vessel will work, but these are the ones we'd pick.
lead_paragraph: Any vessel will work, but these are the ones we'd pick.

headline: In Move to Protect Whales, Polynesian Indigenous Groups Give Them ‘Personhood’
abstract: Indigenous leaders of New Zealand, Tahiti and the Cook Islands signed a treaty that recognizes whales as legal persons. Conservationists hope it will lead to legal protections.
lead_paragraph: For many Indigenous groups across Polynesia, whales hold an ancient sacredness and spirit that connects all life. Whales — or tohorā, as Māori call them — guided their ancestors across the Pacific Ocean. Today, those groups consider themselves to be guardians for the largest animals under the sea.

headline: Big Ticket: N.Y.’s Top Sales and Listings in March
abstract: March's top sales include the former home of George Malkemus.
lead_paragraph: March's top sales include the former home of George Malkemus.

headline: Stop Looking for Flaws in the Premier League Contenders
abstract: As Arsenal and Manchester City meet, remember that titles are not always won head-to-head, and that being the second-best team in the world’s best league does not constitute failure.
lead_paragraph: Chances are, the truth will not feature much in the coverage. It will not be a central point in the buildup. The commentators may mention it in passing, but their tone will indicate that the hyperbole is not to be punctured. And if Pep Guardiola and Mikel Arteta try to point it out before Manchester City faces Arsenal on Sunday, it will be viewed as gamesmanship, or deflection, or unapologetic sophistry.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: A fanatical faith leader, aggressive home invaders and disfigured attention hogs are among the subjects of this month’s horror picks.
lead_paragraph: Kyle McConaghy’s knockout neo-noir thriller is a sinister yet humane parable about blind faith and religious manipulation. It’s one of my favorite movies of the year so far.

headline: A Georgia Town Basks in Bountiful Filming. The State Pays.
abstract: When movies are made in Thomasville, Ga., it welcomes celebrities and an infusion of cash. But the financial incentives that attract studios have cost the state billions.
lead_paragraph: It is no wonder that moviemakers saw potential in Thomasville, Ga., as a stand-in for Main Street U.S.A. Cobblestone streets and mom-and-pop stores speckle the downtown of this city of 18,000 that is caked in red clay soil and nestled among rolling hills.

headline: It’s Time for Honey Baked Ham
abstract: Not for you? There’s always carrot maqluba, or a no-recipe recipe for kielbasa with pierogies.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. What I smelled during a 10-minute bicycle ride today: wood smoke, diesel exhaust, grass, frying bacon, rotting wood, bleach, balloon rubber, dollar pizza, a tendril of burning weed, the sharpness of electrical ozone, cart coffee and, last, the strong, sweet scent of lilies — Easter in the air. Good Friday!

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 8, 2024

headline: Israel Cites ‘New Initiatives’ for Gaza Aid, but Progress Has Been Slow
abstract: The country pointed to measures to deliver necessities by land, air and sea that aid groups say are not nearly sufficient to meet the need.
lead_paragraph: Israel said Friday that it was committed to its legal obligations to provide humanitarian aid to desperate civilians in Gaza, pointing to a series of measures to deliver aid by land, air and sea. But progress on the efforts has been slow, and aid groups say they are not nearly sufficient to meet the vast need in the enclave.

headline: The Big Number: $30 Billion
abstract: An agreement by Visa and Mastercard to cap swipe fees could save merchants billions. The question is how much it will help consumers.
lead_paragraph: An agreement by Visa and Mastercard to cap swipe fees could save merchants billions. The question is how much it will help consumers.

headline: Heart Pump Is Linked to 49 Deaths, the F.D.A. Warns
abstract: The agency faulted the device maker for delayed notice of mounting complications, citing increasing reports of how use of the device perforated the walls of the heart.
lead_paragraph: A troubled heart pump that has now been linked to 49 deaths and dozens of injuries worldwide will be allowed to remain in use, despite the Food and Drug Administration’s decision to issue an alert about the risk that it could puncture a wall of the heart.

headline: Who’s Who on Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’
abstract: A guide to key guests and behind-the-scenes figures on the star’s eighth studio album.
lead_paragraph: A new Beyoncé release isn’t just an album — it’s a sprawling collective effort where the supporting cast and behind the scenes crew can reveal a lot about the scope of the star’s vision. For “Cowboy Carter,” in addition to household names like Willie Nelson, Dolly Parton, Miley Cyrus and Post Malone (and a brief cameo from her daughter Rumi), she’s looped in a slew of collaborators new and old. Here’s a guide to some of the most significant figures you’ll see in the credits.

headline: The Sean Combs Saga Is Catnip for Pop Culture Podcasts
abstract: The raids of Combs’s homes have been a primary topic on podcasts and radio shows that cover the Black entertainment world.
lead_paragraph: In the sprawling world of Black pop culture podcasts, its own media ecosystem covering the story lines and people central to the hip-hop genre, the one topic that dominated conversation this week was, unsurprisingly, the latest in the saga of Sean Combs.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: News surrounding former President Donald Trump dominated late night this week, including a New York appeals court reducing the bond in his civil fraud case, and his newest venture: a $60 Bible. Here’s what the hosts had to say.
lead_paragraph: News surrounding former President Donald Trump dominated late night this week, including a New York appeals court reducing the bond in his civil fraud case, and his newest venture: a $60 Bible. Here’s what the hosts had to say.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Adopts the Music of Opera Singers, Too
abstract: On the star’s new album, the track “Daughter” includes her take on an 18th-century Italian song most often heard in classical music recitals.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need opera glasses to see that Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” takes on more than just country music.

headline: Our Reporter on the History, and Return, of Private Clubs
abstract: Private clubs have long shaped the fabric of New York social life. Many of them formed during the Gilded Age, meticulously designed to be showstoppers before Manhattan’s skyscrapers surrounded them. But in recent years, a new wave of clubs has proliferated, varying in price point, exclusivity and amenities.
lead_paragraph: Private clubs have long shaped the fabric of New York social life. Many of them formed during the Gilded Age, meticulously designed to be showstoppers before Manhattan’s skyscrapers surrounded them. But in recent years, a new wave of clubs has proliferated, varying in price point, exclusivity and amenities.

headline: Members-Only Mania: Why Are More Private Clubs Popping Up in New York?
abstract: Some people belong to multiple private clubs that have emerged to fill physical and emotional voids. Others belong only to Sam’s Club.
lead_paragraph: In a 115-year-old ferry terminal in New York’s financial district, an abundance of excess now exists. Walls lined with Loro Piana cashmere, Brooklyn Bridge views, a wellness center, a jazz bar — all of it can be yours for $3,900 annually (or just $2,500, if you’re under 30). Since it opened in 2021, Casa Cipriani has become one of the city’s buzziest private clubs.

headline: ‘Bathhouse.pptx’ Review: A Fever Dream, Both Poetic and Mystifying
abstract: Jesús I. Valles’s prizewinning play gets a stage at the Flea, but the ambitious work about queer history proves too difficult to wrangle.
lead_paragraph: In “Bathhouse.pptx,” Jesús I. Valles investigates the fading history of gay bathhouses, bringing to life both the marginalized people who reveled in them and the forgotten people who cleaned them. The play — selected as the winner of the 2023 Yale Drama Series Prize by Jeremy O. Harris (“Slave Play”) — laces historical fantasy with melodic prose, loosely stringing together Valles’s ramblings like an epic fever dream. But if, like most such dreams, it’s far more captivating to the storyteller than to the audience, the work offers enough lyrical beauty to keep viewers listening, if not fully understanding, and yearning for more.

headline: 4 Things You Need to Know About Health Care Cyberattacks
abstract: Despite the explosion in ransomware hacks like the one against Change Healthcare, regulation is spotty and few new safeguards have been proposed to protect patient data, vulnerable hospitals and medical groups.
lead_paragraph: The recent cyberattack on the billing and payment colossus Change Healthcare revealed just how serious the vulnerabilities are throughout the U.S. health care system, and alerted industry leaders and policymakers to the urgent need for better digital security.

headline: Shakira’s Pop-Up Show: Not Something She Dreamed Up at Breakfast
abstract: Months of preparation precede what can appear to be a sudden decision to entertain fans at a busy time in the heart of Times Square.
lead_paragraph: They may look impromptu. But they are not. Pop-up performances in Times Square aren’t quite the spontaneous events the term suggests.

headline: New Jersey’s Ballot Must Be Immediately Redesigned, Federal Judge Rules
abstract: The ruling is expected to abolish a practice that has allowed the state’s Democratic and Republican political machines to flourish.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark ruling, a federal judge on Friday ordered New Jersey to redesign its election ballot before the June primary, upending a longstanding source of electoral power for the state’s Democratic and Republican political machines.

headline: Fed Chair Says Central Bank Need Not ‘Hurry’ to Cut Rates
abstract: Jerome Powell said that strong economic growth gives Federal Reserve officials room to be patient, and he emphasized the institution’s political independence.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said on Friday that resilient economic growth is giving the central bank the flexibility to be patient before cutting interest rates.

headline: The Great Tension Inside the Trump G.O.P.
abstract: How long can a populist party support a libertarian Congress?
lead_paragraph: This week the populist think tank American Compass released polling showing that larger shares of Republican voters said they believed that the federal government should be doing more, rather than less, to provide “support for the poor, disabled, needy” and “medical care for those who need help affording insurance” and to sustain Social Security and Medicare.

headline: OpenAI Unveils A.I. Technology That Recreates Human Voices
abstract: The start-up is sharing the technology, Voice Engine, with a small group of early testers as it tries to understand the potential dangers.
lead_paragraph: First, OpenAI offered a tool that allowed people to create digital images simply by describing what they wanted to see. Then, it built similar technology that generated full-motion video like something from a Hollywood movie.

headline: How ‘3 Body Problem’ Created a Spectacular Disaster, With Strings Attached
abstract: Technical artists used a combination of digital and practical effects to slice an oil tanker into pieces in the fifth episode. Here’s how they did it.
lead_paragraph: It begins slowly, almost soundlessly. As an oil tanker glides through the Panama Canal, the flow of a hose slows to a trickle. The hose has been sliced in two. Then the man holding the hose falls apart, his body severed at the knees and waist. Strands of nanofibers, each a hundredth the thickness of a human hair and strung across the canal at its narrowest point, knife through the ship, cutting smoothly through walls, through pipes, through flesh and bone. The sundered ship fans out like a deck of cards then collapses, smoldering. Every soul onboard — a thousand people, many of them children — has been killed.

headline: Our Critics Talk About the Novels That Make Them Laugh
abstract: Dwight Garner, Alexandra Jacobs and Jennifer Szalai weigh in on 22 of the funniest novels since “Catch-22.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Book Review’s staff critics — Dwight Garner, Alexandra Jacobs and Jennifer Szalai — released a list of 22 novels they have found reliably funny since Joseph Heller’s landmark comic novel “Catch-22” came out in 1961. On this week’s episode, they tell Gilbert Cruz why “Catch-22” was their starting point, and explain a bit about their process: how they think about humor, how they made their choices, what books they left off and what books led to fights along the way. (“American Psycho” turns out to be as contentious now as it was when it was first published.)

headline: Eleanor Collins, Canada’s ‘First Lady of Jazz,’ Dies at 104
abstract: A singer known for her mastery of standards, she found stardom in Canada on TV and in nightclubs. But she was virtually unknown in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When the singer and pianist Nat King Cole’s 15-minute variety show debuted on NBC in November 1956, he made history as the first Black American to host a television program. But just over the country’s northern border, another Black entertainer had him beat: In the summer of 1955, Eleanor Collins had her own show on the CBC, Canada’s national broadcasting network.

headline: Review: An Age-Old Riddle Ginned Up for Postapocalyptic Times
abstract: The choreographers Baye & Asa usher the Sphinx puzzler into a vaguely menacing landscape.
lead_paragraph: What has one voice but four legs in the morning, two legs at noon and three legs in the evening? So goes the riddle of the Sphinx, and the answer, as Oedipus discerned, is man: crawling as an infant, bipedal as an adult, walking with a cane in old age.

headline: 3 Festive Main Dishes for Any Spring Party
abstract: Whether for a casual cookout or an elegant dinner party, these impressive recipes are easy to pull off.
lead_paragraph: After the quiet winter months, spring heralds the return of longer days and gathering over leisurely meals. The best dishes for those get-togethers are the ones that feel celebratory enough to serve to guests, but are simple enough to ensure you’re not spending all day in the kitchen.

headline: How Female Bodybuilders Became Fashion’s Latest Muses
abstract: An industry long known for revering willowy bodies is taking a new interest in muscle.
lead_paragraph: When fashion designers, as they often do, allude to women’s strength as an inspiration for the clothes they make, they tend to have in mind their customers’ emotional resilience rather than their bench-pressing prowess. But on the runway at the New York-based brand Collina Strada’s fall 2024 show last month, one model — dressed in a woven sleeveless top and lace-lined athletic shorts — proudly flexed her arms, and another, wearing a floral-print shorts set, did bicep curls with dumbbells made with kabocha squashes (a reference to a photograph of a woman in Nepal weight lifting with pumpkins, explained the line’s creative director, Hillary Taymour, 36). Combining traditionally feminine motifs like frills and flowers with nods to the gym, the collection seems to poke fun at the idea that femininity and strength could ever be seen as opposing forces. Underscoring the point, a third model effortlessly carried her baby up and down the catwalk with one arm.

headline: Heat Waves Are Moving Slower and Staying Longer, Study Finds
abstract: Climate change is making heat waves linger for longer stretches of time, exacerbating the effects of extreme temperatures.
lead_paragraph: When heat waves swept across large parts of the planet last summer, in many places the oppressive temperatures loitered for days or weeks at a time. As climate change warms the planet, heat waves are increasingly moving sluggishly and lasting longer, according to a study published on Friday.

headline: Beyond Beyoncé: Black Women of Country, Past and Present
abstract: Listen to songs from Rhiannon Giddens, Rissi Palmer, Linda Martell and more.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the release of Beyoncé’s eighth solo album, “Cowboy Carter,” a sprawling celebration of country music and a saucy rebuttal to its most close-minded gatekeepers. Its previously released singles, the haunting “16 Carriages” and the rowdy No. 1 hit “Texas Hold ’Em,” reignited conversations about the erasure of Black voices in country music history and the industry-enforced barriers that still make it difficult for nonwhite artists to break through.

headline: Daniel A. Moore, Founder of an African American Museum, Dies at 88
abstract: To tell the full story of the American Black experience, he created an Atlanta institution in 1978 and later moved it to a building “erected brick by brick” by Black masons.
lead_paragraph: Daniel A. Moore Sr., who created a pioneering African American history museum in Atlanta when such initiatives were rare, died on March 4 in Decatur, Ga. He was 88.

headline: Alice Coltrane’s Explosive Carnegie Hall Concert, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by St. Vincent, Ani DiFranco, Camila Cabello and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Louis Gossett Jr.’s Greatest Roles: A Streaming Guide
abstract: His range was wide, as evidenced by performances in projects as different as “Roots,” “An Officer and a Gentleman” and “Diggstown.”
lead_paragraph: When most people think of the venerable character actor Louis Gossett Jr., who died Friday at 87, they understandably summon up his Oscar-winning turn in the 1982 drama “An Officer and a Gentleman.” But he accumulated over 200 credits over a screen, stage and television career that spanned more than 60 years, and brought a skill set that included not only drama but also comedy, science fiction, action and horror. Here are a few highlights from his illustrious career and where to stream them.

headline: ‘Bless These Books’: How Karen Kingsbury Is Extending the Reach of Christian Fiction
abstract: She’s sold more than 25 million copies, but isn’t slowing down. An Amazon series and a film getting wide distribution mark a new phase.
lead_paragraph: In the early years of her career, the novelist Karen Kingsbury often prayed for success. “Lord,” she would say, “bless these books beyond anything I could ask or imagine. Let them be bigger than anything I could envision and let them change culture.”

headline: Serra’s ‘Splash’: A Public Artist’s Private Breakthrough
abstract: Serra spattered a pot of molten lead against the base of a wall in Jasper Johns’s home. Then he let it harden. The result looked nothing like a traditional sculpture.
lead_paragraph: Although Richard Serra seems destined to be remembered as “the man of steel,” when he died this week, I found myself thinking back to a story he had told me about his younger and more vulnerable self.

headline: Czechs Accuse Men of ‘Russian Influence Operation’ in Europe
abstract: Amid news reports that European politicians received payments to promote Russian interests, the Czech government froze the assets of the men and a website, Voice of Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Czech Republic has frozen the assets of two men and a news website it accuses of running an influence operation in Europe that supports “the foreign policy interests of the Russian Federation,” the country’s Foreign Ministry said in a statement.

headline: Neeli Cherkovski, Poet Who Chronicled the Beat Generation, Dies at 78
abstract: His biographies of Charles Bukowski and Lawrence Ferlinghetti came to overshadow his own work. “I would love an interview,” he once said, “where Bukowski is not mentioned.”
lead_paragraph: Neeli Cherkovski, a prolific poet and denizen of beatnik cafes who chronicled the literary ethos of bohemian culture in biographies of Beat Generation writers, including his friends Charles Bukowski and Lawrence Ferlinghetti, died on March 19 in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Should I Speak Out When I Overhear a Person Saying Something Hateful?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on taking a stand against homophobia and other forms of bigotry.
lead_paragraph: I was in a barbershop in a town west of the Mississippi and east of the Rockies. I didn’t hear what had been said before or what came after, but I suddenly heard another customer (quite calmly) say, “I just wish all homosexuals would be obliterated.” I’m gay and have had nightmares about being in a concentration camp because of my sexuality. Hearing those words said out loud froze my blood. I didn’t make a scene, just sat and pondered it all for a minute, then got up and walked out. I didn’t want to knowingly breathe the same air as someone speaking the language of Nazis. Should I have spoken out? — Name Withheld

headline: Can Intel Serve Two Masters?
abstract: Biden is counting on it to be a national champion chipmaker, but it still has shareholders to please.
lead_paragraph: This week I interviewed Pat Gelsinger, the chief executive of Intel, which is one of the most important companies in the United States. President Biden seems to think it’s singularly important, anyway: His administration has tentatively agreed to give Intel $8.5 billion in grants and $11 billion in low-cost loans to help it push ahead in computer chip design and manufacturing. It should also qualify for about $25 billion in investment tax credits.

headline: Trump and Allies Appeal Ruling That Allowed Georgia Prosecutor to Keep Case
abstract: The defendants in the election interference case are once again pressing their argument that Fani T. Willis should be removed from the prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Calling the Atlanta prosecutor Fani T. Willis “utterly unrepentant,” lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump and eight of his co-defendants in the Georgia election interference investigation asked an appeals court on Friday to reverse a judge’s ruling that allowed her to stay on the case.

headline: How Patty Murray Used Her Gavel to Win $1 Billion for Child Care
abstract: A self-described “mom in tennis shoes,” now the Senate Appropriations Committee leader, managed to win an increase in child care subsidies in a spending freeze.
lead_paragraph: Senator Patty Murray got inspired to enter politics when a male state legislator derided her efforts to fight budget cuts to early education programs, calling her “just a mom in tennis shoes” — a remark she would proudly adopt as her campaign slogan.

headline: Biden Will Visit Baltimore Next Week After Bridge Collapse
abstract: The president’s visit comes as officials start planning for major economic disruptions after a ship struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Friday that he would travel to Baltimore next week as officials race to manage the fallout from the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge.

abstract: Because you'll definitely need fuel for the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: Because you'll definitely need fuel for the dance floor.

headline: How a Third-Party Candidate Could Affect the 2024 Vote
abstract: Rebecca Davis O’Brien, a politics reporter for The New York Times, explains how third-party candidates could alter the outcome of the election.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Davis O’Brien, a politics reporter for The New York Times, explains how third-party candidates could alter the outcome of the election.

headline: Airstrikes Kill Soldiers in Syria in Apparent Israeli Attack
abstract: Israel’s military did not immediately comment on the Syria strikes, but its defense minister said Israel would pursue Hezbollah, an Iran-backed militia, “every place it operates.”
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes killed a number of soldiers near the northern Syrian city of Aleppo early Friday, Syria’s state news media and an independent organization reported, in what appeared to be one of the heaviest Israeli attacks in the country in years.

headline: Review: ‘A Pledge, a Plea and a Love Letter’ to Africa
abstract: In “Until the Lion Tells the Story…,” Lacina Coulibaly walks in his ancestors’ footsteps.
lead_paragraph: In his solo “Until the Lion Tells the Story…,” the dancer and choreographer Lacina Coulibaly is the only observable person onstage, a riveting presence in quiet command of the space. But he doesn’t think of himself as alone.

headline: ‘Renegade Nell’ Review: When the Highwayman Is a Superwoman
abstract: In a new series for Disney+, the creator of “Happy Valley” and “Last Tango in Halifax” imagines a sometimes-superpowered 18th-century justice warrior.
lead_paragraph: The British television writer Sally Wainwright may not be a household name in the United States, but for more than a decade she has been turning out television shows whose variety and consistently high quality few writer-producers can match.

headline: Why Russia Is Protecting North Korea From Nuclear Monitors
abstract: The monitors have provided vivid evidence of how Russia is keeping Pyongyang brimming with fuel and other goods, presumably in return for weapons that Russia can use in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Through the most tense encounters with President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia over the past decade, there has been one project in which Washington and Moscow have claimed common cause: keeping North Korea from expanding its arsenal of nuclear weapons.

headline: Iowa Fertilizer Spill Kills Nearly All Fish Across 60-Mile Stretch of Rivers
abstract: Officials in Iowa and Missouri estimated that nearly 800,000 fish had died in waters that flow into the Missouri River.
lead_paragraph: A fertilizer spill in Iowa this month wiped out much of the aquatic life across a 60-mile stretch of rivers in two states, officials said, leaving an estimated 789,000 fish dead in one of the region’s most ecologically devastating chemical spills in recent years.

headline: Sailor’s Remains Identified 82 Years After Pearl Harbor

headline: AT&T Resets Millions of Passcodes After Customer Records Are Leaked
abstract: Nearly eight million customers and 65.4 million former account holders were affected by the data breach, the company said.
lead_paragraph: The telecommunications giant AT&T announced on Saturday that it had reset the passcodes of 7.6 million customers after it determined that compromised customer data was “released on the dark web.”

headline: Police Raid Peruvian President’s Home, Looking for Rolex Watches
abstract: Dina Boluarte, who has been seen wearing luxury watches and a $50,000 bracelet, is under investigation for breaking the country’s unlawful enrichment and asset disclosure laws.
lead_paragraph: The police and prosecutors in Peru carried out a surprise raid at the home of President Dina Boluarte and the presidential palace early Saturday as part of an “unlawful enrichment” investigation into news reports that she had been seen wearing Rolex watches since taking office.

headline: Turns of Phrase
abstract: Spencer Leach makes a lulu of a Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Woman Who Was Charged With Murder After Abortion Sues Texas Prosecutor
abstract: Lizelle Gonzalez was arrested after using an abortion pill in 2022, and her charge was since dropped. Now she is seeking $1 million in damages.
lead_paragraph: A woman in Texas who was falsely charged with murder over a self-induced abortion in 2022 has filed a lawsuit against the local prosecutor’s office and its leaders, seeking more than $1 million in damages.

headline: Chance Perdomo, Star of ‘Chilling Adventures of Sabrina,’ Dies at 27
abstract: Mr. Perdomo, who died in a motorcycle accident on Friday, played the pansexual warlock Ambrose Spellman in the Netflix series.
lead_paragraph: Chance Perdomo, the British actor known for his roles in the series “Gen V” and “Chilling Adventures of Sabrina,” died on Friday. He was 27.

headline: A Close-Up View of the Baltimore Bridge Collapse
abstract: From roughly 100 yards away, the site of one of the worst bridge collapses in the country’s history is haunting.
lead_paragraph: Maroon containers larger than a car sat twisted and crushed. Massive beams of steel warped into crooked arches. Pillars of jagged concrete poked out from the water — a tomb of wreckage that dimly reflected on the gray-toned river.

headline: Tangled in Steel With No Way Out: How the Crew Stuck in Baltimore Is Faring
abstract: Twenty-two seafarers from India find themselves not only trapped in the ship that struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge, but also in an unexpected spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Even from miles away, the destruction of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore is a jarring visual: Chunks of steel jut above the water like metallic icebergs. Twisted gray beams protrude in crooked positions. From a park near Fort McHenry, visitors can see the giant cargo ship that struck the bridge and remains lodged in the wreckage.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gylan Kain, 81, Founder Of the Last Poets Group and a Progenitor of Rap
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: ‘These fellow Black artists who — at that time, it’s all new, it doesn’t exist yet — they said, “Black people don’t like poetry.” So I said, “They’ll like mine.”’

headline: Corrections: March 31, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 4 about an immersive revival of “Cabaret” misstates Rebecca Frecknall’s age; she is 37, not 38. It also misstates her mother’s given name; she is Kate, not Jane. The article also mistakenly states that Frecknall’s parents had met in a community theater group; they joined the group after they had met. And it misidentifies the origins of a playbill for Peter Shaffer’s “Equus”; it was from a London production, not the original Broadway production. And it misspells the given name of a composer and lyricist; he was Stephen Sondheim, not Steven.

headline: Angry Farmers Are Reshaping Europe
abstract: Farm protests are changing not only Europe’s food system but also its politics, as the far right senses an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Gazing out from his 265-acre farm to the silhouetted Jura mountains in the distance, Jean-Michel Sibelle expounded on the intricate secrets of soil, climate and breeding that have made his chickens — blue feet, white feathers, red combs in the colors of France — the royalty of poultry.

headline: India’s Silicon Valley Faces a Water Crisis That Software Cannot Solve
abstract: Bengaluru gets plenty of rain. But the city did not properly adapt as its soaring population strained traditional water sources.
lead_paragraph: The water tankers seeking to fill their bellies bounced past the dry lakes of India’s booming technology capital. Their bleary-eyed drivers waited in line to suck what they could from wells dug a mile deep into dusty lots between app offices and apartment towers named for bougainvillea — all built before sewage and water lines could reach them.

headline: At Stake in the Istanbul Mayoral Race: Turkey’s Political Future
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has campaigned for his party to retake Istanbul from the incumbent mayor, whom many see as a potential future president.
lead_paragraph: The contest to run city hall in Istanbul, Turkey’s largest city and economic dynamo, is in many ways between one man who is on the ballot and another who is not.

headline: A Russian Defector’s Killing Raises Specter of Hit Squads
abstract: The death in Spain of Maksim Kuzminov, a pilot who delivered a helicopter and secret documents to Ukraine, has raised fears that the Kremlin is again targeting its enemies.
lead_paragraph: The men who killed Maksim Kuzminov wanted to send a message. This was obvious to investigators in Spain even before they discovered who he was. Not only did the killers shoot him six times in a parking garage in southern Spain, they ran over his body with their car.

headline: Elite College Admissions Have Turned Students Into Brands
abstract: Teenagers should not have to commoditize themselves for the sake of getting into an elite school.
lead_paragraph: “I just can’t think of anything,” my student said.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Presents Trump Bibles
abstract: Ramy Youssef hosted this weekend’s episode, which also spoofed immigrant fathers and Flaco the owl.
lead_paragraph: Former president Donald Trump’s recent foray into the business of selling his own Bibles provided plenty of comic fodder for “Saturday Night Live” on Easter weekend, including an opening sketch that, for a moment, seemed like a sincere retelling of the resurrection of Jesus.

headline: ‘I Discovered That I Had Left My Tuxedo Shirt at Home’
abstract: A desperate measure at a desperate moment, a rainy day interview and more reader tales from New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Can We Engineer Our Way Out of the Climate Crisis?
abstract: Blocking solar rays. Sucking carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Ideas that sound like science fiction are now starting to become reality, raising concerns about safety.
lead_paragraph: On a windswept Icelandic plateau, an international team of engineers and executives is powering up an innovative machine designed to alter the very composition of Earth’s atmosphere.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Shohei Ohtani’s Arrival Brings Hope and Nostalgia Home to Little Tokyo
abstract: For a Los Angeles community contending with gentrification in its historic center and an aging population of cultural standard-bearers, Ohtani’s accession with the Dodgers has been galvanizing.
lead_paragraph: Shohei Ohtani’s powerful arms and boyish face, looking up from under a Dodger blue helmet, loom 15 stories over Los Angeles’s Little Tokyo neighborhood from the side of the Miyako Hotel.

headline: Accused Subway Shover Found Little Help in New York’s Chaotic Shelters
abstract: Carlton McPherson had been placed by New York City in a specialized homeless shelter for people with serious mental illness. It was not enough.
lead_paragraph: Before Carlton McPherson was accused of fatally shoving a stranger in front of a subway train last week, he was placed by New York City into specialized homeless shelters meant to help people with severe mental illness.

headline: A Warhol Superstar, but Never a Star
abstract: Cynthia Carr’s compassionate biography chronicles the brief, poignant life of the transgender actress Candy Darling, whose “very existence was radical.”
lead_paragraph: Never mind soup-can paintings and portraits of the famous — what Andy Warhol keeps on giving is books. He’s like Mother Ginger in “The Nutcracker”: Smaller people keep running out from under his capacious skirts to bow or curtsy.

headline: 6 Y.A. Novels That Open Conversations About Teen Chronic Illness
abstract: Maya Van Wagenen, the author of “Chronically Dolores,” shares her favorite young adult books that authentically represent being a teenager living with illness.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when you’re a teenager, you have to plan make-out spots around accessible public bathrooms. At least I did. As a kid with interstitial cystitis, I longed for books that reflected the experience of navigating high school with the added complication of an embarrassing, long-term condition. Where was my sassy heroine with a head full of plans and a bladder full of sores? And what about my friends with I.B.S., endometriosis and chronic fatigue? Don’t they deserve representation, too?

headline: As Graffiti Moves From Eyesore to Amenity, Landlords Try to Cash In
abstract: Brands, developers and even city officials are embracing the global appeal of street art, but the boom comes with questions about preserving a neighborhood’s cultural cachet.
lead_paragraph: Julian Phethean’s first canvas in London was a shed in his backyard where he covered the walls with bold lettering in spray paint. When he moved his art to the city’s streets in the 1980s, it was largely unwelcome — and he was even arrested a few times.

headline: A Book Found in a Cairo Market Launched a 30-Year Quest: Who Was the Writer?
abstract: For Iman Mersal, the slim novel was “life altering.” She narrates her journey in the footsteps of its largely forgotten author in “Traces of Enayat.”
lead_paragraph: Crouching over piles of books in a market stall in Cairo one day in the fall of 1993, Iman Mersal stumbled upon a slim volume with a gray cover and a catchy title: “Love and Silence.”

headline: Boots, Backpack and a Ubiquitous App
abstract: Fourteen years and one Apple App of the Year award in, AllTrails has become something rare: a tool that works for both experts and newbies.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes and imagine a stereotypical hiker. Do the words “rugged” and “built Ford tough” come to mind? Are they wearing khaki shorts? Is a tube attached to a CamelBak hanging from their mouth?

headline: Watch These Cute Videos of Babies (and Learn Something, Too)
abstract: A social media account features smiley toddlers, while also offering positive lessons about child development.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible that on X — the social media site formerly known as Twitter and sometimes called “the hell site” — there remains a font of delight and edification, a place to witness laughter and even love?

headline: Why Did This Guy Put a Song About Me on Spotify?
abstract: The answer involves a remarkable — and lucrative, and ridiculous — scheme to game the way we find music today.
lead_paragraph: I don’t want to make this all about me, but have you heard the song “Brett Martin, You a Nice Man, Yes”?

headline: Ewan McGregor and Mary Elizabeth Winstead Go From ‘Fargo’ to ‘Moscow’
abstract: The actors, who met while filming “Fargo” in 2017, are now married and have reunited onscreen in “A Gentleman in Moscow.”
lead_paragraph: The first time that Ewan McGregor and Mary Elizabeth Winstead shot a scene together, they were in a bathtub, mostly naked. McGregor, in a maximally unflattering wig, was sticking his gut out as far as it would go.

headline: How Street Art Is Gentrifying Neighborhoods
abstract: Brands, developers and even city officials are embracing the global appeal of street art, but the boom comes with questions about preserving a neighborhood’s cultural cachet.
lead_paragraph: Brands, developers and even city officials are embracing the global appeal of street art, but the boom comes with questions about preserving a neighborhood’s cultural cachet.

headline: Hollywood’s New Fantasy: A Magical, Colorblind Past
abstract: Films and TV shows keep reimagining history as a multiracial dream world. Is that really a step forward?
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, in the cinema, I found myself trying to focus on Timothée Chalamet’s charming portrayal of a young Willy Wonka, arriving penniless in a new city. What drew my attention instead was the population he encountered there. The first person to greet him was a joyful British Indian. Soon we met a cute orphan sidekick, played by a Black American actor, and the chief of police, played by a biracial American. The vaguely Mitteleuropean city Wonka had come to — Viennese shops, Italian architecture, English language — was a happy melting pot: All races seemed to coexist without race meaning anything. The story was set in a fantastical past, but its cast looked like a utopian 21st-century London, with actors of British and Caribbean and Asian backgrounds all stirred together. The Oompa-​Loompas, described by Roald Dahl as a pygmy people found “in the very deepest and darkest part of the African jungle where no white man had ever been before,” were played by Hugh Grant.

headline: In Yemen, Renewed Conflict and Rising Hunger Stalk a Lean Ramadan
abstract: Airstrikes, crippling inflation and a drop in foreign aid are raising alarms about a new humanitarian crisis in the world’s poorest Arab country.
lead_paragraph: In the years before war and hunger upended daily life in Yemen, Mohammed Abdullah Yousef used to sit down after a long day of fasting during Ramadan to a rich spread of food. His family would dine on meat, falafel, beans, savory fried pastries and occasionally store-bought crème caramel.

headline: Trump Is Financially Ruining the Republican Party
abstract: How do you build a strong party when your money is also going to a candidate’s legal bills?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is someone you should think carefully about hitching your financial fortunes to. The guy is a gifted carnival barker, no doubt. But when it comes to serious business, he is a bad bet. Many of his ventures, from vodka and steaks to casinos and “university” degrees, have flopped like dying fish. Declaring corporate bankruptcy seems to be one of his favorite hobbies. And even when he wriggles away from failure largely unscathed, the other parties involved aren’t always so fortunate. Where money is involved, anyone still foolish enough to crawl into bed with him should be prepared for the experience to end in tears.

headline: Trump Is No Savior
abstract: It is fitting that the biggest movie in the world this year is the story of a messiah gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: It is fitting that the biggest movie in the world this year is the story of a messiah gone wrong.

headline: You Don’t Need to Freak Out About Boeing Planes (but Boeing Sure Does)
abstract: Commercial aviation remains miraculously safe, far more so than all the alternative ways of traveling.
lead_paragraph: “Ah, it’s a Boeing Max,” I exclaimed to my travel companions after we boarded our plane a few weeks ago. I looked to see if we were seated next to a hidden door plug panel like the one that blew out on Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 in January. We weren’t, but joining a trend on social media, we cracked a few jokes at Boeing’s expense: “Maybe they can charge extra, saying it’s potentially an even bigger window seat.”

headline: King Charles, Hoping to Reassure Public, Attends Easter Service
abstract: The family has been thrown off balance by health crises, including cancer diagnoses for the king and Catherine, Princess of Wales. She and her husband, Prince William, did not appear.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III attended the Easter church service on Sunday at Windsor Castle with Queen Camilla, later greeting well-wishers who had turned out to see his first significant public appearance since disclosing last month that he has cancer.

headline: Life at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Inside a new season of “Serial.”
lead_paragraph: Around 780 people have been detained at the prison at Guantánamo Bay since it opened in January 2002. Thirty men remain there today, many of whom have not been charged.

headline: Amid Health Concerns, Pope Delivers Strong Easter Message Calling for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: Pope Francis’ decisions to reduce his participation in two major Holy Week events had raised fears about his health.
lead_paragraph: Amid renewed concerns about his health, Pope Francis presided over Easter Sunday Mass, and with a hoarse but strong voice, he delivered a major annual message that touched on conflicts across the globe, with explicit appeals for peace in Israel, Gaza and Ukraine.

headline: We Still Haven’t Figured Out How to Beat ISIS
abstract: Stripping the Islamic State of its self-proclaimed caliphate is not the same as beating it.
lead_paragraph: For all of the counterterrorism wins that the United States has had in its fight against the Islamic State — and there have been many — we still have not figured out how to defeat it.

headline: There’s No Such Thing as an American Bible
abstract: Trump’s God Bless the USA Bible focuses on God’s blessing of one particular people. That is both its danger and, no doubt for some, its appeal.
lead_paragraph: The presumptive Republican nominee for president of the United States, who weeks ago started selling shoes, is now peddling Bibles. During Holy Week.

headline: Thousands Protest in Tel Aviv Against Netanyahu’s Government
abstract: Some scuffles broke out between police officers and demonstrators calling for the government to strike a cease-fire deal to free the hostages held in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Some scuffles broke out between police officers and demonstrators calling for the government to strike a cease-fire deal to free the hostages held in Gaza.

headline: Netanyahu will undergo hernia surgery at an important moment.
abstract: The
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will undergo surgery on Sunday night to treat a hernia, his office said in a statement.

headline: Beyoncé’s Country Is America: Every Bit of It
abstract: On the bold, sprawling “Cowboy Carter,” the superstar plays fast and loose — and twangy — with genre.
lead_paragraph: The first song on “Cowboy Carter,” Beyoncé’s not-exactly-country album, makes a pre-emptive strike. “It’s a lot of talking going on while I sing my song,” she observes in “Ameriican Requiem” over guitar strums and electric sitar, adding, “It’s a lot of chatter in here.”

headline: How to Use Up Those Easter Eggs
abstract: Deviled eggs, for sure. Maybe pickled eggs, cured with beets, vinegar and sugar, too?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I had a lovely run of Brooklyn sandwiches going, before work, school and Easter intervened to send me back to the kitchen. There was a classic Saigon-style bánh mì from Ba Xuyen in Sunset Park. A colossal roast beef, fried eggplant and mozzarella hero from Defonte’s in Red Hook, with hot peppers, gravy and mayonnaise. A ton-katsu sando on pillowy milk bread from Taku Sando in Greenpoint.

headline: Deep-Sixing Pornographic Deepfakes for Good
abstract: Responses to a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Analyzing Donald Trump’s base; a “deep state” makeover.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Esther Coopersmith, Washington Hostess and Diplomat, Dies at 94
abstract: A place at her dinner tables, which sat 75, provided access to networks of money, influence and power across cultural and political divides.
lead_paragraph: At a private fund-raising reception last year, the president of the United States introduced himself this way: “My name is Joe Biden. I’m a friend of Esther Coopersmith’s.”

headline: Lorraine Graves, Pioneering Harlem Ballerina, Dies at 66
abstract: Tall and commanding, she dazzled audiences as a principal dancer for the groundbreaking Dance Theater of Harlem for nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: Lorraine Graves, a ballerina known for her willowy frame and majestic grace who starred as a principal dancer for the groundbreaking Dance Theater of Harlem for nearly two decades, died on March 21 in Norfolk, Va. She was 66.
